chunks.text: Ivy. Here. Mister Lee. Here. Mister Burroughs. Here. Mister Danoka. He stepped away just for a moment. Miss Fisher. From here. Vice chair Harrison. He'll be right. He just stepped away, too. Mister Hawkins. Madam Clerk. I am present for the moment. Mister Olsen. Here, Miss Oyeva. Miss Watson. Still present. Eight members present. Oh, Mister Dedal. Next we have CB 37, an act concerning supplementary appropriations for the purpose of declaring additional revenue and appropriating to the general fund, an internal service fund to provide for costs that were not anticipated and included in the approved fiscal year 2024 budget. We will have a staff overview by Nathaniel Tutt. Good afternoon, madam chair. CB 37 2024, an act concerning supplementary appropriations. The legislation, if enacted, adjusts revenue estimates, increases general fund appropriations, and authorizes intra departmental transfers in the Internal Service Fund for the FY 24 25 budget as established in CB 63 2023. CB 37 2024 provides additional appropriation authority totaling $45,807,000 in the general fund. The following revenue adjustments in the bill serve to offset much of the supplemental budget increases, an adjustment in revenue estimates for the general real property tax receipts and an increase of 8.7 million. Interest income under use of money and property, an increase of 12.5 million and other miscellaneous receipts from radio one payments which increase $900,000 and Board of Education outside sources, 13 million. The remaining $10 million is covered by the use of assigned fund balance enactment of CB 37, according to our policy analysis team and Andrew Stover wrote the document, will have an adverse fiscal impact related to the use of the $10 million in fund balance I mentioned, with the remainder of additional expenditures being offset by the additional revenue. As noted, the legislation increases the fiscal year 2024 general fund budget from 4.5 billion to 4.559 $440,400. Thank you, Madam Chair. Oh, and we have Mister Brent Johnson, one of the senior staffers at the department of office of Management and Budget, I should say, is here with me. Do you have some comments you'd like to share? I think that was a good summary, and if there are any questions, I'm here to answer them. Do we have anything from the county executive's office? What Mister Johnson just said, madam chair. Okay, great. And is there a motion for committee recommendation favorable? We have a motion by council member Hawkins, second by council member Olson. Please call the roll. And madam chair favorable on the draft two a. Yes on draft two a. Okay. Thank you. I didn't even see that. Yes, that was the substitute version that was sent earlier today. Okay. Yes, I'm sorry, I forgot that I needed to mention that. Um. Hi, Miss Bligay. Hi, Mister Burke. Oh, he stepped away. Mister Danoga. Aye. Miss Fisher. Aye. Mister Harrison, vice chair. Oh, he stepped away, too. My apologies, Mister Hawkins. Did you say we're playing tennis or am I voting? You'll vote, sir. Oh, I vote aye. Mister Olson? Aye. Miss Orrietta? Yes. Miss Watson. Aye. Motion carries, 80. Thank you. I would just like to note that the proposed amendments to the endorsed Bowie, Mitchellville and vicinity sectional map amendment will be deferred till May 28. Is there a motion to adjourn committee of the whole second? All those in favor, please raise your hand. We are adjourned. We will return as county council momentarily.

chunks.text: Good afternoon. Today is the Education Workforce Development Committee standing committee hearing Monday, April 22, 2024. We have a quorum, so Madam Clerk, can you please call the roll? Chair Harrison? Madam Clerk, I vote aye. I mean president. Yeah. Councilmember Hawkins. Madam Clerk present. Council member Oriata here. Three members present. Madam Clerk aye. Thank you Madam Clerk. Now we're going to kick it off to the committee director, Mister Albert Obeer, sir. Thank you and good afternoon. I will turn over to David Nota, the legislative budget and policy analyst, to provide an overview of employee Prince George's proposed fiscal year 2025 budget. Good afternoon Chair Harrison and members of the Education Workforce Development Committee. My name is David Noto and I'm a member of the Office of Budget and Policy and I'll be presenting on employ Prince George's fiscal year 2025 proposed budget report this report can be found on page 200 of your virtual Binder employ Prince George is a 501 organization that serves as the the primary employment services division of the county that is partially funded through annual county grants in the non departmental section of the budget. The proposed 2025 budget totals $18,323,100, an increase of 1.9 million, or 11.7%, over the fiscal year 2024 approved budget. These budget increases are driven by an increase in operating costs, annualization of planned salary adjustments, and additional staffing needed to support new grant programs. The proposed budget includes a direct county contribution of 3.6 million made up of the county executive grant of 1.7 million, the reentry program grant of 300,000, the video lottery terminal grant of $637,700, and the returning Citizens Affairs Division grant of $1 million. Employee Prince George is also expected to receive an additional grant from the county in the form of a department of Family Services grant of $214,000. These represent about 21% of the total budget. On page two of your report you will see a table showing a breakdown of the different funding streams from the county and the relative portion of the money from each two employed. All three expenditure categories are proposed to increase due to annualization. Planned salary adjustments and additional staffing. Operating expenses are proposed. The fiscal year 2025 staffing account includes 21 county funded full time positions, which has remained constant from the previous fiscal year, but non county funded positions have increased to 99 non county funded positions, up from 81 in fiscal year 2024. Page seven outlines employ Prince George's mission and core services, as well as their accomplishments in fiscal year 2024. Among their major accomplishments for this past fiscal year are they created and increased a pipeline of workers that go through training and enter apprenticeships through the International Union of Painters and Allied Trades. They increased the number of participants engaged in pre apprenticeship and apprenticeship trainings in all industries, increased traffic flow and programming at the national at the American Jobs Center National harbor and enhanced their commitment to bring special populations such as returning citizens and youth, through development of the bridge center at Adams House and the Youth Career center, as well as launching a system to track participant services across the workforce ecosystem to limit duplication of services and improve customer outcomes. Employ Prince George's primary concern is the decrease in the county's work labor force. From January 2019 to January 2024, the county has 18,614 fewer jobs in its labor force and 10,505 fewer jobs. Nonetheless, the January 2024 numbers are an improvement from January 2023 numbers, with the county having gained over 1800 workers and over 2950 jobs. The charts on page nine of the report show some of employ Prince George's performance metrics over the past five fiscal years, which show significant improvements in the number of jobs posted by employee Prince George's and a steady improvement in the percentage of employ Prince George's placements who remained employed at the business in which they were placed after one year. Thank you. That concludes my remarks on employee Prince George's. If you have questions about the report, I'm happy to take them at this time. Thank you, sir. Now we're going to kick it over to the president and CEO Walter Simmons to speak on his budget. Good afternoon, committee members. We decided because we were here about three weeks ago, to not go through another 45 minutes of presentation. But as the council staff did highlight, the main focus is going to be on a labor force recovery strategy. When we compare 20, when we look at 24, compared to pre Covid, when you're looking at right December of 19 Maryland, and when we're talking resident workforce, that's going a different, that's going away from the economic development employment number. But looking at your La U S data

chunks.text: number of jobs posted by employee Prince George's and a steady improvement in the percentage of employ Prince George's placements who remained employed at the business in which they were placed after one year. Thank you. That concludes my remarks on employee Prince George's. If you have questions about the report, I'm happy to take them at this time. Thank you, sir. Now we're going to kick it over to the president and CEO Walter Simmons to speak on his budget. Good afternoon, committee members. We decided because we were here about three weeks ago, to not go through another 45 minutes of presentation. But as the council staff did highlight, the main focus is going to be on a labor force recovery strategy. When we compare 20, when we look at 24, compared to pre Covid, when you're looking at right December of 19 Maryland, and when we're talking resident workforce, that's going a different, that's going away from the economic development employment number. But looking at your La U S data, your local area unemployment, which is resident employment, Maryland lost 160,000 workers out of its labor force, and that's resident workers. Out of that 160,000, Prince George county equates to close to 30,000. So when you look at the 24 municipalities, of course 30,000 out of that is a large number. We also know that the labor force reduction chronically impacted those who were what you call just making it, you know, you're working poor population, which we really consider the Alice population asset, limited income constrained but employed, which means they're about $1,000 away from $1,000 expense, emergency expense away from being below the poverty line. So that's where you see an increase in our outreach efforts, the mobile job center, things of that sort. We can't fill positions if we don't have the workers. And so we have to figure out how do we rebound from those 30,000 that are not on any. They're out of the system means they're not on unemployment, they're not on taNf, they're not on snap. We have to reengage them with some point of the system. And so that will be really an ongoing theme, which we expect for the next few years, of how do we reengage? And we think the best portion of the re engagement is to start with our school system and starting there with the population that's graduating and connecting them to local businesses and opportunities. Also our colleges and universities, then looking at our other non traditional populations. When I mean nontraditional, I mean the populations that pre pandemic employers didn't want to hire, that is returning citizens, that is immigrants, that is high school dropouts, that is people with lower skills. Because now that there isn't a large population of workers, these traditionally non traditional or populations that they'd want to engage, they are a population that do want to engage. As we saw with the kickoff to reentry month, some of our large businesses have already started making commitments to higher populations. Luminous health, where we held the kickoff of the second chance month, is one of those larger businesses that has made a commitment to hire returning citizens, which we didn't see from our, you know, your larger businesses historically. And so what we tend to do is to really identify those populations through our reentry program, through our populations that are working with immigrants. We just launched our first CDL program that is in Spanish. So a CDL spanish program. I was. Was there this morning at the site in Forestville. And so that's the work that we will continue. Also working on entrepreneurship with the gig economy and creating those where we have entrepreneurship programs for reentry for young people and for immigrants, refugees in the sales. So that labor force recovery strategy, we already have a low unemployment, 2%, 2.4%. But that doesn't tell the true story of populations that have been left behind. We want to try to get those populations reengaged and then also work on our young people to build the future pipeline. And the one thing that we'd also like to highlight as well is the work in the community to engage. So tomorrow, we are opening our first american job center job and resource lab. We want to put one in every 27 municipalities this committee helped us connect. So district Heights is going to be the first to open tomorrow. We invite everybody to attend about 10:00 we also, our next is Laurel and the multi service center is open in there. And we hope that through the next year we'll see six or seven resource labs pop up in our communities. We're also working with a storage facility recommended by chair Ivey to really bring these services to the community and really using what you call credible messengers. That's how we're going to connect with the unconnected, disconnected population is to not ask them to come to our job center, but to go to where they are and work through people that they already trust. And that's how we're really going to rebuild this 30,000 workers that we lost. So I don't want to bore you with another hour long presentation, so I'll keep it there. Thank you. President and CEO, Mister Simmons. Colleagues, are there any questions for Mister Simmons? We have vice chair Watson. Thank you Mister chair. Good to see you all. You know, EPG is close to my heart. Just have one question, because you all really answered a lot of questions previously. But in regard to you mentioned working with the schools and reengaging in regards to the labor force recovery strategy. So in one of our budget hearings, I believe it was EDC, it was mentioned that cyber and it was lacking as far as trying to find the appropriate people to hire in the county. They can't find those people here. So I didn't know. Is that one of the industries that were looking to help fill, based on who were kind of re engaging at the schools and what, or what industries are we looking to the schools to engage them to fill positions for which ty

chunks.text: ing to rebuild this 30,000 workers that we lost. So I don't want to bore you with another hour long presentation, so I'll keep it there. Thank you. President and CEO, Mister Simmons. Colleagues, are there any questions for Mister Simmons? We have vice chair Watson. Thank you Mister chair. Good to see you all. You know, EPG is close to my heart. Just have one question, because you all really answered a lot of questions previously. But in regard to you mentioned working with the schools and reengaging in regards to the labor force recovery strategy. So in one of our budget hearings, I believe it was EDC, it was mentioned that cyber and it was lacking as far as trying to find the appropriate people to hire in the county. They can't find those people here. So I didn't know. Is that one of the industries that were looking to help fill, based on who were kind of re engaging at the schools and what, or what industries are we looking to the schools to engage them to fill positions for which type? Which industry is what I'm trying to say. Yeah. So we've identified. We've identified 13 in demand industries. That's a lot to try to do it all. So we broke them down into six clusters. One of those clusters is it and cybersecurity. Second is professional services. The third is construction and real estate. The fourth is hospitality and accommodation. We also are looking at transportation logistics. We're also looking at healthcare and social assistance. So those are the six clusters we are convening employers. We have business advisory councils. Each of those employers is working with a contractor which is called a council for adult and experiential learning Cael. And we're developing career pathways and competency maps. We've already released two. One for healthcare and a second for retail and hospitality. Next up is going to be it and cybersecurity and the rest of those clusters, they should be released by the end of this calendar year. And part of that work is letting the young people know which industries are prevalent, what are the skill sets, what are the certifications, but also what are the on ramps. Can you start working this career in high school? Can we match that interest that you have in school with your summer youth employment, either through the Office of Human Resources or we have multiple summer youth programs along with these other summer youth programs. So we're working with these different programs to connect them with employers and placements so that what they're learning in the schools matches what they're doing in the summer and really creating those on ramps. Also working on apprenticeship opportunities. But those six clusters which have the highest business and employment need. We are trying to match young people and also their parents. So when we engage, we're also engaging the parents and letting their parents know. And that's key to that strategy of working with your offices and the municipalities, of letting their parents know what's available to them and then bringing in those non traditional community partners like Patriot Technology Center. Thurman is someone that has been around for 30 years. People have known. He just got a building donated to him through bank of America. They do the cyber, they do the academies, they do the competitions. That class and those competitions should have 1000 students packed, right? Having a couple of hundred at this size of our county isn't enough. So we need to do a better job of getting the word out. I mean, and they have NASA, they have Northrop Grumman, they have DoD contractors. The employers are already coming to them because they need to work. We have to do a better job of getting the students and their parents aware of those opportunities. And so that's what we hope to do. Focus. And that's why we're concentrating on those six clusters, which does include it, and cybersecurity. Okay. And one question to piggyback on that. Do you have people in the schools or in every school in the county, or is there some engagement with all the schools in the county? And how do you do that? Well, through the blueprint for Maryland's future, there was a component to fund the workforce boards to put staff in the schools. We are working with Prince Church county public Schools right now. We aren't in the schools yet. Weekly we'd like to be. We're having a huge push, really, that started this week with the school system to talk to the principals and try to get in front of those graduating seniors that aren't on track for the college of the military. I hope it's by the first day of next school year. We've hired 50 career consultants to be in every middle and high school across the public school system. And that's our goal. That at the start of next year those 50 will start to be in the schools on a weekly basis. Thank you. Thank you Madam vice chair Watson, councilmember, orator, before we turn to you, I know Mister early wanted to make a quick comment. Mister, thank you Mister chair. Just quick comment. Coming out of Annapolis there may be an additional adjustment in the budget for employ Prince George's as there was a program that we believe may give a little more resources. So that may be coming. And I also wanted to say that I think Mister Simmons has really identified a critical problem. The state, the state's chief economist has talked about has put out some interesting material that Maryland is not only we not only have that shrunken workforce, but we are separated from the other states around us because they're in a more upward trend. So it's a little bit hard to explain because even people like in the DC that's higher cost area is it has that. So that is a, so the area he's talking about is a much more critical focus than it was a year ago. Thank you Mister early council member Oriato. Thank you. Thank you for the presentation. I just had a few questions. One, I wanted to start with the reentry program that you guys have with the incentives i

chunks.text: Mister chair. Just quick comment. Coming out of Annapolis there may be an additional adjustment in the budget for employ Prince George's as there was a program that we believe may give a little more resources. So that may be coming. And I also wanted to say that I think Mister Simmons has really identified a critical problem. The state, the state's chief economist has talked about has put out some interesting material that Maryland is not only we not only have that shrunken workforce, but we are separated from the other states around us because they're in a more upward trend. So it's a little bit hard to explain because even people like in the DC that's higher cost area is it has that. So that is a, so the area he's talking about is a much more critical focus than it was a year ago. Thank you Mister early council member Oriato. Thank you. Thank you for the presentation. I just had a few questions. One, I wanted to start with the reentry program that you guys have with the incentives in the private sector. I just want to make sure my notes were correct. Are there three businesses right now that are, are in partnership you guys are in partnership with for that program, the private sector? You're talking about the Princess County Reentry Employment Incentive fund? Yeah, it's at the early stages of launch, but we've expressed more, we've seen more businesses express interest, but putting them through the application process has been limited so far. Okay. And then for I know there's a pathway to government jobs program. Is that a program that is just open that just. Our focus is on specifically returning citizens. So pathways the government focuses on returning citizens getting into government jobs. How many have been placed to date in that program with jobs? I think I'd have to give you the exact number. I don't think it's changed much from March due to some hiring slowing at the county level. So I can pull the exact number, but I don't think much changed since what we promoted in March. Can you refresh my memory with that number. I have a number in my head, but I'm not sure if that's right. I can pull it up for you right now. Thank you. And then while you're looking for that, another question, because I'm just trying to get a grasp of where we are with the end goal, which is making sure that we get people in jobs long term. So if we look at the numbers where you have jobs posted, then we have the numbers of who was placed and then stayed after a year. And then if I go on the budget book and look at, for example, the number of people that visited the work center, looking at 2024, for example, we see like over 10,000 people visited the work center. Then we have about 1075, let's say 1700 jobs posted, 220 estimate placements. Right. So that just seems like a big gap between the amount of people that are coming in looking for employment, the amount of jobs posted, and the actual amount of people placed. And so just what could we do to help bridge that gap from the amount of people that are actually entering, actually leaving with a job? And what can we do from a council perspective to assist you in that? No, that's great. I think the number that we're looking at, and I have to take more time, twelve is the last pathways to government number that we have. Thank you, Jeff. Let's make sure we circle back after the hearing to make sure we get the most accurate. Related to that number we talked about in the last hearing was data. Again, this is our first full year utilizing the system that you all funded, which is the virtual career center in years past where we want to bring. So we use the job centers like a WeWork model. Nonprofits, community based organizations can get access to these centers. And it gives them an address, it gives them support staff, things of that sort. It also opens the door to other government agencies. They're not only the people that we fund are mandated to use our system. Everybody else was using their own system. And then we were using the state labor exchange, which doesn't allow, because Maryland labor controls, that doesn't allow them. So we can track who comes into the center, what happens after. If they. Now, we are one of the largest partners in the center, of course. But if they go to a nonprofit or they go to Maryland Department of Labor, we only get what they agree to give us. Now, with the virtual career center and our atlas, we can now give a free resource to nonprofits and government agencies so that they can agree to track what we hope and what we've talked to OMB, and what we hope to bring eventually to the council and the county execs office is that we can get every nonprofit that receives county funding to track those outcomes in the system. It allow us to show our investments, it's allowed to show the outcomes. But right now, what you see is what we can track, not the. Every single partner in there. And, I mean, we could say that with your discounted lease space, you have to report it. But then we run the risk of an organization not using the center, and then kind of. We're kind of in that chicken or the egg, where if they leave, the community leaves a resource, or if they don't have the capacity to track it, we don't have a funding mechanism to give them that capacity. But this is the first year, ending in June 30 that we will have the virtual career center. We've been talking with the staff of getting those numbers, and we should be able to start seeing that change, of getting a true number of not just seeing who walks through the center, which we checked from that, but actually seeing which nonprofit served who. What was the outcome? Did they refer it? And then we've got a couple of government agencies that have also agreed they're going to have to do dual data entry, but we've agreed to share the data, could help them with grant revenue fundraising, but eventually, we would like to see every partner in the center provide that programmatic data and no

Thank you. Thank you. Please introduce yourself. My name is Nicholas Worrell from the National Transportation Safety Board and I want to talk today a little bit about the pedestrian safety concerns. NTSB appreciates the opportunity to provide some information regarding a special investigation report on pedestrian safety and especially on our call for the increased use of pedestrian safety action plans. We hope that the information I provide today can be helpful in convening the school pedestrian safety workgroup. My agency, the NTSB, investigate accidents and crashes in all modes of transportation, aviation, railroad, pipeline, highway and commercial space. We also conduct studies concerning transportation safety, such as our special investigative report on pedestrian safety. The recommendations we issue based on our investigation and studies are our most important product for saving lives. A lot of the report recommendations focus on infrastructure. My personal shorthand we teach our children to look both ways before crossing the streets, but we must also give them crosswalks and crossing guards to support. We published a report in 2018 of special investigative report after the 2016 Pedestrian Safety Public Forum and TSP, where experts discuss data, designs and technology, and after we investigate a dozen fatal pedestrian crashes. And one of the reports we issued eleven safety recommendations and we urge the Federal Highway Safety Administration to promote municipal pedestrian safety action plans that develop a network of safety improvements, local pedestrian safety action plans. They seek to improve and cooperate pedestrians and transportation networks. The objective of pedestrian safety action plans are to establish risk assessment frameworks, identify data requirement for selecting and evaluating actions, and prioritize countermeasures for increasing safety. The publication how to develop a pedestrian safety action plan is available at the federal Highway Administration. It's called for analyzed safety data, seeking public input and coordinating the planning process. It recommends engaging with citizen groups, local public agencies, effective private sector interests and the media, as well as coordinating other local plans. Our findings recognize that effective street designs for pedestrian safety are highly context dependent and should be managed by local interests. However, states and cities would benefit from resources, tools, funding, support to develop and implement effective plans. The design guidance need to develop effective pedestrian safety action plans is readily available to local transportation planners. Addressing the pedestrian safety design changes needed for many of the urban environment will take substantially more resources, and I hope this information is valuable to the committee as you move forward with putting together your work group for pedestrian safety. Thank you. Thank you so much. We will go to council member Watson for a GOFP report. Thank you, Madam chair. The Prince George's County Council's government operations and fiscal policy committee convened on March 14, 2024 to consider CB Zero zero 720 24. CB seven is an act concerning an elderly property tax credit which revises the current elderly property tax credit to make its applicability exclusive, separate and distinct from the homestead and Maryland homeowners property tax credits. Committee staff provided an overview of the bill and background for the legislation, including comparisons to surrounding jurisdictions, qualification requirements, the duration of residence, income and or assessed value limits, and other requirements that could mitigate the fiscal impact. The bill, as drafted will authorize individuals to receive the credit if they are at least 65 years old and have lived in their home for a minimum of ten years and the home's assessed value is less than 500,000. The projected cost is $11,120,634. In tax credits granted annually. The maximum value shall increase annually on July 1 by the lesser of the consumer price index for the preceding calendar year, or 3%. The credit shall be granted each year for a period of up to five years if the individual remains eligible for the credits. The sponsor of the legislation, councilmember Burroughs, reminded the committee that CB 29 2022 passed unanimously establishing a 20% reduction of property tax. A provision in CB 29 requires that the credit is inclusive of any homestead or homeowners tax credit provided, which caused many residents not to benefit from the credit. CV seven removes that requirement and will allow many more senior residents to qualify. Public comments from 22 members of the committee were heard and over 100 attended. Everyone who testified expressed support for the tax credits enactment during the council members discussion, proposals to change the eligibility from ten years to 20 years and changes to the qualifications to include income instead of assessed value or not accepted. Council members expressed concern about the impact on the budget and a desire to keep the promise made when CB 29 2022 was enacted. The county executive's liaison reminded the committee that the executive was in support of CB 29 2022, the initial tax credit legislation. The liaison asked that the members reconsider the methodology for qualification for the credits used in this bill to avoid unintended consequences and decrease the fiscal impact. The administration does not feel that considering our budget deficit and the way that the legislation is drafted will provide the support that seniors expect. The county executive took no position on the legislation as drafted. The government operations and Fiscal policy committee reported CB 720 24 out favorably. Five to zero. That concludes my report. Thank you. CB zero zero. 720 24 stands introduced. Madam Chair, because council members Harrison and Bligh are not here, we will need to remove them as sponsors. I just wanted to state that for the record. Okay, thank you. This is sponsored by council member Oriata and we'll have a committee report from council member Fisher. Thank you, Madam Chair. The Health and Human Services and Public Safety Committee convened on March 21, 2024 to consider CB 1020 24. The bill requires the Department of Health to create and disseminate specific literature to businesses selling firearms or ammunition, and I believe there are about six that are identified in the county. The literature pertains to gun and firearm safety, gun and firearm training, suicide prevention, mental health and conflict resolution. The sellers are to suppose signs on the premises where such transactions occur and distribute them to all individuals who purchase firearms or ammunition. The Department of Health has the authority to enforce regulation and failure to comply will consist of a civil violation and that may result into a fine up to $100 or $1,000 I think it's supposed to be. The legislative budget and policy analyst provide an overview of the bill and details on the fiscal impact. Further, when enacted, CB 1024 may have a favorable indirect impact on the county if successfully reduces the overall number of suicide attempts occurring in the county, which would reduce the workload of our police, fire and other emergency services to respond to such attempts. Over a year ago, I testified in front of this council advocating for the enactment of this crucial legislation, and I'm heartened to see the positive impact that has had in our community since its implementation. Throughout the past year, we've heard concerns from landlords and property managers who feared that the Rent Stabilization act would threaten their ability to operate. However, despite these concerns, we have witnessed them continue to conduct business as usual, demonstrating that reasonable limitations on rent increases have not hindered their operations. In fact, this legislation has helped strike the balance between the needs of tenants and the entrance of property owners, fostering a more equitable rental market for all. As the director of organizing for Life after release and a member of the Prince George's County Housing Justice Coalition. I have seen firsthand the impact of stable housing on individuals transitioning from incarceration. People who are incarcerated are ten times more likely to be unhoused, and unhoused people are eleven times more likely to be incarcerated. And it's also important to emphasize that 70% of Maryland's prison population are black people. So this is an issue of public safety and racial equity. For many, access to affordable housing is a linchpin in their journey towards successful integration into society. By extending the sunset provision of the Rent Stabilization act for an additional six months, we have the opportunity to continue providing essential support to those in our community who need it most. Let us not lose sight of the progress we've made in addressing homelessness and housing insecurity in Prince George's county. Let us stand firm in our commitment to ensuring that everyone has access to safe and affordable housing. And by extending this critical legislation, we affirm our dedication to building a more just and equitable future for all members of our community. Of our community. These figures included african american population in the county, the average income comparison to white residents of Prince George county, and the county's historical connections to slavery and specific plantations that are actually still present and used as park space in Prince George's county. Recognizing the historical backdrop of slavery in Prince George's county is crucial as it helps us understand the foundation on which we stand. Advocating to establish the Maryland Reparations Commission by the General assembly reflects a dedication to justice and historic guidance. The council calls upon the General assembly to stand with states like New York, California, and others that have already started their own commissions on behalf of the county executive. Secinda Skinner, the county council liaison, expressed support from the county executive for CR 520 24. Public testimony was heard from delegate Athea McCaskill from Baltimore County District 44. Her support on CR 2024 on behalf of the legislative black caucus. Delegate McCaskill indicates that it's essential to be cohesive and on one accord when it comes to reparations because things, because of the various things that have happened in the african american community that impact us all. Delegate McCaskill indicated that she looks forward to working with stakeholders and modifying the bill. She is the main point person for the Black caucus on reparations for the upcoming 2025 session, and she hopes that General assembly will be encouraged by the council's support. Additionally, Reverend Kobe Little, the president of the NAACP for the state of Maryland, spoke in support of CR 520 24. Reverend Little emphasized that reparations are healing and repairing his historic injustices to African Americans and advocating for unity and action to address these issues. Linda Thornton Thomas, our own president of the NAACP for Prince George's county branch, stated the NAACP aims to extend its efforts beyond the county's borders and ensure widespread adoption. It aims to explore avenues of providing reparations, whether it's in housing opportunities, education, or business ownership. Josephine Mourning, a president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference for Prince George's county and obviously it was founded by Doctor Martin Luther King spoke in support of CR 520 24 on behalf of C of C of CLC, indicating it's been long overdue for descendants of African Americans who are severely impacted by chattel slavery. NAACP NCLC support for reparations Commission is rooted in recognizing injustice and the need for economic empowerment and business opportunities of African Americans. Nicole Bruno, a Prince George county resident for twelve years, also spoke in favor of establishing a commission. Miss Bruno of caucasian nationality acknowledged the potential opposition. However, she emphasized the importance of creating an environment that's conducive to exploration, creativity and envisioning a fair, more liberated future. Whereas the office of the county Executive for Prince George's County, Maryland Council chair Jolene Ivey and at large council member Calvin Hawkins wish to recognize the month of April 2024 as second chance month whereas second chance month is a nationwide effort to raise awareness of the barriers faced by individuals with criminal records and to unlock brighter futures for returning citizens, providing second chances and supporting reentry efforts not only benefits returning citizens, but also strengthens families, communities and the economy. By promoting policies and initiatives that remove barriers to reentry, we can help individuals with criminal records rebuild their lives and contribute positively to society and whereas the also Brooks administration and the county council have been committed to strengthening reentry service since the start by including reentry as one of her priorities, with the goal of better coordinating reentry service and finding ways to strengthen those services through a centralized office and whereas the reentry advisory board was created by council resolution 49 2019 to address the needs of returning citizens in Prince George's county, researching best practices and surveying county agencies and nonprofit organizations to identify gaps in services and make recommendations to the office of the county executive, including the creation of the Prince George's County Returning Citizens Affairs Division. Whereas established in May 2022, the Returning Citizens Affairs Division is dedicated to leading the county and being a regional and national model reentry ecosystem, providing residents released from incarceration in state, local and federal facilities with opportunities to transform their lives and become fully engaged and productive members of the community. Whereas the Returning Citizens Affairs Division provides countywide coordination and oversight for Prince George's county network of services for returning citizens, including coordination of services, community engagement, policy and advocacy, research, resource development, programmatic assessments and recommendations and the creation of a reentry playbook to guide the division in building an ecosystem that works for returning citizens in Prince George's county and wHereas, the returning Citizens Affairs Division has convened faith leaders from throughout Prince George's county to discuss strategies to help returning citizens, including securing personal documentation, supporting reentry ministries, and creating mentoring programs, the Returning Citizens Affairs Division has also launched the Pathways to Government initiative, the Reentry Employment Incentive program, thanks to Mel Franklin, as well as awarded 100,000 in grants to community based organizations. Now, therefore, Angela Osterbrooks, county Executive and county chair Jolene Ivey, and the county council for Prince George's County, Maryland do hereby proclaim April 2024 as check and chance month in honor of the efforts to increase awareness of obstacles in place that hinder those with criminal records from becoming productive members of our community. insights.observation: The Returning Citizens Affairs Division provides countywide coordination and oversight for Prince George's county network of services for returning citizens, including coordination of services, community engagement, policy and advocacy, research, resource development, programmatic assessments and recommendations and the creation of a reentry playbook to guide the division in building an ecosystem that works for returning citizens in Prince George's county.
The county has hired ten returning citizens in county agencies, ranging from the Department of Public Works and Transportation to the health department.

The Returning Citizens Affairs Division has convened faith leaders from throughout Prince George's county to discuss strategies to help returning citizens, including securing personal documentation, supporting reentry ministries, and creating mentoring programs.
The Returning Citizens Affairs Division has also launched the Pathways to Government initiative and the Reentry Employment Incentive program.
Awarded $100,000 in grants to community based organizations.

The Board of Appeal hearings are being called to order at 06:00 p.m. on Wednesday, May 8, 2024, per the discussed decision announced by the county executive, effective March 9, 2022, at 05:00 p.m. the Prince George's county state of emergency expired in an abundance of caution, and given the current state of the novel coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic, the county council is now operating under the following procedures. The Board of Appeals in person meetings and or hearings continue to operate virtually using alternative public participation options, including utilization of digital technology or teleconferencing. Virtual hearings are recorded and transcribed during the meeting. Please state your name for the record each time you speak for clarity in transcription. Please do not speak over another person. If you wish to speak, please raise your hand to be called upon. I will call upon you in turn. Please listen carefully to our criteria. Our criteria for granting appeals involving variances pursuant to Council Bill CB 16 2021, section 27 230 of the Zoning Ordinance authorizes the board to grant variances when a specific parcel of land is physically unique and unusual in a manner different from the nature of surrounding properties with respect to exceptional narrowness, shallowness, shape, exceptional topographic conditions, or other extraordinary conditions peculiar to the specific parcel, such as historical significance or environmentally sensitive features. The particular uniqueness and peculiarity of this specific property causes a zoning provision to impact disproportionate proportionately upon that property, such that strict application of the provision will result in peculiar and unusual practical difficulties to the owner of the property. Such variance is the minimum reasonably necessary to overcome the exceptional physical conditions. Such variances can be granted without substantial impairment to the intent, purpose, and integrity of the general plan or any area, master plan, sector plan, or transit district development plan affecting the subject property, and such variance will not substantially impair the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, a variance may not be granted if the practical difficulty is self inflicted by the owner of the property. All of these criteria must apply. If the board determines that it needs to seek technical assistance from any other governmental agency, we shall do so. The approval of a variance is not a guarantee that further review will not be necessary by any other governmental authorities. Following the approval of a variance, a building permit must be obtained. Before any building permits will be processed by the county permits office, a copy of the board's written order must be presented. Approval of any variance is contingent upon development of the property in compliance with the board's approved site and elevation plans. If the board determines that it needs to seek technical assistance from any other governmental agency, we shall do so. Approval of any variance is contingent upon development of the property in compliance with the board's approved site and elevation plans. All board of appeal hearings are virtual. Dear members of the board, we are writing to express our strong opposition to the zoning building permit application for the proposed single family home located at 4711 Main Street, Capital Heights, Maryland. As adjoining property owners, neighbors, and community members, we are deeply concerned about the potential negative impacts this development could have on the surrounding properties, characters of the neighborhood, and the community as a whole. First and foremost, the proposed single family home fails to comply with the zoning regulations outlined in the Prince George's county zoning ordinance. Specifically, section 24 442 B, table one, or I, rather than rather the proposed variance, requests consideration under a previous zoning ordinance with no explanation as to why this property should not be subject to current regulations. The current ordinance sets forth clear guidelines and standards for setbacks lot coverage, building height and other important factors that are essential for maintaining the integrity and character of the neighborhood. The proposed lot coverage does not align with the requirements outlined in the zoning ordinance, potentially encroaching upon the privacy and enjoyment of adjacent property owners. In fact, because the petitioner is asking for 4ft of rear yard depth, excuse me, the residents at 1121 Eastern Avenue would have their privacy significantly impacted and encroached upon. Additionally, with a total lot width of 40ft and a house plantable width of 40 of 30ft, this will only allow for a maximum of 5ft of space from the property line shared with both 4709 man and 4713 man. This does not adhere to the current county codes which require a setback of 8ft from the side property lines. It does not appear that a variance has been requested for this discovery discrepancy. Although a variance has been requested for the total lot coverage, the neighborhood community feels that the proposed single family home is too large for the lot upon which it will sit. The size of the proposed dwelling will have a significant impact upon the privacy, use and enjoyment of the current property owners. Along with these concerns, the community also has a variety of concerns regarding drainage, parking, pests and the current presence of a number of unfinished developments in the local area. Prince George's county general variance decision standards indicate that a variance to zoning ordinance may only be granted when the board of appeals finds that one, a specific parcel of land is physically unique and unusual in a manner different from the nature of the surrounding properties with respect to exceptional narrowness, shallowness, shape, exceptional topographical conditions, or other extraordinary conditions peculiar to the specific parcel, such as the historical significance or environmentally sensitive features. Two, the particular uniqueness and I'm going to struggle with this word sorry, peculiarity of the specific property causes a zoning provision to impact disproportionately upon that property such that strict application of the provision will result in peculiar and unusual practical difficulties to the owner of the property. Three, such variance is the minimum reasonably necessary to overcome the exceptional physical conditions. Four, such variants can be granted without substantial impairment to the intent, purpose and integrity of the general plan or any functional master plan area master plan sector plan affecting the subject property. Five, such variants will not substantially impair the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties and six, a variance may not be granted if the practical difficulty is self inflicted by the owner of the property. As owners of the neighboring property, we dispute that one, the parcel under consideration is physically unique and unusual. Two, the zoning provisions disproportionately impacts the parcel under consideration three, the variance requested is the minimum reasonable reasonably necessary to overcome the exceptional physical conditions. Four, the variance can be granted without substantial impairment to the plans affecting the parcel under consideration, and five, the variance requested can be granted without substantial impairment of the use and enjoyment of the adjacent properties. In light of these concerns, we urge you to carefully reconsider the approval of the zoning building permit for the proposed single family home. It is imperative that any development in our community adheres to the established and current zoning regulation and considers the current use and enjoyment of adjacent properties. Thank you for taking the time to consider our objections to this project. insights.observation: The community embraces diversity and growth, and is proud of its diverse population.
There is a desire to preserve the green space aesthetic of the community.
Approval of variances for lot sizes and coverage will negatively affect the overall landscape of the community.
The variances would substantially impair the use and enjoyment of adjacent property, violating county requirements.
Concerns that cutting down vegetation would lead to water runoff issues into neighboring yards.
The community supports growth as long as it adheres to existing rules, regulations, and zoning ordinances.

chunks.text: Good afternoon. Today is May 6. Monday, May 6, 2024. We are convening as the education workforce Development Committee. Today we have the Prince George's county public school systems before us to give us a briefing and questions and answers on particular questions that we might have. Unfortunately, we don't have a quorum, so today's meeting is for just informational purposes. And so I guess, Madam Clerk, you can call the roll for the members that are present, please. Chair Harrison. Thank you. I'm present. Vice Chair Watson? Present. Two members present. Thank you so much, Mister House superintendent, you are before our committee today to give us a presentation on the athletics and the athletic field presentation that we have at the Prince George's county public school system. So, before we kick it off over to you, I'm going to look to our committee director if he has any other information. Thank you, Chair Harrison. No additional information. So, Mister House, the floor is yours. Thank you, Chair Harrison and council members. Madam chair, it's always good to see you as well. We do have a presentation that we'd like to walk you through, and we welcome any additional questions beyond the presentation. So without further ado, I will turn it over to my operations team to do so. Thank you. All right. Thank you so much, Superintendent House. And good afternoon, council members. Joining me this afternoon to provide this presentation are our coordinating. Or is our coordinating supervisor of interscholastic athletics, Miss Shirley Diggs. And also our capital programs director, Miss Shayla Taylor, in addition to myself. So if we can see the presentation, mister. Doctor Coleman, if you could give Mister House an opportunity to introduce his team. I'm sorry? Oh, sure. All these people here with all these doctors in front of their names, we want to make sure we give them all the respect in the world. We'll just. We'll just start on that end down there and have everyone introduce themselves. I can't see everybody. From. From. From right to left, Jason Washington, associate superintendent of supporting services. Good afternoon. Shiroska Coleman, chief operating officer, Millard House. Good afternoon. Shirley Diggs, coordinating super supervisor. Good afternoon. Shayla Jackson, director of capital programs. Good afternoon. Will Smith, project management supervisor, Department of Capital programs. Good afternoon. Quincy Boyd, chief of staff. All right, Doctor Cole. All right, very good. Thank you so much for that. All right, so if we could bring up the presentation, that would be great. Excuse me, chair Harrison. They're having a little it problem with the presentation. They're restarting it, so it should be available shortly, I believe. Okay, well, we have our copies, so why don't we go ahead and get started. Yep. Okay, so, Miss Diggs, why don't we go ahead and start with slide one? All right. Good afternoon, everyone. I'm here to discuss some of the field use that we have in Prince George's county public high schools. And so I want to go through the slides very quickly. For the first slide, we talk about the start dates and the first play date and the championship dates. Those dates are set by the state Maryland Public School Athletic association. And so we follow that calendar. And what you see, I'm not going to just go through all of it, since you can see it. But as you can see, from August 14 to December 7 is the longest sport in the fall. Winter goes from November 15 to March 15, and spring is March 1 to May 25. Those are the times and dates that the entire fields from the county are used daily. Okay. And on the next slide are turf fields. We have eleven turf fields that we use. And as you can see, the schools that now have turf and the grass fields, we have ten fields. But at this point in time, Suitland high school is being built, rebuilt, renovated. So they are now using Forestville High School as the grass field. Okay. Going on to the next one. In the fall, sports, mainly football, boys soccer and girls soccer are the sports that we use. All the fields. And I mean all fields are used all season long for the fall. There's not a time where they're really empty, except for Sunday, because we are not allowed to do anything on Sunday. If you go to the winter sports, of course, there's not very many. We use the fields, so that's when our fields are empty. It's cold, so we don't use them. Our indoor track team will sometimes go outside, but other than that, we do not use the fields. Come spring is very busy. We have outdoor track, boys and girls lacrosse on the fields. We have softball and baseball on the other fields, which many times people want to rent those fields. So we are in full force. But what I would like to tell you about spring is that we also have middle school soccer. And so those middle school soccer teams have to. They don't really have good fields for the middle schools, and so they have to use some of

And we actually use all of these fields for the state championships, the semifinals, all of those things. So again, they're being used constantly. Now, the grass fields, it's hard to use because they just don't hold up long enough. When you put soccer on it, you put football on it. We can't use it for anything else. Middle schools they actually, what's important is spring sports, boys soccer and girls soccer. Those use all of our high school fields also. So this is just letting you know who all is using our fields constantly for the lawn maintenance. The maintenance of the field, including baseball and softball, which includes mowing and lining the fields. Classic lawn covers high point. Laurel Duval and Roosevelt Blythewood. They cover all our other fields. And the contractors are responsible to provide routine and annual maintenance to ensure a safe playing surface on all middle and high school athletic fields. Now keep in mind, when those companies come out, they are lining the field for the next game. They are cutting the field for the next game. They are monitoring it. So, you know, it's hard because if other people come onto the field and ruin those lines, then we got to call them back out to put the lines out. School practices, as you can see, it's very packed in season teams, open fields. Open field means the school can use it for the other sports just to do workouts. Conditioning seven on seven leagues for football is using the fields. So pretty much we go from Monday to Friday from after school, which is anytime from about 230 to 09:00. And those are the fields with lights. And we have practices all, all day, all night. For those Monday through Friday. After school to 630 are the schools with no lights. So your grass fields, some of our turf fields, don't have lights. Saturdays we are using the field from 08:00 a.m. to at least 03:00 p.m. sometimes we have to do some makeups, which could take the fields on Saturday evening. And the other thing is, our fields are used by three charter schools. They don't have fields, so they use our high school fields and international schools. We have two international schools that also use the high school fields. So we have to schedule them between all the other games and then all the playoffs for high school and middle school. So that just gives you a little idea of how much our fields are used. Thank you so much, Shirley. And so, moving into the memorandum of Understanding with Maryland National Capitol park and planning, this was an agreement that was brokered to begin on July of 2023 and is set to take a hold over three phases. Phase one is currently in effect and shall apply to all artificial turf fields and any future schools that also have a turf field. So currently that includes eleven of our facilities moving into the following year, meaning July of 2024 to take effect. The phase two of the MoU shall consist of additional PGCPs facilities and fields in the north, central and southern counties as negotiated by PGCPs and Maryland National Capital park and planning. And then finally, phase three shall consist of all PGCPs facilities and fields for all schools as negotiated by the two entities, and that should take effect July of 2025. The MoU speaks to how fields, and ultimately facilities will be reserved. The current reservation process always has the school system holding priority when reserving its fields and facilities. So the athletic directors are responsible for entering all practices, game times, and field use into our online reservation system. Following that, Maryland National Capitol park and planning is to schedule their events. And then Maryland National Capital park and planning at that point should open the reservation system to schedule third party users. I'm going to turn it to director Taylor to wrap us up to talk about stadium renovations. Good afternoon. So, actually, I'm sitting next to our subject matter expert on the Turffield installations. He's done all of them for the last decade. His passion is not unrelated to being a Prince George's county public school high school athlete himself. So this is Will Smith, our project management supervisor. Appreciate that, Director Jackson. Sorry, my pencil. Okay. This slide that we have really just talks about. Just our typical process for all of our turf field renovation projects, some of which that we have passed, completed, some that we have currently that are in whether multiple phases, whether in construction, permitting, etcetera. The ones that we have identified here in terms of next products and pipeline. The first one up is Laurel High school. So Laurel has been in construction roughly seven months, and we're nearing the end of that. The turf field has been installed, the track has been installed. Bleachers and press box, et cetera, all been installed and will be finalizing the rubberized track surface here this summer. And at that point will be completed there for F

And so that all is contingent upon site conditions, additional stormwater management requirements, et cetera, that are required, but typical. We'll do replacement or transition from natural grass to turf will correct some of the non compliance issues related to our track surfaces. In addition, we'll add storage facilities, press boxes, bleachers, stadium lighting, egress lighting, things of that nature, to make sure that it is a safe and inviting facility at night when we're hosting our night games. Average cost that we're seeing is roughly $7.5 million. And that's give or take. Some are lower than that because it doesn't need the full replacement. Example, Bladensburg already had existing bleachers, so we didn't have to move forward. Press box and bleachers there. And so that came in less. But a project such as Frederick Douglass, it's a total renovation, right? It needs everything. So that would be around that $7.5 million mark. Thank you, Mister House Superintendent House and Doctor Coleman, and your entire leadership team, Miss Diggs, for the presentation, we're going to go to questions. I see councilmember begay has her hand raised, and we do have a quorum just for. So sorry about my tardiness today. I just wanted to ask a question. We have received multiple concerns at Largo high school about a turf field there. It is my understanding they do not have one or looking for serious upgrades. And the principal has brought it to our attention multiple times. And I wanted to know, has there been any. And he said that this has been brought up to you all's attention, that we met, my staff met with the entire. The leadership there. And this has been a concern that I remember hearing last year. So is there anything being done about the turf fields and Largo high school? So before my team jumps in, what I will say is, as we share this insight, I'd love to ensure that we understand better the. The average costs, because turf fields are extremely costly. And it also, I think it's important for us to understand the climate action plan and how out of alignment it is with us moving forward to move turf fields in over the idea of grass fields. So with that being said, well, I'll let you go ahead and share some insight that be a feasibility student. Okay. Well, regarding Largo high school, we have a party list, and that party list was identified. I want to say 2016 ish. 2017 ish that identified just the party in which we're moving forward with the replacement renovation of all of our high school projects. This is something that I think, you know, I'm very passionate about, you know, being alum of Prince George county public schools, being an athlete as well, knowing the extent of a lot of our counterparts in other communities, that they've had turf field for quite some time. And so I don't think it's. And also with the passion our colleagues have, it's not a situation of not wanting to move forward with turf. I think ultimately the issue is, you know, we have a large need across the board, you know, and all of our facilities, not just athletics. And it's also trying to have that balance of funding needed to make sure that we're making our modernization, school replacements, etcetera, but then also having fun in for athletics improvements. And at that point, it's not so much just going in and installing turf fields. It's, you know, the comprehensive renovation to make sure that it's the, you maximize your usage for each facility. So Largo, we would go in and replace lights, and I think their bleachers are fine there. We would have to expand their track because their tracks also is not compliant. In addition to once we have resolution on the turf field, currently Largo is slated after cross. Then we'll have Duval Central High school friendly Parkdale, and Largo would then be next. And so it's quite, what's the time down in a priority order? Is there any way we can move that? I mean, what is the process of moving things up to? Because we've heard, I mean, Largo has been some of our champions, and we would like to make sure they have adequate turf build. So is there, what is a way, maybe I could talk to you offline of what we can do to bring this. It seems like it's pretty much a long way from now. You know, from an equity standpoint, I think regardless of whether a school is winning a championship or not, we want to provide students with the best possible. So we have a, you know, a system in place, as Will has talked about in terms of the timeline. Will, is there any other information that you want to share? Can we get a year? Or. I mean, what. I mean, what can we get right now? So it's hard to commit to a year because it's contingent on funding. And there's been multiple years in which we thought we were going to receive funding for the stadium category, and we didn't receive anything. And so, you know, even this year, you know, we're anticipating receiving 3.5 for Crosland, but as of right now, that has not been approved and it's not earmarked for crossing at this point. And so it's hard to commit to a year understanding that, you know, there's so many variables, whether it's dealing with the state and trying to get grants and approval for that or whether or not going through our CIP and get approval. So if we just look at, if we just factor on our CIP crossing would be somewhere around maybe FY 30, 31 ish, and that's contingent on getting approval each year. If we do not get approval for that statement category. It then pushes them out, you know, each year because that funding will be needed for whatever that priority school is within that order. Currently. Councilmember Bogey, just for the record, you know, I've been on the council six years and they've been talking. Frederick Douglass High School has gotten pushed back a bunch of times. Obviously, the need is great and the funding is short when it comes to that. And so as you can see, Frederick Douglass has pushed back again a little bit because the funding is not necessarily there. I would encourage you, if you would like, maybe Mister House having an opportunity follow up with councilmember begay about a meeting because we are getting state funding for it. Do think that we should actually get some county funding, too, but we've now reached out to Senator Charlton and he's going to get. Be glad to check. Thank you. Yeah. Thank you. Thank you. I just thought you mentioned. Okay, so the turf is actually more of an expense than the natural grass. Well, I will say it's a different expense. Right. Right. And so in the turf product usually lasts about ten years. So our warranties, I believe, are ten years for that product. So I'll defer, I believe Director Baldwin is here from our transportation department. But as you all know, and as you probably have heard, we moved forward with a significant step in the right direction in terms of transportation. We completed an extensive audit with an outside organization that allowed for us to really take a look in the mirror in terms of what we want to do and what we need to do for our 85,000 students that are a part of our ridership. Recruitment is a major part of that. But efficiencies that we're finding as a part of this audit should help with that as well. Director Baldwin, I know you. Thank you for that. I'd like to pivot to the other Baldwin, Chief Baldwin, our head of human resources. Good afternoon. I am Christy Murphy Baldwin, chief of human resources for Prince George's county public schools. Not related to our wonderful director Baldwin, no pun intended. So we are very actually proud of our recruitment and retention plan. We actually, the audit that Superintendent House had done, they pointed out that we had a very robust plan. We spend a lot of money to make sure that we post different advertisements. If you ever go through the NBA, you'll see a rolling billboard of come drive with us. We have a major brand campaign and different kiosks all throughout the county to recruit our bus drivers. One of the things that Superintendent House pointed out is the challenge, though, with our bus routes. So having the number of people versus how many routes we have to run on a given day are two very different things. And I think that is one of the challenges when it comes to staffing. And I believe Chief Coleman, as well as Superintendent House reference every single day. We start with 300 routes that cannot be covered. So although we have the bodies, we don't have the routes to cover those individuals or those specific routes to get the children to school. So we are hoping with this change in the bus time, that it will reduce the number of routes that will match then the number of individuals that we hire. Thank you. And how many bus drivers do you think we need to hire for this upcoming school year? So, every year we run between. For the number of routes, we try to have at least 200 to almost 300 drivers. Unfortunately, one of the things that we have a challenge with is our biggest competitor is Wamada. So being in the DMV presents a significant challenge, because once people earn their CDL, the doors open up for them. So that's why we really are looking forward to this change, so that we can create a better work balance for our bus drivers to get more individuals to come. I would also say that we're also market competitive, too. You will often hear that we're not paying our bus drivers equal compensation to other school districts, and that is not true. As a father of a student that runs through a couple backpacks a year, we know that those needs will not stop. So whether it's the incredible philanthropic support from our community, whether it's blueprint, whether it's the county, we know that these needs will be there on an annual basis. I do hear often that the teachers and the principals are always pulling out of their pocket because their budgets are so strapped and strangled that they're pulling out of their own resources. And those are things that individuals can't even claim on their taxes anymore of that tax deduction removed. So just make sure that there's some sensitivity in that matter when it comes to funding in certain high performing areas, you know, in low performing areas as well. I know the chair, Ivy, has a couple of questions, and I know councilmember Olson has a couple of questions. So thank you, mister chair. Thank you all for being here today. I appreciate it. We all know how important sports are to our students, and it made me look up a couple of things. This is from the state board of education. Whereas the Interscholastic Sports program is an integral part of the education program, whereas it is essential to promote healthful living, character building and good citizenship for students through competitive sports, whereas emphasis shall be placed on equality of opportunity, wholesome competition and safety of participation. So that's from the state and then our own Prince George's county public schools philosophy. It is our belief that athletics is a way to achieve a balanced educational program for our students in middle school and high school. As we all know, athletic competition, by its nature, will contribute to greater student awareness of self discipline, a growth in emotional maturity, and an increasing realization of the worth of the individual. So I think those are important statements that kind of acknowledge how important sports can be to students. And especially some students are coming from backgrounds that might be particularly challenging, and they look to sports as a way to succeed and to have a reason to come to school every day, because otherwise you might feel like, I'm not really doing great anywhere else, but at least I can go play soccer or basketball or whatever and be a part of a team, and it helps with their emotional growth. But we have a rule in Prince George's county that is different than Montgomery county, for example. The state has a certain rule about students being able to participate in sports and for how long. And all schools say you can't be past 18 years old, and it says a maximum of four seasons in any one sport, and then, which is fine, but our policy, the way it's interpreted here, is interpreted differently than our neighboring jurisdiction. So if someone has perhaps had a year in 9th grade that it didn't go well for them at a different. In a different school system or, you know, private school, I should say, or home school or whatever they were doing. And then they come to Prince George's and start again in 9th grade. That grade, that year of 9th grade seems to be counted against them here in a way that is not counted against them in Montgomery county because the state doesn't require that. That's something that we have done to our own kids. So I think that it would be wise if, given how important sports are to

So I think that it would be wise if, given how important sports are to these kids, if you have had reason that you had to repeat a grade, then chances are you have had enough of a challenge in your life that the sports are there can help you. One of my kids repeated. What grade did he repeat? I think it was 8th grade, not because his grades weren't good, but he had such a crappy year that year that we sent him to private school for a year and actually was two years because he repeated 8th grade and then 9th grade and then came back and has done extremely well in his life. And he, you know, this didn't affect him because he wasn't trying to play sports. But I know that you can have a bad year and regroup. Right. So what kind of consideration can you all give to changing that policy so students aren't being impacted by that, that they are able to continue to play if they haven't played the four years? I'm not saying change it so they can play more than four years. I'm not trying to change that. That's a state law or a state policy, but it's our own policy that it's keeping these kids from playing. And who could address that? And I'll start off and then let miss Diggs, who is one of the individuals responsible for our athletics and PGCPs, as a former high school athlete that went to school on a full college scholarship as well, I understand the importance. What was your sport? Basketball. Don't let the height fool you. Would not. I could handle mine out there. But what I will say, I completely agree. What I've got out of sports has really been equated to a lot of leadership lessons that I've gained in life. What I also have learned about the sports as a former coach at the high school level as well, is that we're in a day and age that between travel ball, club ball, AAU, EYBL, BCI, our kids, in many instances, are playing a number of games, even if they don't play. Many kids don't even play for their high school teams because they're the competition level with travel ball, AAU, EYBL is so extreme. There are a number of kids in Prince George's county that are playing in some of the best travel ball, best EYBL teams in the country right now. So, quite frankly, the number of dollars that are spent outside of the school system in these kind of private summer, or not even summer throughout the year, is incredible to see. We also know that, you know, from our general counsel to the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic association, that while it's in alignment and the Maryland Athletic association allows for school systems to have some variants. You mentioned Montgomery county. I'm not necessarily familiar with it, but from my perspective and my experience, it's important to think through the body mass, everything that goes along with a fifth year senior, because it's an opportunity for that individual to be bigger, stronger, whether they're playing travel ball, EYBL, AAU, BCR. insights.observation: The current policy prevents students who have repeated a grade from participating in sports beyond the age of 18 or for more than four seasons, regardless of the circumstances that led to the repeated year.
The policy impacts students who have faced challenges such as poor grades or personal issues, potentially depriving them of the benefits of sports which can aid in their personal development.
There is a high level of participation in extracurricular travel sports such as AAU and EYBL, which indicates a strong community emphasis on athletics.
The community spends significant amounts of money on private sports leagues, indicating a potential disparity in access based on financial resources.
There are calls for revisiting the policy to prevent penalizing students based on their age or repeated classes due to personal challenges.
The school system can align its policies to provide variances similar to other jurisdictions, helping students continue their participation in sports.

Prince George's county allows students to play as long as they have a 2.0 GPA even if they have multiple E's.

Historical mishandling: Athletic director and parents incorrectly added 14 truckloads of fill dirt, resulting in gravel contamination and poor field conditions.
Recognition needed for fund allocation ($400,000) to properly redo the Parkdale football field, considering soil preparation and other environmental measures.
Establishment of a committee to oversee and approve any changes to school fields to prevent future mishandling.
