chunks.text: Okay. Good morning, everyone. This is the planning, housing economic development committee. What's today? Today is Thursday, May 16. We have a pretty full agenda, but not as full as it was. So the presentation by the farm bureau has been put off until maybe September. Okay. And we're still waiting to hear from the building industry about them coming in front of us. Okay, so on the agenda, we've got three bills. We will move on CB two as an accommodation to the sponsor and the administration, and then we'll do the presentation from park and planning and CB 31 we'll deal with at the end, but we're just going to move that to June 3. So that's the game plan. So if we could move on to CB two. Yes. Good morning, Chairman Dunoga and members of the committee. We have a proposed draft two and an amendment sheet that is attached. CB two is the bill that amends the housing code to add email by written consent as a method of service for notices of violations, civil citations, and administrative citations. The bill also provides guidelines for implementation of the email methods of service. A copy of CB 220 24, proposed draft two can be found on pages 498 through 506 of your virtual binder. There's also an amendment sheet, as I mentioned before on page 507. I can turn to miss Kathy Cannon to go over the amendments, if that's possible, and then we'll turn to the administration. Thank you, sir. This is CB 220 24, proposed draft two. As Rena had indicated, there are six amendments. Three amendments are amendments offered by DPI and are found in proposed draft two. Three amendments are amendments proposed by chair Donoga and are found in the amendment sheet. Amendment number one is substantive and deals with method of service. It provides that if me mail consent is provided, then service by certified mail or first class mail is not required. Failure to update the department with a new email is not a basis to challenge service and failure to update an email address shall preclude them from any notice related defenses. Amendment number two as substantive and deals with license applications. It requires that license applications shall provide that the licensee is obligated to maintain an updated email address and if email consent is provided, then service by certified mail or first class mail is not required. Failure to update the department with a new email address is not a basis to challenge service and shall preclude them from any notice related defenses. Amendment number three is subjective and deals with license application renewals. It provides that the renewal license application shall provide for the placement of the optional signature of an applicant for service by email. It provides that the renewal license application shall provide that the licensee is obligated to maintain an updated email address. Further, it provides that if email consent is provided, then service by a certified mail or first class mail is not required. Failure to update the department with any new email address is not a basis to challenge service and shall preclude them from any notice related defenses. Now, turning to chair Donegas amendment sheet, chair Donoga's amendments are technical. Each of the three amendments are identical and amend the three amendments just noted, namely method of service, license application, and license renewal. The amendments say strike the term them and substitute the applicant in each instance. And it strikes the term notice related and substitute the term notice hyphen related with a hyphen in each instance. Those are a summary of the six amendments. Thank you, Miss Canning. I'll turn Miss Skinner. Thank you, mister chair. And good morning. The administration wants to thank the sponsor of this legislation and bringing it forward, councilmember Fisher. esg_v1.name: Department of Permits, Inspections, and Enforcement (DPI)

insights.observation: Three amendments proposed by DPI include changes to allow email as a method of service for notices of violations, civil citations, and administrative citations.
The amendments require license applications to provide an updated email address and if email consent is given, service by certified or first class mail is not required.
Amendments stipulate that failure to update an email address precludes one from any notice-related defenses.
The bill aims to ensure property owners get notice of violations more promptly via email, leading to more timely responses.
The bill is expected to help property owners who do not reside locally get timely notices about their properties.
The initiative supports the county's move towards digitization and is aimed at better serving the next generation of homeowners.

We appreciate the ability to conduct this meeting by way of virtual technology. To staff as to its inclination as to final action, perhaps in the form of a resolution of approval. Then that would be as to the planning board recommendations on the SMA, with some none. The council's discussion of potential action on the minor amendment to the 1989 Master Plan and sectional map amendment for the Langley Park College Park Greenbelt and Vicinity area may include, but is not limited to, whether the council shall make changes to the recommendations of the planning board in approving the endorsed sectional map amendment. And we will now go to Kiera McClung. McCune? You speak McCune? McCune. Yes. Thank you. Good afternoon, chair Ivey, members of the council, again, for the record, my name is Kier McCune. nal map amendment for the Langley Park College Park Greenbelt and Vicinity area may include, but is not limited to, whether the council shall make changes to the recommendations of the planning board in approving the endorsed sectional map amendment. I am the project facilitator for the proposed minor plan amendment and concurrent sectional map amendment for the 1989 Langley Park College Park Green Belt and vicinity master plan. Emily Lutz, who is the project manager, could not attend today. She's taking a well earned vacation. During today's work session, I'll provide an overview of the project, summarize the little bit of testimony we received that was put into the record, discuss the minor plan amendment staff report and Planning Board's action from their April 25 work session and review the project schedule and end with any questions that you have for us. As stated earlier, the proposed minor plan amendment are for the 1990, excuse me, 1989 Langley Park College Park Greenville vicinity master Plan. And from here on out in this presentation, I'll just refer to it as a 1989 master plan. The boundary for the plan is highlighted in pink on the slide. The plan boundary is in the northern part of the county covering planning areas 65, 66 and 67, and includes areas in College Park, Greenbelt and Berwyn Heights. This minor plan amendment and SMA focuses on a group of CGO zone properties encompassing about 1.4 acres on Bruin Road in College park. The primary uses for these properties include retail, a restaurant, personal services that are all located in the heart of a single family neighborhood. The proposed amendments do not fundamentally change the goals and objectives of the master plan, but instead make modifications to update commercial neighborhood development patterns and to provide for context sensitive infill development. Additionally, the 1989 master plan is based upon growth concepts from the 1989 General Plan, which refers to areas of concentrated development as centers. These 1982 general plan center classifications are no longer recognized. However, they are still areas of importance within the plan boundary as to not create confusion with plan 2035 centers. The proposed amendments have replaced all plan references from the term centers to focus areas and proposes to rezone the subject properties from the CGO zone to the CN zone. At the hearing, one speaker testified and four written statements of testimony were received to the clerk by the close of the record, which was on April 3. The record included letters from the city of Greenbelt and the Berwyn District Civic association on behalf of area residents. All testimony was either in support of the minor plan amendment and SMA or provided general comments about the plan. Staff reviewed and evaluated the proposed minor plan amendment for conformance to the requirements of section 2735.02 I of the Zoning Ordinance, which are the rules and procedures for initiating, developing and the approval of a minor plan amendment. Staff found the proposed minor amendments, as drafted in CR 120 24, meet the requirements of the zoning ordinance. On April 25, the planning board voted unanimously to adopt the minor amendments for the 1989 master plan and to endorse the recommended approval of the sectional map amendment. Both the minor plan amendment and sectional map amendment were initiated in January. We held a joint public hearing. In March, the planning board held their work session and acted to adopt the minor plan amendment and endorse the SMA in April. And then today we're having our work session that will lead potentially to an adoption in June. So I try to be brief and that concludes my presentation and happy to answer any questions that you have. Thank you very much and thanks to the staff for their quick work on this. I know it wasn't a large area, but still is work, and so I really appreciate that. I think you did mention the city of Greenbelt sent a letter, but I believe that was city of College Park, I think. But that's. Yeah, I probably disagreed with that, but yes, you're right. Okay, that's fine. That's fine. Okay. Thank you. Madam chair, would you like to make a motion? Would you like to make a motion? Yes, I would like to move for the preparation of document of approval consistent with the planning board. Second, I have a motion by council member Olson. Cool Springs Judith Heuer Modernization project increased by 63.5 million and was rescoped to include a therapy pool a family center and PGCPS offices. The new Northern Adelphi Area High School project total increased by $89 million and completion is now expected in fiscal year 2029. And then going on to the Suitland annex, replacement completion is delayed until fiscal year 2029. The total project cost added $73 million in fiscal year 2024 and 99 million is expected for fiscal year 2025 for a total project cost of $390 million. And finally, in this section, the William Schmidt Educational center cost increased by $17 million due to additional scope. This section here provides the legislative and fiscal background to the Build to Learn act, which enable the county's public private partnership. A list of the schools in phase one and phase two are provided in the list. This next section provides information on ongoing PGCPS projects. As we know, very difficult year, not only in the state of Maryland, but in our county as well. And we are prepared with a budget to answer any questions that you all may have. I do have my chief financial officer, Lisa Howell, as well as members from my capital improvement team here to answer any clarifying questions at this time. Okay, so, do you have a question, Miss Warrior? Okay. Miss Fisher. Oh, I'm sorry. I'm so sorry. Madam chair. Hi, it's good to see you, Mister House. How are you? I wanted to ask you a little bit if you could maybe expand, and I don't know if this is the right form for this budget question, but I'll just put it out there on busing of our children. I'm sorry, councilmember Fisher, if you can move the mic a little closer, some people are struggling a little bit to hear you. Thank you, ma'am. Is that better? Okay. I wanted to ask you something that I think all of us here at the council care deeply about and discuss in various different bills is obviously the welfare of our children, which we spend the most money on. So we want to see good results. Right. I think the busing of our children has been a huge issue, I know, in the recruitment of bus drivers. And then something that we all discuss and sort of try to think about is how do we move children from school to then different activities, right. To fill their days and to help supplement them after the school day ends. And so I wanted to talk to you. I wanted you to expand a little bit about what does busing for the 2025 budget for PG CPS look like? What are you doing on the recruitment and retention of your drivers? What is our school system able to do to expand the movement of children to the opportunities for their potential across our county? That would be greatly deserved. Absolutely. And of course, upon my arrival, one of the things that I took a close look at is was just kind of the history of transportation in the county with pgcps, and soon learned that there had been quite a bit of heartburn over the course of time in terms of how we transport our children and really the dependability of buses and several other things that go along with our transportation of our students as well. Decided to move forward with a comprehensive audit through a nationally renowned organization called formative. And so my transportation and operations team has been working very closely with formative to move forward with a significant number of recommendations. One of the biggest recommendations that probably many of you have heard about is the change of bell times. And to make this as simple as possible, in pgcps we had over 1314 different bell times. That's actually start times of our schools. We have moved forward. We actually made an announcement on the 25th that we're moving to three different tiers and that should offer us a significant level of service improvement in reference to what we're looking for. There are a number of other improvements and we'd be glad recommendations that we'll be moving forward with and I'd be glad to send those to the council, if you don't mind, Doctor Coleman, if you want to share a little bit more at the microphone around what we're doing here. But we're very excited about what this will mean for pgcps and families and students moving forward. Sure. Thank you so much for that question. And again, as Superintendent House said, he has prioritized improving the transportation system across our district and we have taken that charge very seriously. And again, as Superintendent House said, he has prioritized improving the transportation system across our district and we have taken that charge very seriously. With the rollout of a multi year, multi phase plan, we are preparing to implement phase one. The first lead, foundational step in that plan is to adjust bell times, as was discussed. And then it will follow with the inclusion of four additional steps. Consolidating bus stops to make our bus trips more efficient. Auditing our walk zone, meaning the non transportation zone nearest our schools, actually services 26,000 or a third of our ridership. And so there's a need to assess whether or not students in that non transportation zone still require a bus. We're going to be moving forward with an opt out option for our families that have a bus, meaning they meet the criteria for a bus for their children, but they no longer need it. They either take their child to school or have some other way in which they get them to school. So we just want them to let us know that they no longer need that bus and therefore we can make our trips more efficient. And we're also focusing in on customer service, because we've heard from our families that they want to have a real clear line of communication around the location of the bus and be able to reach out to us in the need that arises. So with all of that being said, we have our eye on improving efficiency of our transportation system. System while also maintaining a priority on safety. Mom chair, am I allowed to follow up? Yes, you may. Okay. So within that. Am I interrupting? Within that plan. So what is your, what are you proposing in your, in your. In a budget priority in the recruitment and retention of your drivers? So I don't want to speak for human resources because I'm the chief operating officer, but I will tell you that we work closely with our HR partners with a consistent recruitment strategy and retention strategy for our drivers. We do pay to have drivers trained. If they don't come to us with a CDL, we will certainly train them to be a driver with us. And there are a number of incentives that we provide to our respective candidates. But what I will also say, councilmember Fisher, is that because of the efficiency in this first round of recommendations that we're moving forward with, there actually should be a need for less drivers. Right now, with so many different start times, our need was, of course, greater. But because we are consolidating not only stops consolidating bell times significantly, we should be in a position where we will need less drivers. Now, we'll still need drivers and we'll still need to recruit because the driver shortage is real and it's been consistent nationwide. And we have one of the largest fleets, I think the 8th largest ridership in the nation with 85,000 students. So our need will always be there. But this is about consolidation of efforts and ensuring that we do what makes sense. The question is around the infrastructure, as you talked about. And so we are open to having collaboration with our county partners to find more financially sound ways in which to charge those vehicles in a way that we can share that burden. chunks.text: ant to ask an operating budget question. I know that the Kirwan funding is supposed to go to a number of areas that are to help our young people. So two questions. First question is, are you seeing a real benefit yet from the significant increase in funding from Kirwan, from the current new funding formula? If so, how are those increases helping? How are you seeing those increases materialize in terms of achievement so far? That's the first question. Thank you for that question, and I can address the first part in terms of the funding. My name is Lisa Howell. I'm the chief financial officer for fiscal year 25 budget. The funding that we're getting relating to blueprint is actually, it is increasing over the previous year, but is a smaller increase relative to the years we've had before into the years that we're expecting. Some subsequent part of the funding formulas are driven by student enrollment or student count for certain student groups, and is also driven by a per pupil amount. And the per pupil amount for 2025 is a smaller increase than we've had in the previous years and the years to come. So there is a year over year increase, but it is a smaller increase that we've received. And the same thing relating to the student count that drives a lot of the funding to the school, school system. The formula such that that student count actually dipped in fiscal year 2025 across the state for all leas in the formula. So it was an unintended consequence of the way in which the formula was written, and so it was really less than a 1% increase across the board relating to student funding. So we have continued to leverage our student based budgeting model that we've had in place for years, which is actually very similar to the blueprint legislation, which is where the funding follows the student. And so we've continued to use that as our framework to help allocate the funding to the schools. And so as the enrollment increases, the amount of funds for those schools are following the student accordingly. And so we're going to continue with the blueprint implementation, not only for 25, but it's going to be a long process as this continues to evolve to ensure the funds are getting to where they need to go based on the attributes of the students, and then I'm sure there'll be academic outcomes that follows that as well. Formula also went down, or is it going to be smaller increase than expected. What was the reason for that? Specifically, our foundation formula, which is the funding that we get for every single student, is driven by student student count. insights.observation: The planning board recommended implementing the 2022 Bowie, Mitchellville and Vicinity master plan as it was approved and opposed all 16 amendments.

For amendment 1, the proposed amendment is to retain the RR CGO split zoning for the two properties that make up Free State Shopping Center. The planning board opposes this amendment and recommends rezoning the entire property to the CGO zone.

Amendment 2, Keller property: The amendment is to rezone the Keller property to the CGO zone instead of retaining the RR zone. The planning board's position is to oppose the amendment and retain the existing RR zone.

Amendment 3, former Wellands property: The proposed amendment is to retain the Wellands property in the RR zone instead of rezoning to the CS zone. The planning board opposes the amendment and recommends rezoning the property to the CS zone.
Amendment 4, Boys and Girls Club property: The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the AG zone instead of retaining the RS zone. The planning board's position is to retain the RS zone.

Amendment 5, one of the Supreme Landscaping LLC properties: The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the CS zone instead of retaining the AR zone. The planning board opposes the amendment and recommends retaining the AR zone.

Amendment 6, South Jesuit property (sacred Heart property): The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the AG zone instead of retaining the AR zone. The planning board recommends retaining the AR zone.
Amendment 7, Collington Place LLC property: The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the RMF 20 zone. The planning board's position is to retain the existing CGO zone.

Amendment 8, Northern Jesuit property: The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the AG zone instead of rezoning to the AR zone. The planning board's position is to rezone it to the AR zone.
Amendment 9, TMZ 450 LLC property: The proposed amendment is to retain the property in the AR zone instead of rezoning to the CS zone. The planning board's position is to rezone it to the CS zone.
Amendment 10, former Franks nursery property: The proposed amendment is to retain the RR zone, but the planning board's position is to rezone it to the CGO zone.
Amendment 11, MNCPC property: The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the RS zone instead of the AG zone. The planning board's position is to rezone it to the AG zone.
Amendment 12, Lawley and Parker Williams property: The proposed amendment is to retain the property in the AR zone, but the planning board’s position is to rezone it to the AG zone.
Amendment 13, Freeway Airport: The proposed amendment is to retain the property in the AR zone. The planning board's position is to rezone the property to the RSF zone.
Amendment 14, Prince George's County-owned property: The proposed amendment is to rezone the property to the RS zone. The planning board's position is to rezone it to the AG zone.
Amendment 15, other Supreme Landscaping LLC property: The amendment is to retain the property in the AR zone. The planning board's position is to rezone it to the AG zone.

Amendment 16, Bowie State University Mark Campus Center property: The proposed amendment is to rezone the entire property to the RS zone, but the planning board’s position is to retain the existing zoning, which is a portion of the property in the NAC zone and a portion in the RS zone.

chunks.text: r the record, my name is Claire Wershtell and I am the CIP budget manager for the Department of Parks and Recreation. Today we'll walk through the goals and objectives of the Capital Improvement program, or CIP. We will then review changes to the proposed CIP submitted to you in January 2024 and compare the changes to the amended proposed CIP. That's before you today. Finally, we will walk you through the elements of your CIP binder and open the floor to any questions or items you would like to discuss further. We strive to address the following four priorities in the FY 25 CIP be good stewards of our existing assets fully fund the implementation of current projects, grow and change our inventory to meet the needs of current and future residents, and equitably distribute those resources and facilities. Our primary focus is on existing assets, specifically playgrounds, athletic fields and trails, which are facilities that residents have the greatest access to in terms of proximity to their homes and daily use. We are implementing a new asset management approach to guide the investment prioritization in these facilities. We're still feeling the effects of historic inflation. In order to complete many of our previously funded projects, we need to supplement funding to account for current material cost increases so we can finish these projects in a timely manner. Our proposed CIP is guided by policies and recommendations in the adopted 2020 2040 Functional Master plan and the Land preservation, Parks and recreation plan. These overarching planning documents have spurred specific site and facility plans and feasibility studies that we then turn into new capital projects and finally providing additional resources to the areas of the county most in need of high quality parks and recreation. Here's a brief snapshot of some projects completed over the course of the year. There are currently 206 projects projects in the CIP, many of which include multiple projects. We will always have more work to do with such a large system and so many facilities, but we should take a moment to be proud of all that we've accomplished this year, including the construction of 15 playgrounds, a turf field, replacement field upgrades, trail replacements, a new indoor track at the sports and learning complex, two dog parks, and much more. The proposed CIP is the commission's six year financial plan for acquisition, development and improvement of capital assets. The CIP is composed of two components, the capital budget and the capital plan. The capital budget refers to expenditures planned for the first year of the CIP and provides the appropriation authority to spend those funds. The capital plan is the proposed projects and related expenditures for the remaining five years. The actual funding for those projects will not be allocated until the budget year. The CIP fund is funded in six ways. Tax revenue also called Paygo funding commission backed general obligation bonds, state funded program, open space for acquisition and development, financial contributions for developers as a condition of development approval, and other state and local and federal grants. We also fund projects by closing out prior approved completed capital projects and moving unspent funds where they exist to new projects. The graphic on the right illustrates how the CIP is created, from master planning efforts to stakeholder request to right sizing in the face of fiscal and manpower constraints. This is a herculean task. However, we wanted to address capital needs in a way to inspire, to be innovative, and to incentivize and excite our residents. We are proposing a CIP that meets the spending affordability guidelines as approved by the county spending Affordability Committee. As we show each year, this slide compares the proposed CIP presented to you in January to the the amended CIP presented to you today. As previously mentioned, the first year of the CIP is proposed funding. The outer years are for planning purposes and subject to change based on available funding and policy direction. In the amended CIP, you will note a $5.6 million increase in general obligation bond funding, a $3.25 million increase in state bond funding, a $1.2 million decrease in state funded program open space funding and a $3.5 million increase in developer funding. This has increased our amended budget to $142 million. We expect to spend $382 million over the next six years to improve our facilities and program offerings, which in turn will improve the lives of Prince Georgians. We think that the projects in the CIP are a great way to spend that funding, as we do each year. We've had the pleasure to meet with many council members individually to explain our CIP budgeting process and deep dive into district specific projects and initiatives. We've listened as much as we can within the current cycle and we've made adjustments. The changes you see on the screen reflect all of the substantive additions we've made since our initial presentation, mostly state legislative bonds and capital grants and developer funding. It's important to include large scale developer built parks in the CIP in order to realize the capital investment in our system. $2.1 million was added for the Central Avenue connect so that we could move forward with design of phase one while maintaining our match requirements for the raise grant. We also added 7.25 million for work at Wilmers park over the next two years. Madam chair, if I may too, just an additional shout out about Wimbles park specifically. As you can see, it's a substantial commitment of money and in large part that's that reflects the commitment from the county executive, from this council, especially the council leadership, and if I may single out vice chair Harrison for this as well, but also for our team. We are all in and fully committed to Wilmers park and moving that along. So I didn't want to preempt Miss Worshall's presentation,

Mister Irving, good morning, chair Donega, members of the PHED committee and other council members in its in attendance thank you for the opportunity to present this overview of the fiscal year 2025 budget requested by the Prince George's County Department of Parks and Recreation. The Department of Parks and Recreation is responsible for acquiring land, developing and managing park and recreation facilities, maintaining and policing park property, and providing various leisure activities and services. The department carries out this work through three primary funds, park fund, recreation fund and enterprise fund, as well as smaller special revenue funds. Revenues to the two larger funds are primarily derived from property tax collections, representing 98% of the park fund revenue and 89% of the recreation fund revenue. The commission projects tax revenues in FY 25 to reach $307 million for these two funds, up $18 million from the current year. This projection assumes no change in real or personal property tax rates and is based on estimates from the estimates of the county's accessible base by the Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation, published this past November. Revised estimates of the accessible base were released last week, and the commission will update its revenue projections if needed. Prior to budget adoption, enterprise fund revenue is split evenly between program generated funds such as fees, concessions, sales and rentals, and a transfer from the recreation fund. Across the three funds, non tax revenue has rebounded significantly from pandemic related lows by the end of fiscal year 23, the last fully completed fiscal year, charges for services reached $10 million after falling to $4 million. In fiscal year 21, rentals and concessions reached $6 million after falling to $1.8 million, and sales rebounded to $1.7 million after dropping to $980,000. Consequently, the FY 25 budget projects a continued upward trend in non tax revenue. Total revenue for the Parker recreation funds are projected at $324.7 million and $15.9 million for for the enterprise fund, the FY 25 budget proposes spending $353 million, excluding reserves in the park and recreation funds, an increase of 13%, or $42 million above the current fiscal year. The budget also proposes $16.6 million of spending in the enterprise fund. While we'll discuss the funds in greater detail, a summary of the proposed revenue and expenditures can be found on page six of your virtual binder. As you can see from that table, expected revenues in the park and recreation funds are not alone sufficient to support the proposed spending, necessitating the use of fund balance, $16.5 million in the park fund and $12 million in the recreation fund. We'll return to this use of fund balance a little bit more when discussing the recreation fund in details. Turning to staffing, the proposed FY 25 budget requests 1331 full and part time positions 71 more positions than the current fiscal year. This represents the single largest annual increase of positions in ten years. Notable additions include 13 child care positions, including three facility directors, two additional project managers within the capital planning and development division, five new park police officers and five park staff staffers for playgrounds, trails and field support. Pages six and seven of your binder have more details on the requested positions. The commission is currently in negotiations with its two collective bargaining units, and the budget includes $6.9 million for anticipated compensation adjustments. The department reported that recruiting, hiring and retaining staff are critical issues that we'll continue to face in the coming years. Through the first half of the fiscal year, December 31, the department reported 215 vacancies. A list of the vacant positions is included on page 65 of your virtual binder. More than half of these vacancies were unfilled for longer than six months, and 21% of those positions were unfilled for more than one year. Page seven of your virtual binder highlights the divisions with the highest number of overall vacancies as well as the longer term vacancies. The department has made strategic use of those unused personnel funds to address other priorities. For example, in FY 23, the department repurposed $8 million to replace outdated vehicles and heavy equipment to better meet the needs of its current work programs. Ultimately, the funds that are not repurposed are placing the fund balance to be carried forward to the subsequent fiscal year. Through December 31, the department reported filling 104 vacant positions. More than two thirds of those were longer term vacancies. Progress in filling those long term vacancies was highest in facility services as well as the northern and southern region parks and recreations. A listing of the field positions can be found on page 73 of your virtual binder. The department may provide updated hiring figures during its presentation. Turning to project charges project charges are budgeted at $4.9 million, a $4.4 million decrease from the current year, which you may recall included one time funding for twelve projects. A history of the budget versus actual project charges can be found on page eight of your virtual binder. For the Largo headquarters building. Committed to building community relationships, the department increased its volunteerism programs and social media engagement. The department continues to work alongside our community members, recording nearly 14,000 volunteer hours. This time invested equates to $473,000. Additionally, the department provided over 155 teen volunteer opportunities which engaged over 1400 teens. The departments social media outreach has increased its followers by 36% with over 260,000 impressions this past fiscal year. This indicates how engaged the community is with the departments brand. Specifically, the departments Instagram page has increased its views by 177%. This is largely due to the increased use of video reels. This demonstrates the interest of followers and videos of our programs and services. Next slide we have seen an increase in visits and program enrollment over the past year. Our recreation centers remain a hub for the community with over 1 million visits in fiscal year 2024. The youth and county wide sports division continues to be busy increasing and diversifying program offerings and a new ARP position focused on teams directly correlates to the increase in team participation. We continue to expand our natural surface trail offerings and now are at over 51 miles of trails and the new wayfinding system helps to improve the users experience on the trails. Our park operations teams are increasing the inspections, renovations and upkeep of our playgrounds and in FY 24, using the inspection data, we renovated over more than 60 playgrounds. Next slide we are very proud of our park police team and they continue to set a high bar for our community policing efforts with attendance at 162 community events. While one crime is a crime too many, we continue to have historically low crime in our parks. We would like to remind you that these are fiscal year 2024 highlights and over the next two months we will continue making progress. The increase in operations is due largely to our focus areas which are natural and paved surfaces, our partnership with Prince George County Public Schools, inclusion services through our therapeutic recreation programs, arts and culture, environmental stewardship, meeting ADA standards and overall compliance. The 17.6% increase reflects a one time budget expenditure of 6.1 million. These items, which are critical, needs upgrades in firearms and communications equipment for our park police, county wide ev charging stations and information technology infrastructure upgrades, as well as significant vehicle repairs and replacements. This does not include those vehicles well past their useful life due to day to day wear and tear. This slide provides an overview of the proposed budgets for the enterprise and special revenue funds. Our ongoing goal for the enterprise fund is to gradually reduce the need to subsidize this fund. We increased revenue goes to pre Covid levels and provided increased offerings. One area that continues to be popular is golf and our expectation is that these operations will continue to thrive. Given this, we have projected an increase in the overall revenue goals based on increased offerings. As with the enterprise fund, the revenue goals for the special revenue fund were also increased to pre Covid levels and expenditures increased proportionately to accommodate the increased programming. insights.observation: In addition to our primary focus on trails, athletic fields, culture and arts, environmental stewardship and compliance, we have added branding and customer care to our FY 25 budget focus.

We have over 1200 career employees, approximately 5000 contract employees, part time team members. We look forward to presenting our CIP budget on April 30 and are prepared to answer any questions you may have regarding our FY 25 proposed operating budget.

We have been challenged over the last three years with filling some positions because of the competition that is out there. As a result of COVID we are now beginning to increase our rate of filling vacancies.

Prior to just as I got here, it was taking us about 150 days to get someone from the recruitment process into the department. We've reduced it now in some cases to 60 days, but the average is right around 75 to 80 days.

We had a meeting with Chair Shapiro and employ Prince George's to talk about that very thing, to really reach out to the communities that may not be on the radar, as we would say, to get into some of the positions that we have available.

We have a pesticide free program that we started two years ago. We have 132 parks where we do not use pesticides, but we also have cleanups with community members where we go around to different parks, trails, playgrounds, to reduce some of those invasives as you speak about.

chunks.text: mplementation package presentation. I think we got Mister felt and Miss Schollers. I'll turn to Miss Hightower for an overview. Chair, there's not much of an overview. We have Miss Katina Schulers, the division chief for the countywide planning, and Mister Tony Felts, the division chief for the community planning. And they're going to go over. We'll give a briefing on incentivizing development areas and plan 2035 centers and inside the beltway, and I'll turn it over to them. Thank you. Well, good morning. It looks like it's still two minutes in morning, so I'll say good morning. So good morning. Chair Dunoga and members of the planning, Housing and economic development committee. Again, my name is Tony Felts, and I am the chief of community planning with the Prince George's county planning Department. As mentioned, I'm joined today by Katina Shoelers, chief of county wide planning, Adam Dodgson, the supervisor of the community Planning Division's place making section, our director, Lakeisha hall, and our deputy director, Derek Berlaj. You'll remember that we appeared before this committee on January 18 of this year to provide a broad overview of a package of implementation strategies that the planning department will be working on in the coming year to further the goals of Plan 2035. At that briefing, we let you know that we would come back to this committee to go into more detail for strategies related to growth inside the centers in the Capitol Beltway and outside centers in the Capitol Beltway. The briefing today is related to strategies related to growth inside the centers and inside the beltway. And in this presentation, you will hear a lot about how to make the kind of transit oriented and infill development envisioned in plan 2035 easier and more desirable to build. So, kind of think the right development in the right places. And remember that we'll be back next month at this committee to discuss additional goals, guardrails and safeguards that can be put into place to help manage growth outside the Beltway and outside centers. So let's start off, like I always like to do, with a reminder of about plan 2035. You'll remember that the key takeaway from your plan 2035, which was adopted by the county council in 2014 and which, as you know, sets the county's vision and growth policy, is that the county council and adopting plan 2035 approved a fundamental shift in the county's development pattern away from auto dependent suburban sprawl and toward pedestrian and transit friendly mixed use centers. And what can we do to keep moving in the right direction? We're focusing on four areas, right sized zoning, incentives for in center development, managing growth outside the centers, and providing housing for all. And as you know, zoning is the source from where approvals for new development come. Without proper zoning and regulations in place, the county cannot effectively manage growth. And as you know, zoning itself stems from plan 2035 and the master and sector plans that complement the plan. That's why the planning department is going to propose funding to fully evaluate the county's 38 master and sector plans to see what is working, what isn't working, what is and is not appropriate and complimentary to plan 2035. Because, as you know, many of these plans predate plan 2030 five's adoption. We anticipate that this review will lead to opportunities to initiate plan amendments and possible zoning changes to right size zoning in the county and ensure that proper zoning designations are in place on a plan by plan level. In addition, the planning department is continuing to develop new plans which include sectional map amendments which are comprehensive rezonings associated with adoption plans to ensure that the right zoning is in place. But it's worth mentioning that it's not enough just to have the right zones in place. It's also important that the regulations tied to those zones match the goals of Plan 2035. The next few slides are going to focus on proposed by riot density increases in the centers these centers have special zoning districts referred to as transit oriented activity center base zones. The planning department is proposing as part of the omnibus bill to increase by right densities in these very specialized districts in order to bring the densities in these districts more in line with plan 2030. Five's vision of transit oriented development but numbers on a slide don't really tell the story. The next few slides are going to give some conceptual examples of what these densities could mean for buildings on the ground. So at 80 to 95 units per acre, one would expect to see about a five story building with some ground level retail. These types of buildings are typically wood framed and wrapped around a central garage structure. This would be some of the lowest maximum densities in the transit oriented and activity centers under the proposed omnibus bill at 90 to 100 2010 dwelling units per acre, you would expect to see four or five stories of residential on top of a podium garage. And what a podium garage just really means is a ground level garage that typically covers a full floor and is sometimes wrapped with retail or restaurant spaces below the residential units. So it covers the entirety of that first floor. The difference from the previous example is that the podium garage allows additional residential units on parts of the parcel that would be taken up by a central garage. These types of buildings are still wood frame. Again, they would incorporate commercial space on the first floors. At 125 to 150 units per acre, you start to get more into mid rise buildings with seven or eight stories typical. These buildings are typically metal framed or concrete and incorporate a multi level parking garage directly beneath the housing units and incorporate commercial spaces at ground level. This level of density is efficient for smaller sites in transit areas, and at 150 units per acr

Curry administration building, the hospital, the metro station and Lake Largo are three other locations where creating great public spaces will attract people to the area. Other investments in downtown Largo that can increase its marketability for new investment but also improved circulation and amenities for workers, visitors and residents are a series of trail connections, most importantly, the Central Avenue Connector trail that will connect downtown Largo with with C. Pleasant, Capitol Heights and the district. Finally, multimodal improvements to the medical Center Drive Capitol Beltway interchange are critical to connecting communities west of the Capitol Beltway and downtown Largo. And next, we move on to New Carrollton, where two major infrastructure investments are underway that will fully unlock this downtown's potential. A new intermodal station that will serve as a gateway to Prince George's county and seamlessly connect riders on Amtrak, Mark, Metro and the Purple Line, as well as inner city and local buses with connections throughout the region and destinations within this growing neighborhood. Retrofitting 85th Avenue and Ellen Road or Maryland 433 to better support pedestrian and bicycle activity are key to connecting new Carrollton with Annapolis Road, which is Maryland 450, and the broader city of New Carrollton. Increasing new Carrollton's attractiveness as a live work play destination starts with improved public gathering spaces, and two locations where placemaking can be prioritized are at each end of Harkins Road at Annapolis Road and Ellen Road by the IR's headquarters for New Carrollton and other planned 2035 centers along the Metrorail Orange line. To maximize their potential, an upcoming restoration of the lower Beaver Dam Creek near New Carrollton metro must be paired with additional green infrastructure solutions, solutions to turn stormwater management features into publicly accessible open space and a comprehensive stormwater management study of the entire lower Beaver Dam Creek watershed. Wilmota has been a key partner in developing the station area throughout its joint development program, and it should continue to partner with other public agencies who own land at New Carrollton to maximize development opportunities. Walking distance to the station at Suitland it is a living example of the power of public investment and unlocking private investments in places where the private real estate market has ignored for decades. Continued investment in the town square at Suitland Federal center creates an in high demand urban neighborhood, walking distance to the metro and thousands of jobs at Suitland Federal Center. A critical next step is retrofitting Maryland 458, which is Silver Hill Road, to better support transit, bicycling and walking along Maryland 218, Suitless Road and Swan Road. A long discussed investment that will build upon the momentum of Town Square is the creation of a formal civic open space at the intersection of Silver Hill Road and Suitland Road. Place making Suitland showed us that the possibilities and demand for civic spaces in improving this place not only gives residents of Suitland a place they can proudly gather and call their own, but tells those who would reinvest in this area that Prince George's county is serious about improving investing in great public spaces. The next downtown is Hyattsville crossing. You'll begin to notice some themes in these recommendations because they are foundational investments critical to creating a baseline environment that supports private investment and reinvestment in these communities. As with other downtowns, retrofitting the main streets to complete and green streets has to be a priority. Bellcrest Road and east West highway continue to serve as barriers to create the type of walkable, mixed use, attractive neighborhood that plan 2035 envisions and need to be transformed into human scale main streets. Stormwater management is also key to unlocking the potential of Hyattsville crossing. The ongoing nine pond project was a key recommendation of the 2016 Prince George's Plaza Transit District development plan, and its completion in the coming months will address current and future storm runoff emanating from areas of Hyattsville crossing that were constructed prior to modern storm water management practices and alleviate flooding downstream on the east side of the transit district. A key next step is doing the same type of studies, evaluation and potentially a similar facility on the west side of the transit district to alleviate stormwater volumes in the northwest branch of the Anacostia river, which could in turn decrease flooding risks surrounding the West Hyattsville station downriver.

Good morning. My name is Katina Schoelers, division chief of the countywide planning division, and I'll be discussing transportation adequacy and fees associated with school and public safety. Historically, Prince George's county has been heavily dependent on mobility by vehicular transportation. Transportation. The goal of Plan 2035 is to grow primarily in our transit oriented centers, to significantly reduce dependent on driving by creating more opportunities for walking, biking and transit in high density areas. This is what attracts businesses and turns urban centers into urban meccas. Younger generations prefer to live or work in areas with strong biking, biking, walking and transit infrastructure in place as well as access to shopping, places to work, restaurants, entertainment, public spaces, health services and a variety of other uses. Like many suburbanizing areas in the 1970s, Prince George's county instituted inadequate public facilities or as we call it, APF ordinance. The idea behind APF ordinances is that development should not occur unless adequate infrastructure is in place to serve new and existing development. There are a few things you should consider when thinking about adequate public facilities. There is no scientific way to determine adequacy. It is a policy determination made by you, the county council. An APF ordinance is effective only to the extent that it a regulates whether development occurs or not and b is coordinated with jurisdictions. Capital improvement program most existing APF ordinances, including ours, include a test for traffic adequacy that is only achievable in greenfield areas where land and money for road improvements are available. In Prince George's county, what constitutes adequate public facilities is established by the council and the subdivision regulations. When it comes to new development, public facilities adequacy is evaluated at the time of subdivision and the intent of transportation AP test is to make sure that transportation facilities are or will be in place at the time of development to offset the impacts of added traffic from development. It is also to ensure that vehicular traffic will be operating at the establish levels of adequacy in a given area of the county. However, in the centers, how fast vehicles can get through a block is less of a priority. Adding lanes in these centers encourages more vehicular traffic, especially for pass through traffic and travel at high speeds. Allowing a higher level of service or more free flowing traffic through centers will further discourage bike and pedestrian use by creating an unsafe environment. Prince George's county already leads the state and the region in pedestrian fatalities through the subdivision process. The level of service, or los as we refer to, is the common standard used for ensuring that needed infrastructure will be in place and operating to accommodate the new development. Each level is associated with a level of congestion that previous county councils found to be tolerable in a specific area of the county. Next slide please. In the prior subdivision ordinance, three levels of service were established. Each one applied to a transportation service area, or TSA, which is a designated analysis area of the county for traffic conditions, and there are three transportation service areas in the county as shown on this slide. TSA three is a rural and agricultural policy area of the county and has the highest of the county's established level of service in this area. The traffic standard is to have a stable traffic flow at peak periods of the day transportation service area two is primarily between between the US 301 and the beltway, where more congestion is expected but tolerable at peak periods and transportation service area one is generally the area inside the beltway and has the lowest level of service, and congestion is expected to be very high during peak periods. The current subdivision ordinance establishes five levels of service or five levels of acceptable traffic conditions that apply to different areas of the county. The implementation of the current subdivision regulations allowed for all ToD centers to have the lowest level of service regardless of their location. This does not include the local town centers. In addition, zones RTO, LTO and plan development zones were allowed to have an even lower level of service, meaning that these areas allow to have a much higher level of congestion than the rest of transportation service area one. For these zones, consideration is given to the focus of more and safer movement by walking, biking and transit. Movement by vehicle is less of a priority. In summary, the current subdivision regulations has moved us toward lowering the county's acceptable level of service and centers and this map right here. I'm sorry, yes, sorry. Next slide this map here shows the location of those LTO, RTO and plan development zones that I mentioned which have the lowest level of service standard. A majority of them are within TSA one already and I can provide you with an electronic copy if you want to to take a closer look at that map. Next slide please. When development is proposed, staff analyzes the development to determine how density will impact traffic and if the roads will operate at the intended level of service. insights.observation: The goal of Plan 2035 is to grow primarily in our transit oriented centers, to significantly reduce dependency on driving by creating more opportunities for walking, biking and transit in high density areas.

Younger generations prefer to live or work in areas with strong biking, walking and transit infrastructure in place as well as access to shopping, places to work, restaurants, entertainment, public spaces, health services and a variety of other uses.

Adding lanes in these centers encourages more vehicular traffic, especially for pass through traffic and travel at high speeds. Allowing a higher level of service or more free-flowing traffic through centers will further discourage bike and pedestrian use by creating an unsafe environment.
Prince George's county already leads the state and the region in pedestrian fatalities.
For these zones, consideration is given to the focus of more and safer movement by walking, biking and transit. Movement by vehicle is less of a priority.

chunks.text: I'll just use the blue line corridor as an example. You know, as part of that plan effort, we commissioned a market study to really look at the market for things like a grocery store and for other high end retail. And so we did that both for Blue Line and we did that for port towns. And both times the market study came back and said, which was a little hard for me to believe, but there was not enough residents within that area to support that to support that type of commercial growth. And so by capitalizing on the possibilities for increased and enhanced density directly around our metro stations, it grows the population. It can bring in folks who are making a little bit high over dollar, especially along the blue line and along our other lines, you know, where folks may be commuting out to the district or maybe commuting to Virginia for jobs, but choosing to live in Prince George's county. And so with those residents comes more money, more disposable income. And that's attractive to businesses, which would essentially use those spaces, those mixed use spaces on the bottom of the building and attract new commercial development. And then outside of that, of course, you would see ancillary development. And just in your district, I know time and time again, what we've heard from the blue line corridor folks is that we need a grocery store. It's a food desert. We understand that. And so we believe that items like this, that will increase density, getting more heads in beds, as they say, could help us accomplish those goals. So it's all tied together, at least. And one of the things that we saw in some of the new developments that did have, like, retail at the bottom were saying, like, that space stay vacant for long periods of time. And then sometimes there was one project that came to me where it had it written in that it could also switch those bottom units if they didn't get retail space, and it would become a full apartment building. So are there recommendations on how we safeguard from that from happening and making sure that even if it takes time, that we keep those bottom levels specifically for retail? Well, I think that's what we're doing in the planning department. We're really insisting that those commercial spaces be put in. I was in new Carrollton just the other day on a ULI event, and very similar situation in one of the new multifamily units, unit buildings that's over there, there is a space that's specifically set aside, and if you walk into it, you think, my goodness, this looks like something that a Starbucks or a coffee shop would be in. But right now, they're just using it as kind of a residence base with a little snack bar there that's kind of pay your own way. And when I was talking to that developer who had built that project, I said, what's your plan for this? And he said, well, when the market's not there yet, but when the market gets there, we would like to get this space to be a commercial space, like a coffee shop or a small restaurant or something. So I think what we understand is that the market is getting there. It's just not there yet. And I think our developers who build these projects are seeing that potential. So it's really just advocacy on our part, insisting on those mixed use components when we get into these developments and making sure that they're there and ready for when we get enough heads. And is there a way when we're, like, approving a project where it can be set in stone that it has to be used that way? Like it can't revert back to residential? Because that was one of the concerns I had. They said that it's set for commercial, but if they don't get a tenant, it will become, you know, first level tenant space. I don't think that there's any requirement of a code right now, and that's something that we could certainly take a look at in the future as part of this effort, because it is very important that we have those commercial spaces. Right. Because I guess that's just, like, the one concern I have. That to your point, if the market doesn't bear it currently, and we approve a lot, especially around the blue line corridor, and they see, well, you know, we can create x more units that they'll yield towards that, and we'll lose the opportunity for those commercial spaces when the market does bear it. Absolutely. And that's something that we can take a look at. And happy to work with your office and take a look at it. Perfect. Thank you. You know how to get me. Yeah. I got two questions. But, Ms. Riada, heads in beds has been the excuse forever. Even though we have almost a million heads. We don't. We don't have the right heads. I mean, when you read between the lines, that's really what's going on. So the development community keeps demanding more and more density everywhere in the county, but no matter what density you bring, they can't bring quality retail. I mean, this has traditionally been a problem. I mean, literally, 2003, four, five. Heard the same thing. I know. Like at Westphalia. That's what news gays hearing, even though there's so many people in the general area. So I'm not sure what to say. Well, you're right. You're repeating what they say, and they said, the market's not ready. We need more beds. It's not just heads and beds. You're absolutely right. You also have to have quality public spaces where people want to visit. You also have to ensure that people feel a level of safety when they're going there. You're also having to make sure that just what you said, that the people who are in those beds also have an appropriate amount of disposable income where a retailer or a restaurateur feels comfortable going into that area, that they're going to be able to have folks who have disposable income to spend dollars in their establishments. So heads and beds is, I would say, the most important factor, but it is not the only factor. You're absolutely right. And that's why we've looked at a comprehensive package real quick, combining detai

They can't control that. And so they were hedging their bets around that tipping fee. So those major constructions are ongoing as well as the improvements of the leachate facility that go along with that. We mentioned a little bit that there is a cost increase because we have ramping up requirements around both standard maintenance and landfill gas associated with our closed landfill and around landfill gas associated with our open landfill. We integrate a digital way of monitoring our performance to ensure that we improve the quality and ensure that all streets are treated appropriately and in a safe manner. Another huge area for us is tied to the 311 system and one of the big accomplishments was in the tree trimming. We had over 6000 legacy requests, many going back as far as seven years. And the department has recently completed all of those. Those are sort of zeroed out and we are beginning to that the Motorola was the old three one one system. We now have the salesforce system which is new. And we are sort of cutting through the backlog in that our goal is really to remove the backlog so that we can move to sort of a proactive posture and a maintenance posture which is what our department is really set up to do. So here this shows as we look at the entire PGC 311. Two years ago, roughly when I joined the department, we had nearly 20,000 backlogged items. And through diligent work by an entire team led largely by deputy director Olusche Olabanley, you can see the progress that was made in a very short period of time. So our backlog is roughly somewhere around 5000 items and we're sort of working to get that eliminated. Our goal, as I mentioned, is to not really have a backlog so that we can proactively address complaints that come in to the department. Another huge area that is new for us, Prince George's county has not really had a comprehensive street sweeping program in residential areas. We did. The department did sweep collectors and arterials, some industrial areas, some residential areas, selective areas. We are in the process of rolling out comprehensive residential street sweeping and we thank you for the sweepers that were budgeted for last year. And we put in another sweeper for this year to give us some redundancy in the program. But this is a huge program that will be broken out into two phases. Phase one will be rolled out this summer and we'll be sweeping about a little over 700 curb miles every five weeks. And phase two we'll be up to nearly 1600 kermiles and that will be covered by a fleet of five machines and they'll be swept like every five weeks. Now, to put it in some context, Montgomery county sweeps for three months a year, and they sweep about 4100 curb miles. We'll be sweeping nearly 5000 every three months, and we will be sweeping for 28 weeks. So we'll be providing a far greater, a more robust approach to it. This came out of the initiative that was started in November of 2022, and the county executive directed us to improve the litter in the county. And in going through the blitz, as it was called at the time, we discovered that the, we had one sweeper at the time, that one sweeper picked up nearly 300 tons of litter. So that really told us something that really, that there's a lot of residual litter that's in the gutter pans, as you can see in the slide, that really a human being cannot collect. It's really better suited for a machine to collect. So we are really optimistic that this will improve the overall cleanliness of our streets and the concomitant improvements to the Chesapeake Bay as stormwater runs eventually to the bay. That would probably help our TMTL as well, the total maximum daily load on the waterways. It does because the sweepers that we are acquiring are called regenerative air sweepers now, they're different from vacuums or brooms. Those sweepers have the ability to pick up nitrogen and phosphorus in addition to litter. So that definitely will reduce TMDL loads of those pollutants. Residual salt will always be, will also be picked up and ultimately all the water flows to the bay. And this will sort of be very beneficial to that. We're taking a different approach also in the way in which we are approaching streets now, this graphic shows broken down by councilmatic district, the roadway conditions within equity emphasis areas within each district. Now, just to step back slightly, what we did, the county in 2018 began to sort of use the PCI pavement condition index measure to have an objective way to determine what conditions of roads are in the county. We have nearly 40,000 streets in the county, more than 2000 miles of roads, and for the first time in about ten years, we reassessed the entire county network. As you can see on this and in the subsequent slides, districts do not have the same number of miles of roads. And equity emphasis is also something that we would like to focus on. Another great initiative that we, that we're working on is the sidewalk trip hazard mitigation program. Now, many of the older communities were built at times when, before arborists were involved, when trees were planted. So they tended to plant the wrong tree in the wrong place. So one of our most successful programs is called right tree, right place. And what it attempts to do is to correct that legacy problem by making sure that we're planting the right tree in the right width of planting space. However, these problems remain. And in many of the older communities, you find that the sidewalks are sort of not level. There are geometric defects. They may not be structural defects in that they can't really carry the weight, but they do make it difficult to sort of traverse, ride a bike on, walk on, things of that nature. So we started a program on a pilot basis. We have 19 locations in which 16 have been done. We started this last November, and since last November, we have eliminated nearly 15,000 trip hazards from sidewalks using this approach. And what this does is that it removes the portion of the sidewalk that is posing a trip hazard. That works because the sidewalk is about four inches thick, and we're removing like a fraction of an inch, like, you know, trip. You can trip on like a quarter of an inch, something like that. So we level it off so that the sidewalk is sort of passable once again. And we've had very, we're very pleased with that pilot and plan to sort of expand that integrated into our program going forward into our operations going forward. Another big issue, a big initiative that we're working on is dealing with sidewalks once again. And we want to sort of use data. We always use data to try to drive the operations of the department. So what we are currently doing is we are going to, for the first time, collect condition data for the sidewalks in Prince George's county. It is not known, other than a very rough estimate, the entire mileage of sidewalk that is available, that's present in the county. But we will know this later this year. Not only will we know the mileage, not only will we know the missing areas where sidewalks should be, not only will we know whether our ADA ramps are conforming to the ADA standard, but we will also have a condition rating for the sidewalks, which will then allow us to move to a programmatic approach to addressing it with these types of large initiatives. Unless you can turn it into a program, you're often going to spend a lot of money with, not with very uneven sort of results. And we are very confident that coming out of this exercise, we will be able to sort of have a sidewalk program which can be funded, costed, funded, and scheduled. And then that will allow us to sort of have an accountable way of delivering that particular improvement. One of the we're not only doing great work in the infrastructure side, but we also are very concerned with our workforce development. And we have in the office of Administrative Services, headed by associate director Ebony Gatewood Crenshaw, we have begun a, we spun up a workforce development unit. And one of the large initiatives that we're working on is what we're calling our career ladder now within, to give some context within the DPW, and this is common in dpws, it's not particular to ours. Staff often do not have a clear picture as to how they progress in their careers. And this has collateral effects, negative effects, in that it affects morale, it affects the ability to sort of upskill staff staff and retain and attract staff. So our program is a comprehensive program that will correct those deficiencies. And it's being done not in the director's office, where I'm sitting in my office and sort of creating this. We have integrated staff from all levels throughout the organization to help us put this together, and we are, I think we're doing terrific work on this. I really am pleased and excited, as are members of staff with, you know, what we will produce coming out of this, which will be beneficial to the department today and for years to come. Our zero emissions bus, where we're trying to transition and actively and aggressively transitioning our fleet to zero emissions. I'll go into some detail there. Transit forward looks at really the quality of our service, really improving our customer experience and improving our reliability and efficiency of service, and then our service changes, which. There are a couple of new service changes happening this spring. And on June 3, we will be introducing. Drumroll, please. Really exciting. Two new routes, one from Greenbelt to Laurel. Using our travel demands analysis and in partnership again with Wamada through their better bus network, we identified areas throughout the county that lacked transit service. So Greenbelt to Laurel was one of them. And we'll be actually going, this line will go through the Laurel Regional Hospital and a couple of senior centers as well. The second route is the route 29, which will go from Largo to Landover. So these two new routes is just the beginning of what we hope to expand over the five year period. We did a couple of route adjustments and we'll be introducing microtransit, which is an on demand service. Some routes in areas in the county does not warrant fixed route service. But similar to how we all have gotten accustomed to the Uber and the lifts, micro transit allows the opportunity for on demand service. So where transit service is needed. So we're looking at three zones, and according to the data that we pulled post Covid, we're looking at expanding in the Bowie, Clinton and Laurel area. As I mentioned earlier, our transit vision plan, an extensive amount of outreach and stakeholder engagement. We have since the beginning of fall of last year into now, this spring and summer, over 15 events we've talked to, community meeting, we've been at community meetings, pop ups, going to high ridership routes, having webinars, partnering with Wamada, going to senior centers, municipalities, etcetera. To really get the word out about the transit vision plan, we hope to release late spring, early summer, some of the spring service changes that I had mentioned earlier, the addition of the two routes there are, you know, some cervix extensions as well, that we're pretty happy to announce as well. The route 30 will begin to. We'll have stops at the Iverson Mall and Suitland metro station, the route 36 extending to Branch Avenue. So these are just the beginnings of what we're seeing, and we're seeing progress. We did a fall service change. The county hasn't had a major service change in a while, so in the fall, we made a lot of adjustments. Have we seen that improvement? Actually, let me go back up. We've seen that improvement in on time performance where system wide, we're at about 73%. Our goal by the end of fiscal year 24 is 75%. We know that best practice is to be at least 80, so we're making progress there. And then our zero emissions bus transition. I want to thank chair Ivey for your support in really getting the letter out. The support letter out. We're actively going for grants we're going to be applying for, which is due today. The team is working hard on that to get that submitted today. But we're going to be submitting a nearly $40 million grant to complete. To complete phase two of our microgrid. And this is more on the construction side. Phase one was more the design, which would be able to charge up to nearly 80 buses at the same time. And so we're happy about that. You know, our $40 million proud to charge initiative, which was last year, was really our largest grant since then. So we're hoping to match that next year. So, again, our goal is to be at 70%. So we were successful in getting a grant to make safety improvements to seven of those. This is Chilham Road, which was another very wide cartwheel that had had some pedestrian issues, conflicts with vehicles. We are close to completing our obligations under the consent decree and director crooms did mention that we'd be out of that fairly soon. insights.observation: The Department of Public Works and Transportation is exploring alternative ways of paving roads that provide adequate life strength and prevent water from getting into the base of the road, which helps to prevent freeze-thaw cycles and degradation.
The department has faced budgetary constraints but still aims to maintain the level of county-supported road and curb work.
The grant funding that was not actualized was on the operating side and not the capital improvement program (CIP) side, affecting budgets and infrastructure projects.
Funding for the bridge program is largely federally funded and driven by structural condition, and the department has been successful in securing grants and awards for completed projects.

It was brought to my attention pretty recently that there are over 20 new capital bike share locations being added to the northern part of the county, and we're not seeing that same level in the southern part of the county. Can I get some explanation on that? I think the capital bike share, one of the criteria that had been used was density, which sort of translates, is sort of related to demand. In a sense, it's kind of related demand. So in the southern part of the county, I think in the way that it was being looked at, that might be the explanation as to why it was skewed in that fashion. I think a lot of decisions from the Olsen Brooks administration has been skewed towards the north, frankly. And maybe one of the bases is density. But we are paying taxes too, in the southern part of the county. And the reason why I'm raising this is because residents of mine in Fort Washington desperately want these capital bike share locations. And while we don't have the density of the northwestern part of the county, you know, we are also tax paying citizens that matter, and we should be treated equitably. And that does not appear to be the case. So what needs to happen for us to get some geographical equity? So I'm sorry not to. I do see in our memo from Mister Hamlin, the bike share initiative, that there's a feasibility study going on that would add to that. But I don't know where this is. Yeah, it's a study. So we have to sort of. I was just explaining what, what had been the metric that was used to help decide where these facilities should have been placed. But a study is being done to sort of reassess to see how it could be more equitable to your. The point that you're making. Thank you. Please communicate that with us. I look forward to working with you. There's a group that is in contact with our chair and that's in my district for Washington forw
