chunks.text: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Prince George's county council. I'm just sorry that we can't be in the hearing room today, but given how hot it is down there, you should be glad that we're up here. So I'm going to begin our proclamations with Charles Herbert Flowers High School Lady Jaguars basketball and if my colleagues would all come join me. Okay, well, come on up. I hate to have to tell you all, but this is my favorite basketball team in Prince George's county. Sorry, it's just true. Okay. Whereas Charles Herbert Flowers High School Lady Jaguars basketball team achieved an outstanding 2023 2024 season, and whereas the Flowers high school lady Jaguars varsity team roster includes seniors, class of 2024, Trinity Young and Kennedy Freeman, juniors, class of 2025, Kyla Graham, London Miller, Lola Saunders and Elise Cooper, sophomores, class of 2026, AJ, Alana Joy, Faith Okonkwo and Brooke Mitchell, Freshman, class of 2027, Ava Richmond, J. MacMartin, Skye Blankney, Brianna Steve and Laurel McLaughlin. And whereas, the coaches for the team includes Roderick Harrison, Tiffany Smith, doctor Crystal Ward, Bianca Brown, Ariel Chichester and Tracy Allen, managers. Well, let me. I don't have to say the managers today. Sorry, because they didn't come. I heard that. Whereas the Charles Herbert Flowers High School principal is doctor Gorman Brown, Carlisle Rose is the athletic director and whereas the 2023 to 2024 Lady Jaguars per game statistical leaders are Kyla Graham with 14 points and four assists, AJ Alana Joy with 13 points, ten and a half rebounds and seven assists. Faith Okonkwo achieved five points and eight rebounds. Eight. Ava Redmond obtained 15 points and five assists, London Miller contributed five points and five rebounds and Breonna Steve attained five points in four assists. And whereas individual accolades and achievements for the Flowers Lady Jaguars include AJ Alana Joy, Kyla Graham and Ava Redmond, who've been selected to the Prince George's County's all county first team. With Alana Joy earning the prestigious title of co player of the year. Alana Joy also made the all Mets fourth team. Kyla Graham and Ava Redmond made the all Mets honorable mention list. Faith Okonkwo earned a Prince George's county all county second team spot. London Miller and Breonna Steve were recognized on the Prince George's all county honorable mention selection. Therefore, be it proclaimed by the Prince George's county council that the Charles Herbert Flowers Lady Jaguars basketball team excelled as they embody their motto, teach, which means team effort, attitude, commitment and humility, the Lady Jaguars is congratulated on 20 wins and three losses during the 2023 to 2024 season, inclusive of four a wins in the 2024 NPSSAA girls basketball regional semifinals and regional finals and the state quarterfinals. This is signed by me, Jolene Ivey, the council chair, Mel Franklin, at large member, and Calvin Hawkins, at large member. Would you like to say a couple of words? I'm going to first say thank you to all the council members. We really appreciate this honor, and we look out in the crowd and see all the other teams that have done an excellent job. I want to say congratulations to you guys, as well, and congratulations to this young team that has a lot of opportunity in front of them. I appreciate you and thank you very much. And I'm gonna let my captains say. Say one word. I want to say thank you to my team, my parents. I want to thank God for putting me on this path, and I wouldn't be able to be here without my great coaches that encouraged me and uplift our team. And I also want to thank the county council for this opportunity to receive this proclamation. Thank you. Thank you. Okay, if you could come behind the table, we're going to take taking home Juanika present to Saratoga. Good morning. So now we have. Next we have Saratzville High School. If you all could stand up and join us in the front, it'd be greatly appreciated. Hey. How are you? Yes, thank you. Yeah, you're fine. No, no, no. Oh, yes. Go ahead. Oh, you want to do it? Okay. Come on. Today, if everyone could just. We're about to acknowledge Surrattsville high school ladies basketball team, but we also want to make a special acknowledgement. Council member Fisher will be making the acknowledgement. I want to acknowledge two favorite people that are here today. We have delegate Janelle Wilkins from District 20, who, and especially for all the young people in the room, delegate Wilkins is the youngest black woman in the state legislature, and she is the chair of the biggest black caucus in the country, which is the Maryland Black Caucus. And then, of course, I have to also recognize. We have Lieutenant Colonel Marlon Jenkins, who is here, who is also a member of our central committee for District 47. And he actually heads a battalion of over 500 men and women in uniform here in the state of Maryland at Haverdy Grace, and they're both my best friends

Revising and adding definitions, revising applicability and exemption requirements revising plan review, validity and grandfathering requirements revising certain definitions, providing for certain fee in lieu establishes, establishing a certain fund, revising the variance of appeal process, revising the enforcement process, revising the conservation requirements, including priority areas, thresholds, replacement ratios, revising conservation requirements, design criteria, priorities, options, and bonding. I'm Janet Gingold and I'm speaking today on behalf of Prince George's Sierra Club. The Sierra Club supports CB 2024 and we urge the council to pass it, but continue to work for realizing the benefits of trees for decreasing health disparities and mitigating the impacts of climate change. Updating the woodland and wildlife habitat conservation is necessary for the county to comply with the new state regulations and to meet our climate goals. But more important, tree conservation is a health issue. Heat waves kill people and trees can help decrease the impacts of excess heat. It's also an equity issue. While our overall tree canopy coverage might look good, the distribution of our trees is very uneven. We remain concerned that even with these much improved rules, we will still see trees removed from where they are scarce and planted where they are more plentiful, where there are fewer trees, higher temperatures increase the risks of health problems for vulnerable populations, especially the very young, the very old, for people who work and play outdoors, people with health conditions that affect their ability to adapt to heat, and people who don't have access to air conditioning. As we increase density and transit oriented zones, special care must be taken to conserve existing forest remnants and use green infrastructure, especially trees, to mitigate heat island effects. Please do all you can to put a value on trees, especially mature trees, and especially in our urbanized areas. Under CB 2024, a hierarchy of afforestation and reforestation prioritizes conserving mature trees and replanting on site. However, in section 25 122 c, the conservation method priorities there's no clear penalty or incentive that makes it worthwhile for developers to meet requirements through higher priority methods. We ask that you consider requiring a greater acreage ratio. When lower priority methods are chosen, fees in lieu and penalties for violation should be substantially greater. Also, we'd like to see stronger criteria for allowing variances so that they become rare and not routine. Please keep in mind that replanting does not instantly replace the benefits of trees removed during a heat wave next summer. A recently planted seedling will provide no significant shade or evaporative cooling. Most of us here today will be dead and gone before an acre replanted today can provide the ecosystem services provided by an acre of mature woodland it supposedly replaces. The Sierra Club urges the county council to make CB 2024 as strong as it can be and continue to work to ensure that already overburdened communities do not suffer disproportionately from the impacts of climate change. First, let me state that while I'm not opposed to CB 2024 as a whole, I have significant concerns regarding the grandfathering provisions set forth in section 25 119 g of this legislation. These concerns relate to projects, many of which are some of the largest and most economically significant in the county, being able to rely on their approved tree conservation plans and or amend them in accordance with existing regulations while their underlying land use approvals remain valid. Projects that have a valid tree conservation plan one, for example, usually with the preliminary plan of subdivisions, CSP CDP under the prior ordinance, should be able to rely on that TCP one approval to then file the subsequent tree conservation plan two using the same regulations the TCP one was approved under. It's not abundantly clear from this legislation that that can occur. Similarly, some of the largest projects in the county have many stages or phases that will need the ability to file new tree conservation plan two s using the grandfather provisions to keep moving forward. Similarly, tree conservation plans two, while otherwise valid, must be able to be revised using existing regulations to avoid significant and unintended consequences of land use entitlements conflicting with tree conservation plants. The current language in this bill seems to indicate that any revision to a tree conservation plan not accepted by July 1, 2024 must use the new regulations in this division. Tree conservation plans are amended all the time for utilities, for outfalls, for very minor things, so having that flexibility for large projects is critically important. Moving forward. As for expiration dates of a tree conservation plan, this bill does not also seem to clearly align with the validity periods in the zoning ordinance under the transitional provisions. July 1, 2028 seems arbitrary for expiration of approved tree conservation plans when large projects can take much longer to develop using existing land use entitlements I do align myself with the April 29 letter from the MBIA, and I respectfully request that this bill please be referred back to the tiE committee to continue the dialogue regarding grandfathering. Given the current economic climate locally and nationally, it is critical that the approval periods in this bill do not negate or conflict with the validity periods of existing land use entitlements and projects moving forward. I thank for your time and consideration. Thank you, sir. Next, we have attorney Matthew Tedesco. Do you have three minutes to speak, sir? Good afternoon, mister chairman, members of the council. For the record, Matthew Tedesco with the law firm of McMose in Greenbelt, Maryland. I would align myself with Mister Antonetti's comments as well as the letter dated, excuse me, the letter from MBIA presented on this bill. I too am not in opposition to CB 20. However, we do respectfully request that this council recommit this bill back to tie committee prior to CB 20 being voted out of committee and in response to House Bill 1511, which was pending at the time that this bill was voted out of committee. The committee chair acknowledged that if House Bill 1511 passed, which it has done and has since been enrolled, CB 20 would be, quote, brought back in reliance. On this. We respectfully ask that CB 20 be recommitted to tie to adjust the grandfathering previously mentioned by Mister Antonetti and as it addresses previously approved plans. As the current grandfathering language in section 25 119 g indicates it was added after introduction and the industry only learned about it in mid April without a meaningful ability to be heard on the late minute addition to CB 20. Outside of this public hearing today, there are significant issues and concerns with the current version of CB 20 regarding grandfathering. These must be addressed prior to adopting the bill. The best way to address these is comprehensively is to recommit this bill to tie. Since House Bill 1511 passed and moved the effective date of Senate Bill 526 back two years, the portions of House Bill 1511 that reference the effective date of July 2024, we believe, were to allow jurisdictions to fix a limited issue created by the state in 2021 regarding mitigation banking. Therefore, the date is limited to address that purpose only. It is not a date whereby a jurisdiction needs to totally revamp its entire wilderness Conservation ordinance. We believe that DNR's intent to include the July 2024 date in House Bill 1511 was limited to the mitigation banking only so as to help jurisdictions and applicants address an issue created by the state in 2021 regarding banking. The July 2024 date is not a mandate or requirement for jurisdictions to hurriedly pass a bill. House Bill 1511 delays the effective date of Senate Bill 526 by two years. Therefore, this council can and should recommit CB 20 to tie to work through the

Colleagues, as we move forward for continued public hearings, bills eligible for third reading. We're on to CB 21 2024, and this is an act concerning tree canopy coverage ordinance for the purpose of revising the existing applicability language requiring a certain grandfather provision, revising tree canopy coverage requirements, revising the credit and security requirements and adding the planning director to those that can issue waivers. This is sponsored by council members Harrison Olson, Watson, Dinogo, Oriata and Fisher. I do believe we have some speakers on CB 21 2024. Miss Janet Gingold, could you please step forward please? You have three minutes to speak. Thank you. Hi, I'm Janet Gingold and I'm speaking today on behalf of the Prince George's Sierra Club. Prince George's County Sierra Club urges you to pass CB 21 2024. This bill will reduce the area of disturbance for requiring compliance with the tree canopy ordinance from 5000 to 2500 square feet, increase the required tree canopy percentages in most zones except agricultural and certain mixed zones, and require the percentages to be met within the neck tract area. Tree canopy is important for healthy communities, especially in our more urbanized areas. As we face a future with more excess heat days, we have a tree equity problem in our county. According to the American Forest Foundation's tree equity navigator, the census blocks in Prince George's county with temperature extremes that are ten degrees higher on average have 27% less tree canopy. And while this legislation will not fix the current inequities, it will help us move in the right direction. Requiring that tree canopy percentages must be met within the net tract area is an important step forward. Trees might pull carbon out of the atmosphere wherever they are located, but for our residents to expect experience the benefits of reduced air pollution, lessened heat island effect and reduced flooding, they need trees in their neighborhood, not somewhere else. Reducing the disturbed area from 5000 to 2500 square feet will reduce the number of properties that do not have to meet these important requirements. Using net tract area to calculate the required tree canopy percentage and requiring that the requirement be met on a net tract area will result in greater tree coverage, as will increases in the percentage required in most zones. Together, these new requirements will bring us greater tree canopy to more neighborhoods in developed areas, enabling more people to experience their benefits. The Prince George's counties government and Operations and Fiscal Policy Committee convened on April 11, 2024 to consider CB 12 20 24, an act concerning procurement practices and revisions for the purpose of amending provisions of subtitle ten a regarding administrative procedures, award of contracts and economic development generally relating to procurements subject to subtitle ten a. During the committee session, Secinda Skinner, County Council liaison offers of the county executive, introduced the other executive branch staff present, which included chief administrative officer Tara Jackson, office of Central Services Director Jonathan Butler and Pam Dickerson, deputy director. Director Butler explained that the proposed legislation establishes two additional exemptions from procurement practices. The bill eliminates the business development reserve program and replaces it with the implementation of the supply schedule. This legislation creates a two year period during which certifications remain valid. Finally, the bill lowers the county based small business percentage bid discount to 12% from 15%. The goal of the changes to the bid structure is to develop the minority business enterprises in the county more effectively. However, despite the lower percentage, the hierarchy remains, with county based MBE's receiving the highest percentage county based minority business enterprise 15% county based small businesses 12% county based businesses 10% minority business enterprise or disadvantaged business enterprise, 5% and county located business, 3%. insights.observation: CR 12 2024 would establish a workgroup to review, analyze, and evaluate county procurement regulations and recommend updates.
The last comprehensive update of the code took place in 1992, and significant work was also done in 2016 and 2017.

The procurement regulations workgroup would be composed of seven members from various county offices, initially including the police department and fire department; later amended to include representatives from the Office of Law and Office of Information Technology.
The workgroup is required to present a report summarizing its actions, including analysis and recommendations for improvements to the current procurement regulations and requirements.
A friendly amendment suggested including a designee from a business that does business with the county for an outside perspective.
Creation of an office of procurement and transferring procurement-related functions to the new department.
The legislation will become effective unless disapproved by a majority vote of the full council.

They're closer to where their businesses are. Contractors were able to come in and negotiate for the places and bid on the places that they really wanted. So we think overall that we're already seeing, seeing some efficiencies in the time that we've, even with the contract not being in effect, just because of the conversations

And then there's idea of, I just want to make sure we have a level of customer service because it can't be a huge amount of complaints. And then it's all, you know, crying wolf of the community. I think there has to be some fire there. So every validated complaint results in a fine. So if we can validate a complaint, it results in a fine. One of the things we added on this contract is that if a, if, when the hauler is out in the community, if a trash can is not out, they are to take a photograph. Therefore they have proof that there was not a trash can there out at the time that they picked up the trash. So then if a resident calls and says, well, they missed my trash, and we see a photograph of the entire front yard of the house, then we know that that's not true. Right. If they don't have that, then we're looking at the resident, as you know, they put out the trash because these folks didn't verify that that trash wasn't there. It makes us have less investigations to do do, and it also holds the trash haulers accountable. The trash, I'm sorry, that is in the new contract that starts in July. Correct. And then in addition. So you were talking about where people wound up. So where people wound up was where they bid. So in most cases, the haulers bid in places that are the closest to their facilities. So by and large, you know, that's how we selected folks. We certainly did not decide that one community got a worse vendor over another. We did it based upon a cost based system in combination with appropriate metrics for performance. So we are able to rank those things. But by and large, we saw that folks bid on the areas that they believed that they could do effectively. So I'm hopeful again that we've done it in a way that we will see better performance across the board. But no, decisions are not made that we're going to. We didn't decide to switch folks around because this community has always had the bad hauler and now they're going to be over here. No, we looked across it and folks bid. And we also have had contractors in the past who have not paid their bills, and those ones are not also new, not part of this contract. May I add, starting July 1, we will have performance evaluations that should be conducted by everyone that manages a contract. So quarterly, there will be performance evaluations of those vendors, and we will collect that information, that data to look at service levels as well as new performance. So if you're not performing contractually, we will be able to help and be able to look at the vendors, and that will go against their performance whenever they are applying for other solicitations in the county. chunks.text: May 30, 2024. Madam Clerk, please call the roll chair Olson here. Vice Chair Harrison here. Council member Burroughs, councilmember Danoga and councilmember Fisher. Three present. Thank you. Thank you very much. Let me turn it over to Mister battle for an orientation. Thank you, sir. We have two items on our agenda today, the first of which is the reappointment of Miss Lynette D. S. B. Williams as commissioner of the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission. She will continue to serve as one of three representatives from Prince George county on the commission, and she's been in that capacity since 2022. And if confirmed, her next term would expire in 2028. Now, I've been guilty in the past, mister chair, of stepping on Miss Brewer's presentation. So I will turn it over to the county executive appointments liaison, Miss Marion Brewer. And after which you can have some comments from Commissioner SB Williams. Okay, thank you very much. Thanks Brewer. It's great to have you here. Thank you. Good morning. Miss Lynette Sb. Williams, a resident of Bowie, is a shareholder with Cozen O'Connor where she manages every phase of litigation, including taking and defending fact and expert depositions, preparing and arguing key motions, negotiating with opposing counsel, drafting motions for summary judgment, and participating in pretrial conferences. She is also a board director responsible for the management and fiscal affairs of more than 1600 employees and is the chief diversity, equity and inclusion officer. Miss Espy Williams previously served as vice chair office managing partner in the community. She also serves on the advisory board of the corporate council. Women of color Miss Espy Williams earned her undergraduate degree from Spelman College and her Juris Doctor from the University of Maryland School of law. She holds the following licenses. I'm currently working as an office managing partner in the Washington DC office for my law firm, where I've served for 18 years as a lawyer. And my practice is really focusing on providing strategic advice to clients and really high exposure liability matters, which really has translated to my work with WSSC to really think through issues of import in our industry. I currently sit on several boards, and so I have the board experience and the governance experience to lead. But I also would continue to be. I would also be honored to continue my role as chair of the Legislative Committee for Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission. It's really where a lot of the work is being done when you think about the issues that are affecting the residents in Prince George's county and how we can rectify those issues on a legislative level. Long reach planning should include development and maintenance of resilience hubs for all communities. New community centers should be climate ready powered with resilient clean energy systems. New residential developments should include resilient energy systems and access to a resilience hub. Good evening chair ivey and members of the county Council of Prince US county. I'm Ruby Stimley, founder and CEO of Eco Latinos, a Prince Georgia's county non profit environmental organization with the mission to amplify the voices of the latino communities in the pursuit of social and environmental justice through outreach, education and activism. Since 2016, Co Latinos has effectively engaged spanish speaking residents in a wide range of of environmental programs. We engage our communities in waterways and trail cleanups, litter reduction and pollution mitigation campaigns, urban tree plantings, as well as multicultural outreach events and language appropriate conservation trainings. As agents of environmental justice, we are transforming a mostly middle class and white movement, but making our programs accessible to neighborhoods that have been traditionally neglected. We are grateful for the support the county has generously given to ecolatino since 2019, from non departmental grants to special appropriation grants from council member Ivy der Noga, Burroughs Hawkins Streeter, Franklin, thank you very much. Past fundings by the county council has allowed ecolatinos to expand our capacity to grow and be able to reach more county residents. For fiscal year 25 24 25, Ecolatino seeks continued funding for our environmental education program for latino youth. We are also developing a spanish language green infrastructure and maintenance training specifically designed for current and prospective latino landscape professionals. These culturally appropriate programs, designed for underrepresented and under resourced communities, will translate into more sustainable communities and a healthier Chesapeake Bay watershed. With the county's support to Ecolatinos, we will continue to do our part to change the narrative that environmental actions in our communities are underfunded. Collatinos requires sustainable revenue streams to continue to build our capacity and allow for the continued expansion of our unique and innovative approach. Diversity is the county's greatest strength. Your support to colatinos will not only contribute to the creation of green jobs, but also engage our youth in the career paths of the future. Together we can work towards more inclusive, cleaner parks, greener spaces and ultimately a healthier and more sustainable future for all. Thank you for your consideration. Thank you very much. We've come to the end of the list of people who have signed up to speak. Is there a motion to adjourn? Motion by council member Watson, second by council council member Fisher. All those who are in favor, please raise your hand. We are adjourned.

The Health and Human Services and Public Safety Committee met on May 13, 2024, to consider the county executive's nominees for the fire commission. The fire commission reviews each of the county's volunteer fire companies financial needs and requests for public funds. It formulates one budget, one capital improvement program and one current expense budget for all volunteer fire companies annually regarding the expenditure of public funds. Under the provision of our charter, the commission submits budgets and programs, together with an appropriate justification to the county executive. Miss Marion Brewer, the appointments liaison for the Office of the county Executive, Angela Alselbrooks, presented an overview of the nominees qualifications to the fire commission. The nominee shared information on their backgrounds and expressed their interest in serving on the fire commission for Prince George's County, Assistant Fire Chief Michael White participated in the work session to support the nominees. The nominees serve as volunteer, career or resident members with terms expiring on July 1, 2026. The nominees are Miss Gloria Bell, Miss Michelle Chandler, Miss Lisa Hedgewood, Mister Marlon Selman and Mister Kyle Snyder. I am pleased to present the county executives five reappointments to the fire commission. First, we have Miss Gloria J. Bell. I'm going to ask her to stand. A resident of Fort Washington, she serves as the district four commissioner to six volunteer corporations. She brings her life skills coaching experience with the Department of Corrections to the fire commission. Most recently, she served on the FY 2024 volunteer Station program funds committee and previously developed standing operating procedures for department functions while facilitating new member orientation sessions. As the chief of staff to the president, Miss Bell received her Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Maryland University College. She was appointed in 2022. Next, we have Miss Michelle A. Chandler, a resident of Bowie. She is a firefighter medic battalion chief with Prince George's fire EMS department. She is a dedicated and accomplished professional that not only has 25 years, that has 25 years of operational experience. In addition to having a distinguished career in the United States Air Force and Maryland Air National Guard, serving as a liaison to the fire stations in District three, Miss Chandler has consistently provided support and assistance when needed and taken the lead on training newly appointed commissioners on the station supplying ordering process. She's a graduate of Columbia Southern University and was also appointed in 2022. Next, we have Miss Lisa Hagwood. Well now Ray. A resident of Laurel, she is a response coordination branch training and exercise administrator with the Maryland Department of Emergency Management and Fire Services volunteer. A respected emergency management professional, she joined the Greenbelt Volunteer Fire Department and Rescue squad in 2017 where she has held many administrative and operational roles within the department and has gained fire instructor credentials. Miss Ray received her Bachelor of Arts degree from Rowan University and a master of Science degree from the University of Maryland University College and was appointed in 2022. Next, we have Mister Marlon E. Selman, a resident of Bowie. He is a native Prince Georgian and a successful business owner. He is president and CEO of his own business where he oversees day to day operations of the company. He is responsible for the achievement of strategic goals and objectives while ensuring excellent customer service delivery. Mister Selman has provided high quality management and information technology consulting services to the Central Intelligence Agency, National Security Agency, Department of Defense and District Government Services. He received his undergraduate degree from Bowie State University and a graduate degree from Capitol College. He was appointed in 2023. And finally, we have Mister Kyle J. Snyder, a resident of Berwyn Heights. He is the town manager where he manages day to day operations. He joined the volunteer ranks at the age of 16 and is an operational firefighter. He was previously town administrator for Upper Marlboro with oversight of public safety, public works and administration and is president of the Maryland City Managers Association. Mister Snyder received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Maryland, College park and was appointed in 2022. I present to you the county executive nominees to the fire commission. And I'm gonna go there. One last thing. If you have trouble going to sleep at night, this will do it in accordance with the provisions of section 610 tax property article Annotated Code of Maryland, tonight's public hearing seeks public comments regarding the council's consideration of a proposed real property tax rate increase above the state certified constant yield tax rate for the unincorporated areas of the county and for county municipalities the fiscal year 2025. Constant yield tax rates and proposed real property tax rates are set in table one, which is the third attachment to this statement. Copies of the statement and the corresponding attachments are available for your convenience on the county council's website. And as an attachment to tonight's agenda, the council is considering a real property tax rate of $1 per $100 of assessed valuation in unincorporated areas and for the 16 municipalities showing proposed increases from 85 and five hundredths of hundredths of $0.01, as reflected within the proposed county operating and expense budget submitted by the county executive for fiscal year 2025. The proposed real property tax rate for unincorporated areas of the county is $1, which is unchanged from fiscal year 2024. The real property tax rates for 16 municipalities in the county will increase in fiscal year 2025, with a mean average rate of increase of 75 one hundredths of $0.01. For fiscal year 2025. The county is continuing a municipal tax differential as required by state law, and the principal reasons for exceeding the constant yield tax rate in the unincorporated in the incorporated areas are number one, according to state law, the county is required to recognize through a lesser county tax rate those governmental services which municipal governments perform in lieu of similar county government services and number two, to meet the funding levels of programs set forth in the proposed fiscal year 2025 budget requires an increase above the constant yield rate. The county council will consider and adopt the fiscal year 2025 resolution establishing the tax levies for real and personal property taxes for fiscal year 2025 on Tuesday, June 18, 2024, beginning at 10:00 a.m. next, we have the proposed fiscal year 2025 multi year contracts pursuant to section 819, Prince George's county charter in subtitle ten of the Prince George's County Code, tonight's public hearing concerning the proposed fiscal year 2025 county budget additionally seeks public testimony and comment as to certain proposed multi year contractual agreements that require submission to the county council for our review and approval in order to take effect. Approval of such multi year contracts is prescribed by the county charter and the manner set forth in subtitle ten of the Prince George's County Code. Accordingly, a list of the multi year contracts proposed for approval within the fiscal year 2025 budget, as well as the text of this announcement, are available in this hearing room and online as CR 2625 2024 for your use and convenience. The public may comment on these proposed multi year contracts at tonight's public hearing concerning the fiscal year 2025 budget, as well as at the public hearing scheduled for Tuesday, May 7. Time limitations of three minutes per speaker has been imposed. There will be no relinquishing of time by one speaker to another. Written statements may be submitted for the record in addition to or in lieu of verbal testimony. We have Charles Colbert, Upper Marlboro would you like to lead us off tonight? Good evening. Good evening chair Ivey, vice chair Harrison, members of the county council, my name is Charles Colbert and I currently have the privilege of serving as a commissioner on the Town of Upper Marlboro Board of Town Commissioners. Since 2017, the Prince George's County Capital Improvement Plan budget has included a line item and project page within the redevelopment authority's budget for $2.5 million to be allocated for redevelopment activities in the downtown corridor of the Town of Upper Marlboro. Also since 2017, that funding profile has slipped to the right each year with the passage of the annual budget and, as of the current proposed budget standard, to not be initially dispersed until fiscal year 2028. I stand before you today formally requesting that the council accelerate this timeline and begin appropriating the funding in FY 25 the town is in need of investment and support in revitalizing the downtown corridor in order to attract businesses to the community and to better provide services amenities for the residents within and surrounding the town. Currently, 64% of the town's landmass is untaxable government owned property, which hinders our ability to collect adequate revenue to fund revitalization efforts. We're essentially providing services for a population that swells tenfold during business hours on 40% of the potential revenue. However, the town has invested resources in undergoing a vision planning process for downtown redevelopment. My name is Jasper Famous and I'm a student at Blainesburg High School and a proud member of liberty promise that I stand before you to shed light on an issue that has plagued our society, the differences in college enrollment rates between higher income families and lower income families. This problem, often referred to as the opportunity gap, is not just statistical inconsistency. It's a reflection of societal injustices that hinder the dreams and aspirations of countless young individuals in our world. Access to education should be a fundamental right, not a privilege reserved for those for the few who can afford it. Yet the reality is starkly different. Statistics consistently show that students from higher income families are more likely to enroll in colleges compared to the counterparts of lower income families. Why does this gap still exist? The answer lies in the unequal opportunities that exist between the two communities. For many lower income families, the path to higher education is plagued with obstacles, financial constraints, inadequate resources, and limited access to academic support. These all contribute to a lack in college attendance. As a result, many talented individuals are left behind, their potential wasted by circumstances beyond their control. Despite all this negativity, there is a positive programs like Libertys promise. Libertys promise strives to bridge the gap, to bridge the opportunity gap by providing support, mentorship, and resources to students from underserved communities. Through programs like this, individuals are empowered to pursue their dreams regardless of their socioeconomic backgrounds. I speak from personal experience when I say that liberty promise has the power to transform lives. Thanks to the invaluable support network, I've had the privilege of meeting people whom I never would have dreamed of meeting. Some examples are a college admissions officer, Sarah Yasino from Trinity University. I was able to see peer into the mind of college admissions officer and look at what they look at when they read a college application. These interactions not only open doors for me, but have also shattered preconceived notions about what was possible however, Liberty's promise is just one piece of a puzzle. To truly address the opportunity gap, we must collectively commit to breaking the barriers that hinder access to education. Thank you, council members. Thank you. chunks.text: , resilience and community empowerment. Today, I introduce you to a beacon of light in our midst, a nonprofit boxing gym nestled in Brentwood, Maryland, dedicated to serving not only the able bodied, but also those in our community who are often overlooked and marginalized. This is the thump yard. The story behind the thump yard is one of survival, determination, and a deep rooted commitment to making a difference. In 2000, I fell victim to senseless gun violence during a home invasion in Silver Spring, Maryland. This tragic event left me paralyzed from my chest down, forever altering the course of my life. But from the ashes of adversity emerged a powerful vision, a vision to unite our community, raise awareness on gun violence, and provide a safe haven where individuals of all backgrounds can find solace and strength through the sport of boxing. Myself, alongside my brother, Rioberto della Cruz, turned our pain into purpose and founded the thump yard. Inspired by our father, Wilfredo dela Cruz, who introduced us to the sport at a young age, we embarked on our journey to create something truly transformative. From humble beginnings, hosting events in Adelphi, Maryland, the thump Yard has risen to become the leader in amateur boxing events in DC, Maryland, Virginia, impacting over 800 participants throughout the years. In 2023, we took a significant step forward by becoming a recognized nonprofit organization and opening our doors as a boxing gym to serve the community. TTY boxing and fitness we are more than just a gym. We are family, a support system and a catalyst for positive change. We believe in the power of boxing to instill disciplined confidence and hard work in all of our members, regardless of age or ability. Right now, TTY boxing and fitness is home to approximately 60 members, but our mission extends beyond the confines of the ring. We recognize that mental health issues and trauma affect individuals of all ages and backgrounds, which is why we offer programs tailored to address these challenges. From youth empowerment initiatives to senior fitness programs, from academic support services to community outreach efforts, the thump yard is committed to building champions both inside and outside the ring. Our favorite quote encapsulates our philosophy perfectly. Not everything in life is about boxing, but everything in boxing is about life. Through the sport of boxing, we aim to cultivate values that will resonate with our youth long after they leave our gym. We believe that the future lies in our youth and it is our responsibility to equip them with tools they need to succeed. But we cannot do it alone. We need the support of our community, our local leaders and members to ensure that our program continues to thrive and expand. With your assistance, we hope to secure resources that will enable us to reach even more individuals in need and be a beacon of hope for the most underserved populations in PG county. In conclusion, I urge you to join us in our mission to make a difference, one punch at a time. Together, we can build a stronger, more resilient community where everyone has the opportunity to thrive. Thank you for your time and consideration. chunks.text: nd that this is a challenging budget cycle, climate action, protection of our streams and wildlands and maintaining a healthful environment for pinch Georgians cannot be considered optional. Healthy people need a healthy environment to safeguard the health and well being of pinch Georgians. We urge you to align the operational capital improvements budgets with our county's environmental values and with the Climate Action Plan adopted by this council in 2022. One of the great concerns is that climate change is not found in the policy focus areas. Climate change is a great threat to our future and local governments provide crucial avenue to addressing the crisis through making wise land use decisions and transportation decisions that are more sustainable, assisting residents with access to financial resources to electrify their lives, and ensuring the permitting process do not impede progress. Making sure we are resilient to climate change the county council adopted this climate change action plan in 2022 and it should be well underway. However, the budget does not appear to reflect that this climate action plan was only mentioned once in the context of the department and the environment. However, the budget of all county agencies, especially Dpw and T and D PI, should reflect the change in direction and new priorities that are necessary because of climate change. The budget needs to be amended to show that the climate action plan is a priority. Though we are supportive of such initiatives such as resource recovery, vision zero, community engagement, enhanced bus service, beautification, restoring the health of county waters and flood management. These are part of the solution, but they only nibble around the edges. One very important position that needs to be created is in the county executive office. Given governmental structures, it's not necessary to provide funding for a full time climate officer in the county executive's office to coordinate mitigation across all agencies. This position cannot reside in DoE and must be in the county executive's office so that the person in this position can work cross agency. We are also greatly concerned about the budget cuts found in DoE. While there's a 2.7% budget cut for FY from FY 24 projected actuals, it doesn't seem so bad. When you looked at the office of the director, there's a draconian budget cut of nearly 50%. While even more responsibility for climate action and implementation is required, we need this budget cut to be reversed. It's also disconcerting to see how the way, how little in the way of local funding goes to bettering our environment. This has created a department that's highly dependent upon the whims of grants, and we need to make sure that policy policy actions are found in local funding. Thank you. Thank you. And is there a motion to adjourn? Motion for adjournment. All those in favor, please raise your hand. We are adjourned.

chunks.text: Recording in progress good evening, everyone. The Board of Appeals hearings are being called to order at 06:03 p.m. on Wednesday, March 27, 2024, as per the decision announced by the county Executive, effective March 9, 2022, at 05:00 p.m. the Prince George's county state of emergency expired in an abundance of caution and given the current state of the novel coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic, the county council is now operating under the following procedures. The Board of Appeals in person meetings and or hearings continue to operate virtually using alternative public participation options, including utilization of digital technology or teleconferencing. Virtual hearings are recorded and transcribed during the meeting. Please state your name for the record each time you speak. For clarity and transcription. Please do not speak over another person. If you wish to speak, please raise your hand and you will be called upon in turn. Our criteria for granting appeals involving variances pursuant to council Bill CB 16 2021, section 27 230 of the zoning ordinance authorizes the board to grant variances when a specific parcel of land has exception. Physically is physically unique and unusual in a manner different from the nature of surrounding properties with respect to exceptional narrowness, shallowness, shape, exceptional topographic conditions, or other extraordinary conditions peculiar to the specific parcel, such as historical significance or environmentally sensitive features. The particular uniqueness and peculiarity of a specific property causes a zoning provision to impact disproportionately upon the property such that the strict application of the provision will result in peculiar and unusual practical difficulties to the owner of the property. Such variance is the minimum reasonably necessary to overcome the exceptional physical conditions. Such variances can be granted without substantial impairment to the intent, purpose, and integrity of the general plan or any area master plan, sector plan, or transit district development plan affecting the subject property, and the variance will not substantially impair the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, a variance may not be granted if the practical difficulty is self inflicted by the owner of the property. All of these criteria must apply. If the board determines that it needs to seek technical assistance from any other governmental agency, we shall do so. The approval of a variance is not a guarantee that further review will not be necessary by any other governmental authorities. Following the approval of a variance, a building permit must be obtained. Before any building permit will be processed by the county permits office, a copy of the board's written order must be presented. Approval of any variance is contingent upon development of the property in compliance with the board's approved site and elevation plan. On behalf of my council colleagues, I want to thank each each of you for being here today as we adopted our county's balanced $5.46 billion budget. I also want to thank every Prince Georgian who took the time to engage in our budget process. Your feedback has been invaluable in shaping a spending plan that best serves the needs and demands of our residents. Our budget shortfall this year was $171 million due to factors including including higher interest rates that have hurt home sales and reduced tax income, the ending of federal pandemic funds, rising inflation, the increasing impacts of climate change, and increasing state requirements for education funding. The budget this year and over the next few years is going to be the biggest challenge facing our county. I've compared it to managing a family budget, which many of you, I'm sure, can relate to. As parents, we can't ignore one child's needs over another's, and we're responsible for ensuring needs are met before we start looking at the family's wants. The key word is responsible, and it's a word that's been top of mind as we make financial decisions that at times can be difficult. The shortfall is a considerable obstacle, and it's crucial that we address it with a sense of urgency, creativity, and collaboration, just as we do in our own households. Families have to plan for the future and save for emergencies, and our county needs to also consider long term sustainability. We must continue to ask ourselves, is this a need or is this a want that's vital for us as we prepare to face challenging years ahead? And we're far from alone with other counties across the state, state and country also dealing with budget shortfalls. Despite our challenges, I'm proud to present to you a strategic spending plan that reflects our county's priorities and values and does not compromise on public safety and education. We've been committed to finding solutions that will address the shortfall while minimizing impacts on our citizens. Countless hours of hard work and collaboration have gotten us to this point. I want to personally offer my sincere gratitude to county Executive Angela Oserbrooks and her executive and budget teams, as well as council administrator Jennifer Jenkins and the legislative budget team, including budget director Josh Hamlin and county auditor Tequisa Green. Thank you to chief administrative officer Tara Jackson and budget director Stanley early for their thorough and diligent work. And of course, I want to acknowledge my colleagues on the dais for their teamwork and commitment. Vice chair and district nine council member Sydney Harrison District one council member Tom Durnoga District two councilmember Juanika Fisher, district three councilmember Eric Olson, district four council member Ingrid Watson, district six council member Walla Bligue, district seven council member Crystal Orietta, district eight council member Edward Burroughs and at large council members Mel Franklin and Calvin Hawkins. I'll share now some of our most significant budget enhancements. We've allocated an additional $200,000 to assist the Prince George's police department in filling vacancy agencies. Public safety is top of mind for our citizens and also for the council. We know that we need to hire more police and first responders and make the hiring process more efficient. The county executive's budget already provided funds for 100 new recruits for the police and for the fire departments. The council has negotiated with the executive branch to create an additional 50 firefighter positions. We have the 16th busiest fire department in the US, and it's imperative we support our hardworking women and men who protect our county each day. We've provided an additional $3 million in non departmental grants to help fund our nonprofits. Our nonprofits do indispensable work throughout the county. They depend on this grant money, and we're delivering on that for them. We've also added $100,000 for animal services and the Department of the Environment. Animal services workers and volunteers spoke up at our budget hearings, and while this money won't solve every issue, we want those dedicated employees to know that they were heard. We believe investing in animal services is investing in compassion and community safety. An additional $250,000 will fund a sickle cell machine and equipment at the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center. I had the opportunity to tour the Sickle cell unit recently to witness the incredible work happening there and this new state of the art machine will only enhance the quality of care. Out of 5000 sickle cell patients in Maryland, 40% are residents of Prince George's county. We've increased funding for warm night shelter support by on

An additional $250,000 will fund a sickle cell machine and equipment at the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center. I had the opportunity to tour the Sickle cell unit recently to witness the incredible work happening there and this new state of the art machine will only enhance the quality of care. Out of 5000 sickle cell patients in Maryland, 40% are residents of Prince George's county. We've increased funding for warm night shelter support by one point million dollars. We've increased funding for Paygo funding for the bus mass transit, access to capital project to support low no emissions buses and a bus facilities grant program. We've increased operating expenses to provide funding for the cannabis reinvestment and restoration fund by $2 million. We decreased the amount for the next phase of the Maryland National Capitol park and Planning Commission building by $10 million, which brings their final number to be below the original agreement from two years ago. So we thank chair Peter Shapiro for his efforts to get the price down to a better spot. There are a few disappointments. I do have the budget, but it all came down to what we need now versus what I wanted to see. Our library system did not get additional funding and those workers deserve more pay. My stepmom and mother in law were both librarians and I know the critical function they serve for our communities. We also need to hire more people to staff our libraries because we've been building new and bigger libraries, but without the people to staff them, they could end up as beautiful mules. There is a health clinic in the southern part of the county I was hoping to bring more resources to that is severely understaffed, which means fewer people would be tested for hiv. The fair election fund is so important to help people run for office but need financial help to do so, but we couldn't commit funding to it in this budget. As we look ahead, we must focus on building new revenue streams to ensure long term financial health and unburden our residents. Prince George's county has the most undeveloped land in the region and the choices we make about how to utilize this resource will shape the county's future and quality of life for generations to come. I'm committed to working with stakeholders, community members and local businesses to encourage smart growth and transit oriented development. We have much to look forward to with the completion of the Blue Line corridor, relocation of the FBI headquarters, and redevelopment of Hospital Hill. I want again to emphasize the collaboration and collective effort that got us here today. While these may be fiscally challenging times for our county, I know we can emerge stronger and more resilient than ever before. Thank you all for making Prince George's County a place where all proud to call home. And I would just like to remind my colleagues that on Monday it is Memorial Day and we will not be here on Tuesday at 10:00. We have a county council meeting at 10:00. We have committee of the whole at 1130. And a board of health at 130. Do we have district council at 945? I'm sure that is on June 4. Okay? Yes, ma'am. Sorry, I have too many things going on. Okay. Is there a motion to adjourn? All those in favor, please signify by raising your hand. We are adjourned.

There are also an estimated 6000 county residents who are deaf or hard of hearing, many of whom use American Sign language or other sign languages to communicate. Ayuta's interpreter bank boasts over 120 local legally trained professional interpreters continuously ensuring that every client's voice is heard, be it through in person or virtual interpretation.

Ayuta also provides translation of critical legal documents enabling immigrants in Prince George's county to fully engage with legal proceedings. Whether it's intake forms, client statements, or vital certificates, these translations are pivotal in the pursuit of justice.

I'm a senior volunteer at the shelter and the foster coordinator for Adopt a homeless animal rescue, one of the shelter's rescue partners who has saved almost 200 dogs in the past six years. Today, I stand before you to advocate for a cause that is not only close to my heart as a shelter volunteer and rescue partner, but vital for the well being of the community animal services. As we reflect on the past year, it is evident that our current resources are stretched to their limits and the need for additional funding has never been more urgent. I urge you to continue. Consider the pressing need for a north shelter. The statistics paint a grim future, a grim picture. Year over year, the length of stay for animals in our shelter before being euthanized has been drastically reduced. In 2023 alone, more dogs were euthanized than adopted, a distressing trend that cannot be ignored. Our kennels are consistently at capacity, our staff and volunteers are overwhelmed, and our rescue partners are exhausted. It's clear that we cannot simply rely on rescue, foster and adoption efforts to address the crisis. We need another facility to accommodate the growing numbers of animals in need of shelter and care. Currently, our shelter operates with 170 dog kennels with a goal of maintaining an 85% capacity rate. However, this model is simply not sustainable. As the demand for animal services continues to rise, we are at a breaking point where we are unable to adequately provide for animals in our care. With the recent health issues and shutdowns, it doesn't bode well for the dogs in the shelter. It is imperative that we take action now to address this crisis before it escalates further. I implore you to reconsider our budget allocation for animal services. We cannot afford to turn a blind eye to the suffering of our community's animals who are depend who depend on us. By investing in a north shelter, supporting provisional, aggressive policies and ensuring adequate resources for existing facilities, we can make a meaningful difference in the lives of animals in our community. Maybe the money can be used for year round internship training programs, something that is positive. Young people learn teamwork, communication and conflict resolution when interacting with their peers, and it boosts their self esteem. There is a great link between idle youth and troubled social behavior, including drug abuse and violence. When I asked a young person why things are like they are, I was told in this verbatim, if we had things to do, we wouldn't be having all this time to be killing each other. We have too much time here. Gangs and drugs keep us busy. That was verbatim, a lack of access to well resourced and well managed activities has intentionally or unintentionally influenced the issue of violence. The SPCA has donated a large play yard along with the smaller pens, but this is not enough.
Adequate enclosed outdoor space for the number of dogs at this facility and the smaller pens have rocks instead of grass, and the dogs don't generally like that.

At this time so that more staff can be present during the day, the animals are being left alone for 13 plus hours. This leaves well over 250 animals with no one to observe them if they happen to have a medical emergency.
I believe if there were more funding in the budget, the dog may have been able to get the medical care he needed, or at least perhaps a veterinary on call.
Lastly, I would like to have a fund set aside to help with low cost adoption so that we do not give these animals away for free.

chunks.text: fully staffed the next few months and we are a team of 31. I just want to put it out there because we heard the bigger numbers, but a lot of that was staff from the housing authority and staff from the RDA. And that is how the DHD budget looks like. And I want to be clear on the general funds on the 5.687 that you see. That includes also operating costs and staff salaries for the RDA. And then the balance of that is for Dhed staff. And the programs we use are entitlement funds and the Housing Investment Trust fund that you see there that support our projects. One small caveat that it is a detail, but I want to be clear is that for fiscal year 25, entitlement funds, the 9.8, that is an estimate we haven't heard yet from HUD. They announce a little later in the year. As soon as they do announce, we update you all on that and you will see all of this in our annual action plan. So core programs that our department launches and supports are production of affordable housing, both rental and home ownership, and also addressing critical repair needs of existing homeowners and of course our community development program. So how do we use our housing investment trust fund and home fund to support this? We issue a notice of funding availability once a year and we try to time this around the state's notice of funding availability and we outline the county priorities. So we make it very clear that supporting ToD projects around the blue line, purple line and all the transit stations are a priority prioritizing projects that are delivering some units that are below 50% of area median income, and of course, adhering to green standards and energy efficiency, among other things, and a little bit of how the whole process works, because that will help us clarify why there is money that hasn't been drawn, but also has has been committed. So we issue the NOFA and we review the projects that come on our way for a few things. One is, do they meet the county priorities? And two, are they leveraging other public and private resources? And based on that, we issue soft lois, at that point, that is not a commitment, that is just an intent to support, contingent to council approval and contingent to funding availability. But we have done the initial screening of making sure that those projects are our maiden county priorities. And this is a letter that the developers need in order to continue securing other public and private funding. So the next thing they do is they go through the state's routes and they seek tax credits and other subordinate debt, and they also go to the private market to secure the investment. And once they have done this, and there is proof that there is a commitment of all these other resources that are needed, because our resources are a small part, they're an important part. They're this last but four part, but they are not a part that on its own can deliver these projects. So they come back to us with proof that this project, that they have secured the other funding, and then we bring the projects in front of you, and then is when we actually do a firm commitment. So I know we're going to be coming in front of you next week for a couple of projects. And this is because we have already done all these steps and they have demonstrated that they have secured the other resources. And after you approve the project, they continue working with us, but also with all the other public and private lenders through this closing process. And sometimes it can be very quick and sometimes it can take a very long time, depending on how the other public and private lenders move and what questions they may have. And then construction starts, and it can last anywhere between 18 to 24 months. So this is to say that from step one to a delivery of the project, it can be a five, seven year period, maybe three if you are like it. But I have never seen that. So it is important, I think what I wanted to explain on this, that it is very important that we do have this predictable housing investment trust fund because it allows us to create this pipeline. So we are now at this point where the county has a pipeline of projects that can be supported from the state. And so what happened specifically, in fiscal year 24, we have currently 752 units under construction. So we will see those delivered in the next fiscal year. We completed 800 units and we have 925 units in the pipeline, meaning they should start construction anywhere between next month and the next few months, contingent to all the lenders coming together. And also this fiscal year, we have continued with the success of the riot first refusal program and have preserved an additional 492 units, NOAA units that are now committed, affordable units in the county. And that is to say that to date we have preserved over 1800 affordable housing units. And what is important, what we always want to drive home with the right of first refusal program, is that this is really preserving home for the workforce, like looking at the income of people who are actually able to stay in their homes. And as we are doing this program, we're also looking at the needs of the property. So we are addressing deferred maintenance and capital improvements, needs that are needed through our tools, through our pilots and our investments. And then on the homeownership side, we have our pathway to purchase that. We're working very closely with the RDA. We did make changes last year that we talked about. We increased the contribution to 25,000 on our end, and we have seen a spike in the activity because of that. But we are monitoring very closely because with the interest rates, the market is volatile and what happens on that. And one of the things, feedback we've heard is that typically when you are in one of those homes that are accessible to a first time home buyer and you are looking to graduate to your bigger home, your first home becomes available. But now with the increased interest rates, p

So we are addressing deferred maintenance and capital improvements, needs that are needed through our tools, through our pilots and our investments. And then on the homeownership side, we have our pathway to purchase that. We're working very closely with the RDA. We did make changes last year that we talked about. We increased the contribution to 25,000 on our end, and we have seen a spike in the activity because of that. But we are monitoring very closely because with the interest rates, the market is volatile and what happens on that. And one of the things, feedback we've heard is that typically when you are in one of those homes that are accessible to a first time home buyer and you are looking to graduate to your bigger home, your first home becomes available. But now with the increased interest rates, people are not looking at this bigger opportunity. So there is less inventory of houses that could meet the first home buyers needs. So we're looking closely on what other changes we may need to, and we're working closely with the state on that. The hrap and the hop program are ongoing programs. Great success. The Hop program is the program that because of your support, we were able to launch 18 months ago, approximately with ARPA funds. And now we continue funding into housing investment trust fund. So we work with heap and habitat in these efforts. And one thing we started last year, and I think that was, again, feedback both from the council and the administration, we launched home maintenance workshops, which are now mandatory for everybody who takes advantage of our programs. But they are also open to everybody, so they happen every two months. It's a partnership between hip and Habitat, and they cover a series of home maintenance needs. Also, we launched last year a faith based initiative, and through a big RFP process we are now working through enterprise with seven houses of worship in helping them think through how they can develop their land to affordable home ownership. So we're helping them with technical assistance, with due diligence, so they can graduate to the level where they are ready to bring in front of us projects. And like the previous years, we update our dashboard now quarterly. So after this legislative session, we will update it again to show what projects we have in the pipeline. So real time, anytime someone wants to see what has been completed, what is under construction, this is available in our dashboard. And for projects in the pipeline, we explicitly include only projects that have received council approval because at that point there is a firm commitment and we know that they are going to be moving to closing community development. I think it was mentioned earlier. So the great news is that this year we already met our timeliness test ahead of time, so we're waiting for Huds confirmation on May 2. It is because of a lot of work that happened on our end. We did work very closely, closely with some organizations that had a hard time delivering and providing biweekly technical assistance, and we also had a lot of support from the council in reprogramming. So I want to thank you very much for your partnership in addressing something that has been an ongoing issue. But because of all of these things, we are in a position to actually be deploying funds. So that is, at the end of the day, the good news, and that is about Iraq. So besides the big organizational chart that you saw about our team, we have been running a parallel branch of our ERAP team that includes temporary staff and also part time DHD staff. So we have twelve full time temporary staff getting paid from IRAP admin, and some of our team continues to do double duty in terms of compliance accounting. There are certain things we cannot add outsourced for different purposes. So where we are today is that era one has been fully deployed. And as you saw probably in the news, we did reopen the portal a few weeks ago and we're getting ready to announce that we're going to be closing it again. Because right now all the applications that we have received are enough to pretty much take away that funding, but for a couple of million dollars that we are able to redirect from the administrative costs to direct payment. So even after we fully close the portal for everybody, we will be able to take applications in for people facing evictions, prioritizing those that are below 50%, and that was because of the cost savings on the administrative costs. So we will continue in fiscal year 24 to selectively provide that assistance. A couple of other things that we did this year and we're going to intensify next year, is we are revamping our loan servicing and compliance teams, both by adding staff and also creating new policies and procedures. And this is because, as you saw, there is a big pipeline of projects that we didn't have before. So we see our responsibility as being stewards of the public resources in the long run, both on the compliance side but also on the repayment side. So these are new functions within the department that are getting intensified and you will hear much more about this the next few months. We did launch our next five year consolidated plan effort. This is something we have to do every five years. And you see then the annual plans coming in front of you. So there will be a lot of market analysis and data analysis, but also a lot of community input in terms of bringing this plan forward. And we will be in front of you multiple times, but eventually in Q one of 25 in submitting that plan. So this is what I had. So I'm happy to take more questions. Thank you so much. Questions for Miss Napoleon. Yes, Miss Ivy, back to erap. Okay. So we do get calls from people who still need help. And you know, what you're saying is really important that sometimes you help people and they still aren't going to be able to afford the place long term. And of course, the county would have to do things differently and of course, cost a lot more to help everybody who is having problems with affordability. So I'm wondering, what can we do for people? I mean, there's a constituent that I have, he's been contacting us constantly about needing help. He's a single dad. He's got three kids. He's got a lot of problems. And we have helped him. We've helped him. Bladensburg's helped him, like, everybody who we could tap into has helped him. But he's reached a point where he's kind of run out of funds and he's run out of organizations that are willing to keep putting money into what you start to feel like as a black hole. He's not going to be able to afford that apartment. So what can we do for people like that to help them move into something that is less expensive? So, yeah, that would be. So this is the $1 million question. And I have a 5ft answer for you and a 10,000ft answer for you. The 5ft answer is that we can rehouse them. IRAP allows us to rehouse. So a lot of times we look at someone's situation and when it's evident. Right. So we cannot force people to move if that is their choice and that is what they're working with their landlord. Right. So now the thing is we can, we provide security deposit and up to three months for housing. So you should stay still, send them our way. We are still having the call center and we still look at each case uniquely. Thank you. That's really helpful. And just generally speaking, what is the situation that you're finding with people kind of post Covid? We see all kinds of things. Some people have moved to new jobs and actually are not even income eligible anymore, which, but they are also not able to avoid to pay rent. And that really tells you of what housing crisis we have. And that is not a unique conversation in Prince George's County. I do want to put that in perspective because we are in regional meetings and national calls. What we see here, we see it everywhere in the housing and I think the housing supply, unless we, we really meaningfully address housing supply for people of all incomes, we will never move beyond that nationally. And what would you say the numbers are that we should be shooting for in Prince George's county if we're supposed to make a difference so that people can afford where they live? We're following the regional numbers. I think there was a huge discussion very recently with urban and hunt. So the regional numbers that the council of Governments has put out there about the housing in the region are a roadmap because they have taken into account growth patterns that all the planning departments in all jurisdictions have provided. And so there are the 19,000 by 2030 affordable units. And that's why we are having our dashboard and trying to create a robust pipeline and also complete. And are we considering how many of those units should be in multifamily and how many should be single family and how many should be townhomes or whatever? Yeah, we haven't come down to making that specific determination as a department because that's a bigger land use decision. But everybody in the region who has been able to make a lot of progress towards affordable housing production goals has intensified also their multifamily production. Because these are a lot of units, it's impossible to deliver this many units, just a single homes or just as townhouses. But it is important to continue building our inventory of affordable home ownership. Right. Because we want to have options. So, but we haven't come down to say this many of that and this of that. Okay, I'll let somebody else ask questions, but I still have some. Okay. Wasn't an number of regional housing units 75,000 or 50,000? Not by 2030, but over the next period of time. How much? 75% of which would be afforded regionally because CoG put out numbers. Maybe Mister Berlaz remembers this because we've had presentations. It was a very large number that they wanted regionally. They wanted 75% of them at high capacity rail stations, which I don't think we're, you know, I don't think we're being successful on our share, Mister Olsen. It was just a lens all the way from Loudoun county down to every county in this jurisdiction. The regional goal from council of governments was like 329,000. I know it's a lot, and I would say some jurisdictions are meeting that and actually exceeding their targets. And we are making significant progress, but we haven't met it yet.
