That are the development fees that go into the legislation that you all passed. That was 20% and definitely no less than 10 million per year. So. But that's based on how many houses are built, obviously, or how many units are sold. Are sold. Right. Okay. All right. And that's. Sorry. 20% is what? 20% taxes annually. 20% of the recordation taxes go into the trust fund. Okay. With a floor of 10 million. So if there was a year where for some reason we haven't seen that yet, unless MB has seen it yet, but it's tippering over there. Okay. It's, you know, I think it's. It's hard to say, but we probably will be around 10 million this coming year. Just because it's dipping, because sales, the number of units available is declined, but it will still be a 10 million. Okay. And so that was, that was increased at some point recently, recent years. That was the action we didn't have prior to that. It was an allocation from the general fund. And what this did is created a percentage of a certain funding source that would go to the housing trust fund. And that was significantly more than we had been able to do most years in the journal fund. But it comes out of the recordation tax. So it's. There's not a separate fee for this that comes just directly out of the tax? Yes. Okay. Okay. That's helpful to know. Okay, thank you very much. I appreciate it. Mister Hawkins. And then Mister Franklin. Good morning to my favorite. As of late, he says that every time I know Madam chair, you bust me out. She knows. She knows. She knows. And I see Shakinda Skinner on behalf of the county's ex office sitting down there. And we receive requests to send. Even with this new program the county council administration is setting up that when we get calls regarding emergency assistance with rental properties or anything that we need to send it through 311, do you have, and I should have given this question to our staff to put in the list to ask you, but since I didn't, I'll ask you now. Do you have the number of calls for fiscal year? For the fiscal year that came from? Three. One. One. And what's the rate of closure resolution of those? We don't. I'll get back to you. Because we have our own line, the hotline for IRAP. We don't get a lot of calls from 311. I know we get all kinds of emails through our PIA request and our. We're trying to respond to those within 24 hours when it's not us and direct them to the right agency. But we don't have 311 people coming our way because we have our own hotline. Okay. Thank you, Mister Franklin. Thank you, mister chair. Thank you, DACC and all that you do wanted to ask on the rental assistance. So the money that you have. Let me back up. No, it's open. It's been open for a few weeks. And we are getting. And we have gotten thousands of households who have applied. We are getting ready to send out an announcement that we will be reclosing that. But we will give people a few, at least a week of a notice. And those applications that we currently have will absorb most of the funding we currently have available. But we are redirecting a couple of million dollars from admin to direct payments. So we will continue helping people after we close that are below 50% and are facing eviction until the funds are fully deployed. So this was there not a period where the program was closed? Does that recall the program being closed for some period of time? The program never closed completely. It closed for all kinds of applications, but we always took applications for people that had judgments and reads. So we had the process that through an access code, we were allowing people facing evictions to apply. But we saw that this was inhibiting progress and it was creating confusion of if people should or should not apply. That's why we went ahead and changed the administrative procedure. But we have not been in a place where we say that we don't take applications so far. Okay. I didn't. I didn't know that. That was not my understanding also. So for this funding, do you have to have a situation related to Covid, or. This can be just anybody who needs rental assistance. So the statutory requirement says that you have to have a financial hardship that occurred during COVID And Covid starts in March 10, I believe, of 2020. And we haven't closed that timeline. Treasury hasn't said that the date has ended. The date ends on September of 2025. So. But you have to have any financial hardship, specifically financial habit, that occurred during that period. So if you have things that occurred five years ago and this is what you carry through, you don't qualify for that. So the hardship related to Covid, even now, you could have a hardship and still qualify. Yeah. If you lost your job, like two months ago and something happened, is due during that period where the funding is still available. Okay. And maybe everybody knew about this. I didn't know anybody. So thank you for that information. Thank you. And that's important. We do take applications through our community partners who are helping us in the court system, because there is a lot of nuance about the program that people need to know and make sure they take advantage.

insights.observation: The new zoning ordinance restricts the use of planned development zones, which are meant to encourage innovative and high-quality developers, especially for properties that were formerly zoned RA. This limits the flexibility and the creativity of projects in the AR zone and reduces the opportunity to preserve environmental and cultural features.

The ordinance categorized the AR zone as a rural and agricultural base zone, which makes it ineligible for residential plan development zoning, even though it allows large lot residential developments.

The genesis of this is that the new zoning ordinance was intended to modernize the zoning code to improve the county's land use goals, policies, and objectives, not to upend the carefully considered decisions of county leadership embodied in the existing master plan.
It creates obstacles to high-end quality projects that are not only desirable but necessary to achieve the master plan and general plan goals, as well as other county projects and policies.

Before you start, we're going to take the public comments. You'll have three minutes to speak to all the amendments. But it's going to be a soft three minutes. And I'm not going to throw you out when the bell goes off. But we don't want to do we have so many amendments. If we give you three minutes an amendment, we're going to be here a long, long time. So do your best within the three plus minutes that we give you. So, Miss Rogers, if you would address whatever you'd like to address. Thank you. And I will be quick chair. So, Andrew Rogers, deputy CEO for economic development. When I was before the committee the last time on this, I think I brought up three issues, two of which have been adequately addressed in these amendments by the planning department. One regarding some additional protections that we wanted to see for larger projects. Sort of going through their planning process. And the, I think existing language talked about changes allowed at 10% or 30,000 sqft, whichever is less. And we wanted to see that go to whichever is greater, in order to provide some protection for larger projects that may take a longer time to get through their developments. So we're happy to see that change. Happy to see a change which I think had been talked about on the council for a while regarding some extended period for uses to go dark in projects extending from 180 days to three years in the changes that we see now. So we're happy to see that. And the only lingering concern which we expressed in the last hearing is about the townhomes in CGO zones outside of the beltway. I think, as I indicated last time, I would like to see maybe a broader boundary for that. If we were going to consider something. I don't think that the beltway is the right boundary. There are lots of established communities that are rightfully still growing that are sort of in right outside the beltway. And so for that, I think we would still want to see a different boundary than the beltway for that particular change. That concludes my. Thank you Miss Rogers. With that we'll go to the signup sheet and we will start with Mister Bracey, Earl Bracey. We're going to down this way at the end. And after Mister Bracey, Mister Tedesco and Miss Gingold, if you would come towards the front so that. Good morning council. My name is Bracey, I'm representing the Lincoln Vista Civic association. My question is relative. Each one of you ran for office to make PG a better county and community. And on that is what you ran on. So my question is this proposed bill extension, is it for the betterment of PG county constituents or for builders? And is it fair and equitable? The proposed bill gave then and you five years to make corrections. I would suggest you let them utilize the new as written and make the corrections moving forward. Or are you content on letting them drive your decision for their benefit, not on what you promised when you ran? Thank you. Thank you. Mister Gracey, Mister Tedesco and Miss Gingold, come towards the front and then Mister Haller. Is Mister Haller here? I think he's on his way. He was in planning board. Mister chair. Too bad. Just kidding. Mister Chairman, madam vice chair, members of the committee and council members. Good. Almost afternoon. For the record, Matthew Tedesco with a law firm of McNaM. I want to thank Mister chairman for his leniency. In the three minutes I will be very brief. I may go a minute over, but I will be succinct. First and foremost, I want to thank Director hall and the planning department and staff and express our gratitude for the ability to provide input and suggestive edits that were considered by the drafters of CB 15. This deals with Mister Dunoga's transitional provisions amendment. While not all of our suggestions have been advanced in the amendment sheet before the committee this morning, we recognize that the current amendments are a huge step in the road right direction. With that being said, I do need to highlight one amendment that is not included that we wish to raise for consideration by the committee, and it deals with section 20 717 oh seven, and that can be found on page nine, line 17 of your amendment sheet for the transition provisions. We would respectfully request that the reference on line 17 to April 1, 2022 be deleted and in its place, insert the words quote after the expiration of any grandfathering provisions in sections 20 717, oh four a and D. Close quote this edit will ensure that the grandfathering provided in sections 20 717, oh four a and d in the amendment sheet is not disturbed, at least prior to the expiration of said grandfathering vis a future sectional map amendment by this council. Although we wish to further reserve the right to be able to provide additional suggestions to further improve upon the transition provisions, we again appreciate everyone's consideration and understanding on the desire to collectively ensure that we create a successful development review process for the county and move our zoning ordinance to the 21st century. I look forward to continued and future opportunities to coordinate with staff and all stakeholders. Turning to Mister Franklin's amendment, I would we are in support of this amendment for all the reasons articulated by the zoning hearing examiner and the planning board when they opposed CB 320 23 last year. Although we wish to further reserve the right to be able to provide additional suggestions to further improve upon the transition provisions, we again appreciate everyone's consideration and understanding on the desire to collectively ensure that we create a successful development review process for the county and move our zoning ordinance to the 21st century. I look forward to continued and future opportunities to coordinate with staff and all stakeholders. Turning to Mister Franklin's amendment, I would we are in support of this amendment for all the reasons articulated by the zoning hearing examiner and the planning board when they opposed CB 320 23 last year. The current provisions of section 27 3604 e one c and 27 3605 e six create confusion, irreconcilable conflicts between planning and zoning, between zoning, the zoning warrants and the subdivision regulations, and with case law, all of which create uncertainty and the inability to uniformly administer the county code. As the hearing examiner stated in opposition to CB 320 23, quote planning involves setting future goals at a point static in time that furthers the police powers, while zoning must consider in real time whether a particular zone or use should be granted. The current language in these sections ties these two concepts, planning and zoning closer, ignoring the fact that they are not synonymous. It is impossible to implement master plans or administer the zoning warrants when these documents and the zones created with the CMA conflict with each other. Turning to the amendment regarding the CGO zone. We would oppose that amendment given the current housing crisis that the county is facing being behind the needs for housing as reported by the Washington Post, including the county budget deficits that will grow larger due to the lost revenue from the lack of recreation and transfer taxes, the county should be encouraging housing opportunities and not discouraging them by imposing lengthy, expensive entitlement obligations. And finally, Mister chairman, regarding Mister Harrison's amendment for the ability to simply request or an application to to rezone to the RPD zone in the AR zone. We would support that for the reasons that Mister Harrison articulated this morning. Thank you so much for your consideration. Thank you. Mister Tedesco, Janet Gingold then Mister Gibbs, good morning. My name is Janet Gingold and I'm speaking today on behalf of the Prince Georgia Sierra Club. We need a zoning ordinance that works for the people by furthering the goals of the zoning Rewrite Plan 2035 and the Climate Action Plan. We're counting on you to strengthen the guardrails that empower the council to reject proposals for haphazard development that causes environmental degradation and harms the quality of life for future principles. Georgians, please reject the amendment of language regarding conformance with the planning documents. Planning is necessary to ensure that equitable and sustainable use of limited resources occurs. Plans aren't perfect and many of our planning documents need to be updated. However, even the best possible plans won't help us meet our community's needs if development doesn't conform with the plans. Please fortify a system that heeds the expertise of planners working in the interests of the people. The speculations of individual developers should not determine what we build and where we build it. The public counts on the district council to say no to unwise development, and the council needs guardrails that allow and require it to say no regarding residential development in CGO zones. Yes, we need more housing for our growing population. However, for growth that puts less stress on the county budget and reduces vehicle miles traveled, we need housing development to occur in parts of the county that already have access to public transit and public infrastructure. Please reject the proposed amendments that would greenlight continued car development sprawl by allowing townhouse developments in CGO zones outside the beltway. Townhouses or multifamily housing should be built outside the beltway if and only if they are in a planned development zone designed to decrease vehicle miles traveled and improve climate. Climate resilience please strengthen the whole process for planned development zones by adding criteria for public benefits that include reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving climate resilience regarding data centers in the ag zone zone. Given our dependence on data, data centers have to go somewhere. In siting these facilities, decision makers need to consider how they add to the cumulative environmental impacts experienced by already overburdened populations and how to mitigate potential impacts. The requirement for a detailed site plan does not go far enough to protect the county's rural land and to ensure adequate protection from air pollution and noise. Setbacks should be larger both for residences and for places of worship. Requirements should include power backup with on site batteries or generators with tier four or greater emissions controls to offset power taken from the grid. On site solar installations should be required. Measures for noise mitigation and reduction of light pollution should also be required. If requirements include specifications and locations for backup generators, battery energy storage systems and solar energy installations, decision makers will be better able to assess potential impacts and mitigating factors prior to approving permits. That's all I have for today for this one. Thank you. Thank you. Four minutes. Not bad. Mister Gibbs, Mister Antonetti. Mister Horne. Yes. Good morning. And I would echo his recommendation for the amendment language and then I would like to address amendment one. A dealing with data centers in the AG zone. I represent Arclight. They are now the owners of Keys Energy center. I assisted in the approval process for Keys Energy center. They have a 167 acre parcel and brandywine. They have an arrangement in place if they can get a text amendment to permit this use in the Ag zone to have a data center developed there. And when we did, the property is very irregular in shape so it's difficult to site buildings. And so we offered some language for an amendment that would allow the ship use in the AG zone. And we proffered detailed site plan approval. Every other zoning classification that allows a data center doesn't have any requirement for a detailed site plan. So the setbacks, the way the building looks, and by the way, these buildings are quite attractive can all be determined at the detailed site plan stage. We will satisfy that. You know, people aren't being given a right here. They got the CGO zone. It permitted those residential uses in all locations. And those folks who have made plans and developed plans to go forward with uses that were permitted and now see that they might be taken away or made it very difficult to achieve are placed in a severe disadvantage. So thank you very much for your time and I appreciate your indulgence in allowing me to go over. Thank you. Mister Gibbs, Mister Antonetti, Mister Horne and Kathy Bartolomeo. Good afternoon. That amendment is before you today and with Mister Dasko's amendment, which I do support. I am supportive of that revised transitional amendment package, and we thank you and thank the staff for their consideration and opportunity to work together collaboratively. I am in support of revisions to the master plan, compliance for special exceptions and detailed site plans proposed by Mister Franklin. You have heard before. It is notable that out of the 43 master sector plans in the county, I believe that only two have been updated since the effective date of the new zoning ordinance, and there's only been one sectional map amendment, soon to be two. There is potential for many conflicts between planning and zoning across the entire county because of how the current law is written. And the amendment for you is necessary to allow for quality and appropriate development to move forward. In the alternative, I think we should look to expedite master plan and sector plan revisions and to approve corresponding sectional map amendment changes to better align development priorities. I think that's a better way to handle it in the future and future omnibus bills. I would ask that consideration be given to that process and the efficiency of that process. I do support the amendment by Vice chair Harrison to allow the ability of certain Ar zone properties to apply for the RPD zone if they are in the established communities designation. The general plan I would respectfully request that this be expanded to properties in the Ag zone that also ag zone that are in the established communities area. In particular, this could greatly assist the redevelopment of the Glendale Hospital site, which is in the Ag zone, in the established communities, and has gone through numerous amounts of community input and planning on the public side. And it would be the opportunity to move that project forward and to make it a reality for the CGO zones. As others have testified, we do oppose the CGO amendment impacting the ability to build towns and multifamily and land outside the beltway. It's still a drastic policy change which contradicts the mixed use purposes of the CGO zone. The general plan does allow development such as this outside the Beltway, and so do certain master plans. A special exception is a very heavily heavy procedure, an expensive procedure which can take twelve to 18 months for approval, and we feel that that is excessive in light of the county's need for additional housing. In short, I am supportive of the amendments here today to the transitional provisions, the master plan conformance requirements, and due respect, the request that the AG zone be added to Mister Harrison's amendment, if that is the will of the body. I do remain opposed to the CGO revisions for the reasons stated. I do look forward over the next several years working with the planning department and the council on future omnibus this legislation that will help lead us to a zoning ordinance that will deliver quality development and economic growth that is vital for Prince George's county. And I thank you for your time today. Thank you Mister Horn, Mister Bartimaeo and Mister Patel, I guess good afternoon now. Committee chair Dunoga, councilor chair Ivey, members of the PHED committee and of the council. My name is Arthur Horne from the law Office of Shipyard Horn, here representing several property owners potentially impacted by CB 15 and some of the proposed amendments here today. As I previously done, I'm testifying today to support the majority of amendments proposed here today concerning the transitional provision provisions and the master plans. My testimony here will mirror that concerning CB 27 which is here today, and I'm in support of that proposed amendments. Concerning the transitional provisions, I'd like to thank chair Ivey and park and planning staff for dillingy working on these transitional provisions revisions that are necessary for the continuing smooth transition into the new use of the use of the new ordinance. I would also like to support and thank council member Franklin for his amendment concerning revisions to the master plan consistency with special exceptions and detailed site plans. These revisions are crucial given the county's 43 existing master plans, which everyone admits are mostly outdated. And as you heard here in previous testimony, since the countywide map amendment on April 1, 2022 became effective, there's only been two approved master plans and one SMA. The council has rezoned thousands of acres of property comprehensively and via piecemeal applications, and the property owners must be able to develop their property in a manner consistent with those existing zones. Otherwise, the zoning of person's property means nothing if there's a mandatory requirement for master plan consistency when in those many cases, the master plan and the land use recommendation now no longer agree with the proposed zoning that exists. The language proposed by councilmember Franklin is consistent with the prior zoning ordinance requiring special subject uses must be substantially, must not substantially impair the integrity and validity of the master plan or in the absence of that, an area master plan or general plan. I also would like to support councilmember Harrison's proposed amendment concerning the residential plan development zones to include LMX, LCD and AR, especially the AR. Thank you for your time and consideration. Thank you Mister Horn, Miss Bartolomeo, followed by Mister Patel and then Sue Ellen Ferguson. Hi, Kathy Bartolomeo from Greenville. The county has already has allowed developers nearly five and a half years to adapt and prepare for the new ordinance. An extension for more time is unwarranted. More time with two sets of rules creates confusion. Many development projects have already adapted and worked with the new ordinance. Plus, a new ordinance will help with development to be near our infrastructure, saving the county money. We're already paying for many hours of overtime. In 2022, county firefighters reported 40,000 hours of maintenance, mandatory overtime. We also have many hours of overtime for the police and the county is paying more for this. We do not need an additional two year extension for using the old ordinance. And as for discouraging housing development, no one's doing that. We just need smart development in 2024. April, just a week and a half ago, NOAA scientists are investigating the possibility that climate change is causing wetlands to give off increasing methane emissions in a feedback loop and the article is titled no sign of greenhouse gases increases slowing in 2023 and much of PG county, as you know, is wetlands. How are you going to offset the greenhouse gases from the 160 generators? Need to run weekly. Data centers should not be placed on agricultural land or green zones. We're going to need these spaces. We also need to protect residents from the centers noise, lights and impacts of air pollution caused by the diesel energy generators. How will we offset the greenhouse gas created must be planned into these centers. Communities must have input regarding data centers location. And as far as Mister Gibbs saying, seeing the buildings, that is not the problem. It's the noise and the pollution and the lights. Will data centers pay their full share of taxes? Or will this add to more burden to our challenging budget? And will the electric grid, how will that priority be set? Will it be fair? Labor conditions in place? What about the CPCN? Certificate of public convenience and necessity. So please oppose an extension to these timelines. Thank you. Thank you. Where was I? Mister Patel. Then Miss Ferguson. And then Mister Haller. Good afternoon. Thank you, council, for the opportunity to speak here, representing the BAPS hindu temple in Beltsville. We've been at this property for 25 years now, and I'd want to say that we're in support of amendment two. When it comes to data centers in rr zones and being at least or 500ft from the dwelling. There is two main reasons for this, and there's science behind it and reality. The first, which some of us have addressed here, the environmental impact. There's been studies done in the recent years to show, you know, stating even Portland State University did a study about eight years ago on the nitrogen dioxide emissions from these data centers. And the closest, you know, they measured was 300 meters, and as far as 3000 meters of nitrogen dioxide emissions, as well as, you know, 2.5 micrometer particulate matter. Right, as we have seen on masks, you know, PM 2.5 that is emitted by these data centers. And the second issue is noise. And no matter how much dampening the reality is, it creates more than 60 decibels of noise just to run the h vac units, the fans and the generators. And at the lowest it can be 48 decibels. And that low humming wave, actually, our brain's not able to ignore it the way it's set up. There's a science behind it. And so we're in support for amendment too. We've been here for 25 years. I have been here through my youth for the last 20 years, and I've also spent some of my life in northern Virginia, where I've seen enough data centers envelop and proliferate across the board right next to housing developments, and have experienced it personally. And so I thank you for the opportunity to speak today and would like to say that, you know, the 500ft is probably a minimum, if not much more, based on what science says. Thank you for your opportunity and consideration. Thank you. Mister Pat

I've been in special exception hearings where the developer's consultant made assertions about whether or not the special exception would have a greater impact at this particular location than other ones in the county. And their consultant couldn't even identify other rr zones in the county in our particular case. So basically they were just making an assertion with no data, no analysis. And where are those kinds of malfeasance going to be held accountable? I mean, I see nothing that deals with that in the. In the current legislation. And then what protections are there for communities that are, and who has liability for communities that are impacted by flooding that's caused by new development? I mean, this is going to be getting only worse with climate change. And where is that taken into account? Who pays when somebody suffers damage? And how are we going to protect our agricultural land if we keep eating it? It's just like moths attacking a wool code. We're nibbling away at it here and there and everywhere. If you look at the satellite images of the county over the years, you can see the dramatic changes that have taken place, the loss of forest cover, the loss of agricultural land, the loss of green space. What impact is that having on our lives? I mean, what's the value of a master plan if it can be overridden by zoning text amendments. And just to look at some of the assertions about the effort to constrain development of housing in the CGO zone, to hear the developers talk about it, you're banning multifamily housing outside the beltway. chunks.text: Good morning. It is 937. Welcome to government Operations and Fiscal Policy Committee. Today is May 2. Madam Clerk, please call the roll. Madam Chair Watson? Present. Vice Chair Harrison. Madam Clerk? Present. Councilmember Oriada? Here. Councilmember Durnoga? Present, present or present. Thank you. And I know Councilmember Franklin will be absent today, so greetings and welcome. On today's agenda, we have six budget work sessions to review on the proposed fiscal year 2025 budget. So we'll begin with the licensed commissioners, followed by the Office of Central Services, Office of Finance, OHRM and the Revenue authority. And finally, OMB colleagues, keep in mind that today is not the last time we will have to address any questions to the agencies. So we will be working with the administration to schedule a time in September when at least two of the agencies can return for briefings. We have an ambitious agenda today, so everyone will need to be as efficient as possible with time. So we will get started with licensed commissioners. Mister Terrence shepherd, director. And our analyst today is Andrew Stover. I've turned to Mister Stover. Thank you, madam chair. Mister Vice chair, members of the committee, my name is Andrew Stover and I'm a policy analyst for the legislative Budget and policy office. As you said, I know we've got a lot on the agenda today, so my goal with these is to try and present to you what we feel is the most important information highlight and I will be happy to answer any questions or anything that anybody has if you want to know more information about the report. So, getting into the budget for Board of Licensed commissioners, this budget is proposed at $2 million, which is just slightly below the FY 2024 level of $16.7 thousand, $0.7 thousand below, or 0.8%. And what we see is that this budget increases in operating costs, technology costs and salary adjustments, but is offset by a decrease in fringe benefit funding. You can look at the expenditures and show that for compensation is proposed at about 1.3 million, which is a decrease of 3.6 thousand. And they do have two additional part time staff positions that they are still looking for. So two vacancies in that. But besides that, staffing has not experienced a lot of change. On page three you can see the revenues, a breakdown of what kind of money they're getting. It's mainly from fees and the license fees. And so for the breakdown of revenue collected from the issuing of fines, you can look at question ten of the first round responses. And for a breakdown of costs that they're charging for licenses, you can take a look at question eleven of the first round responses. Operating expenses are proposed at $288,000. The biggest line items are office automation, general and administrative contracts, and mileage reimbursements. The biggest increase that we saw was for an interpreter for $20,000 and also an increase for $11,300 for mileage reimbursement. When it comes to information technology, they do have some projects going on. There is a $500,000 project that they've got in the OIT budget that is a software that works on increasing the productivity of their issuing licenses. Finally, when it comes to workload and key points, you can find a map of the locations that have alcohol permits on attachment two of the first round responses, and you can see a breakdown on page four of the report of how many there are by county. And finally, I just wanted to say that the board continues to run its underage compliance checks to make sure that licensees are following the law and not serving to minors. That continues to be something that they're doing. And as of March 2024, sale to a minor made up 21 out of 58 violations adjudicated. That concludes my report on the board of licensed commissioners. Thank you. Thank you. Mister Stover, Mister early, did you have anything to add? I have nothing to add at this time. Thank you. Thank you. All right, I'll now turn to Mister shepherd. Thank you for being here. Thank you Madam chair and vice chair and council members. chunks.text: shepherd. Thank you for being here. Thank you Madam chair and vice chair and council members. The mission of the Prince George County Board of Licensed Commissioners is to enforce the alcoholic beverage laws of the state of Maryland and to promote the education of licensees and the public while encouraging socially responsible consumption of alcoholic beverages. The BLC has oversight and management of approximately 630 licensed establishments in Prince George's county. The agency currently consists of twelve inspectors, three full time inspection supervisors, and nine part time inspectors. The administrative staff is comprised of five full time employees. The board is required to hold a minimum of two hearings per month, one daytime hearing where new licenses are issued, and during the daytime hearing. The board also handles substitution of corporate officers and transfers. Evening hearings consist of violations, endorsements such as delivery permits, special entertainment permits, and other matters. The administrative staff is responsible for processing all new application renewals and other administrative matters. They also schedule our hearings and collect all fees that are owed to the board. And the administrative staff is actively involved in outreach and just about the inspection staff. They are responsible for examining every licensee on a scheduled basis. The inspection staff conducts over 5700 routine inspections in the calendar year. Additional inspection consists of underage enforcement, entertainment inspection, as well as focused inspections. Here are some inspection highlights. The BLC has conducted underage compliance checks at locations that hold entertainment permits. 298 underage checks were completed. This operation resulted in 100% refusal of a licensees allowing underage individuals into their premises during restricted hours. The BOLC conducted 60 underage compliance checks so far this year at license establishments. This resulted in 30 underage violations, and this constitutes 50% of all licensees refusing to sell to underage individuals. During our biannual entertainment blitz, our inspectors conducted 45 entertainment enforcement operations. These operations resulted in zero entertainment violations. The inspection staff also conducts outreach through CMAS meetings, community meetings, and numerous workgroups with elected officials and community members. That's pretty much it. As an overview of what we do, I'm here to answer any questions that you may have about our operations or about our budget or anything that you may want to know more about. Thank you. Before we move on to questions, could you introduce your team that you brought with you today? Absolutely. Thank you. Next to me is Patti Bell. She's my budget analyst. So that will be going into effect on July 1 of this year. Okay. Thank you. Thank you very much, Councilmember Oriada. Thank you. Just a few questions. So anything that we see that we think that they need more, you know, they need more training, we'll detail that as a focus inspection. In addition to that, just if we notice anything in the field, for instance, trash at our liquor stores, we'll detail our inspectors to do focus inspections during that time frame. Based on what we're reading here, it's fair to say that when a licensee comes before the board, they are usually clean up their act after the first or second violation. We have not got to the point where we've had to suspend or revoke a license. The major problem that we see is with people having entertainment violations. And entertainment is obviously people that have things like DJ's, Karaoke's and bands and things of that nature. After 09:00 those are usually the major violations that we see. But typically what the board decides to do is they'll just revoke or suspend not the liquor license, but the entertainment permit. And usually if a location has entertainment and that entertainment permit is restricted or revoked, you know, like I said, they clean up their act very, very shortly thereafter. Thank you. You're welcome. Thank you. Mister Dunoga, did you have any questions? No, thank you. All right. Thank you very much. I just had a question regarding community outreach. You mentioned that your office does that, so I just wanted to find out in what how do you do that and where do you go and what does that entail. So we host at least two to three. I'm sorry. We participate in the Seamast meetings, which is at the University of Maryland. Their police department holds a county multi agency services team where they bring community members in from College park and they talk about alcohol related issues as well as other issues. So that's one of the things that we do. We do that at least four to five times a year, if not more. And also we attend numerous community meetings where we're requested to attend things of that nature, where we request that we generally show up. That's pretty much it. All right, I think you have another question. I'm sorry. Okay, Kathy, your question made me have a follow up question because I did see that point in the budget book where it talked about community meetings attended. So is it fair to say because you talked about the one in college park that's maybe like four times, but it only has eight listed in total. In total. Is that just because a lot of communities aren't requesting you guys to attend to meetings? It just depends on what's going on in the community. If someone's having a lot of problems with noise complaints in a particular community as it relates to establishments, then if we're requested to come. We will, but we also do community work groups. One of the community work groups that we recently did within the last two years or so was alcohol density work group, where people were trying to figure out how to disperse the amount of liquor stores that are in the inner beltway. And that was a community work group that we were a part of as well. And who led that work group? I'd have to. My gray matter, I'm a little bit older than I thought. Offline the final report. I'd be interested in that. Absolutely. Yeah, I would like to see that as well. And one more question, because we're kind of sparking those questions. So do you all also provide entertainment permits as well as the liquor license? Yes. So there's only a couple of different types of establishments that are allowed to have entertainment. That is the majority of our licensees. There's about 340 of them. There's about 145 liquor stores. And then we have something called a b, which is a restaurant that might have a packaged goods store or a liquor store attached to it. Okay, so that's a b. We will begin with our analyst today, mister Stover. Thank you, madam chair. Once again, my name is Andrew Stover, analyst for the Office of Budget and Policy Analysis. Here to present to you the FY 2025 budget for the Office of Central Services, as well as the Office of Procurement. So, just to start out, I want to talk about the fact that with executive order number 220 24, the agencies of Central Services and procurement will be separated beginning in FY 2025. And so when the budgets were submitted, they were submitted separately as a budget for the Office of Central Services and then a budget for the Office of Procurement. So if you look at the budgets, it's going to be split. I think it's good to have a context around this change. And so on the second page of the report, you can see the combined budget for the Office of Procurement and Office of Central Services to show what the change would have been if they had stayed as one entity. And there you can see that the Office of Procurement and the Office of Central Services have a combined budget of 47.5 million, which is a decrease of around 1 million, or 2% from the Office of Central Services FY 2024 approved budget. Moving on to specifically the Office of Central Services, you can see that the budget proposal they have is 25 million, which is a 21.5% decrease from the FY 2024 approved budget. This increase, sorry, this decrease being mainly due to the separation of the Office of Procurement. They have 36 employees that they're sending to the Office of Procurement, as well as operating costs as well. Compensation is proposed at $9.7 million, which is about a decrease of $3.5 million. Once again, as a result of the 36 employees being moved as of March 2024, the office has reported 34 vacancies. 16 of those vacancies are for funded positions. If you want to see a closer look at what those positions are and what the status of those positions were as of March 2024, you can take a look at attachment a of the first round budget responses. And I'll just add that one challenge that OCS has pointed out to us is just continued challenge of attrition and vacancies that have strained staff capacity. And the budget for over time has also notably increased to reflect historical costs, which you can see on page four that the overtime budget increases from 300,000 to 400,000. Historical costs have showed that it has been around 400,000. It's projected to be maybe 330,000 for FY 2024. And that's why that proposed budget is increasing 100,000 more dollars to reflect those historical costs. And the need for overtime is driven by the need for emergency requests and various repairs that must be made before and after regular hours. So it is a necessary cost in the budget when it comes to operating expenses. They are proposed for ocs at $13.3 million, which is a decrease of 15.4% or $2.4 million. The major line items that you can see are operating contracts and building repair maintenance. Both of those are over $1 million. In the case of operating contracts, it's $9 million. For a look at what operating contracts that they have, you can take a look at attachment b to the first round responses. On page six you can see a look at the information technology projects that they have going on. There are a number of projects that they continue to work on to make their systems more efficient and make staffing a bit easier or make things a bit easier for the staff in terms of workload. Finally, when it comes to workload and program key points, I just want to point out that the county space and facilities continue to grow. The office has looked towards prioritizing the most critical projects with its ten year facilities master plan and you can find that in attachment g to the first round responses to see what their high or critical needs are and that kind of guides how they're budgeting for the next ten years. Also, just that wanted to add that the county, as I said, spacey grown. They have real property value of they estimate around $705 million. The expenses that are new include three new positions. So 36 positions transferred and there will be three new positions. These positions being a chief procurement officer or director, an associate director of administration and a human resources analyst. Some other increases you can see in the operating expenses are increases that are temporary for the cost of setting up operating procedures for the office and temporary staffing. That is going to cost, I believe around $344,000 is what they estimated for us in terms of information technology projects. They are still working on improving speed, which is their acquisition platform, their procurement software platform, specifically with the life supplier lifecycle platform that will help them stream supplier performance evaluation and supplier registration. And office is looking to implement this module in 2024, FY 2024 and FY 2025. As far as workload and key performance indicators here you can see a lot of the data on page eleven and page twelve of the report has some really important data as far as contracts that have been awarded the status of the businesses that are being awarded these contracts. In terms of minority business enterprises, county based businesses and small businesses generally, the office has continued to meet the requirements and in many cases exceed the requirements for distribution of projects for these groups. I want to move on next to the internal service fund, for which is the fleet management fund, and there is no change in the proposed budget, but it does include funding for a new position and some increased overtime, while also cost per vehicle repair and maintenance continue to rise. So you can see, if you turn to page 14, a breakdown of their operating expenses, which is around $5.7 million, a 1.1% increase from 2024. The two biggest line item expenses that they have are vehicle equipment repair and maintenance for $4.1 million and other operating equipment repair maintenance for $496,000. And a part of this reason is these costs keep going up is because maintenance has become a really important part of what fleet management is doing as it has been particularly difficult for them to secure new vehicles even after they have passed. What is the current recommendations for replacement standards? And if you look in the program points here, you can actually see that 40%. It's estimated that 40% of the fleet currently exceeds the vehicle standards, the replacement standards, and this is due to costs. With inflation, costs are going up. But there are other significant challenges that the office continues to face that has made it extremely hard to secure new vehicles in a timely manner. So one example is that as of April 2024, the office has experienced wait times of more than six months for approximately 117 vehicles, some of these vehicles being ordered way back in September. So we see that there is a big delay that is happening and that is affecting the department and is also contributing to increased maintenance costs as a result. One other impact that it is having is on the Green Fleet initiative. You can see some highlights of the Green Fleet initiative on page 17 of the report. But in terms of the impacts that these challenges are having when it comes to police interceptor utility hybrids and rolling those out, there have been a shortage of battery materials which has led to no clear timelines for the delivery from auto manufacturers on when the police are going to be able to secure these videos. And then also so with just the miscellaneous ev's and hybrids that the office has. Again, the three battery shortages have made it hard to secure vehicles with some orders being canceled or delayed indefinitely. And in the meantime, the office has had to turn to going back to vehicles that primarily rely on gas and oil. Finally, the last part of the budget is the special Revenue fund for the Collington center that is budgeted at $5,000 for FY 2025, and a list of the Collington center parcels that are remaining to be sold can be found in attachment m of the first round responses. The last part of the budget is the capital improvement program portion. I won't go through every single project, but I do want to highlight some of the projects that have seen changes. But to give you an overview, the entire total of all the projects existing right now, which are 22 different projects. That's a decrease of two projects from last year and the total is $751 million. When it comes to FY 2025, the funding is approximately $45 million. On page 19 we start,

Very, very concerned about that, and would like to, you know, to understand how we could, you know, make some adjustments or something to at least do some upgrades to some of the facilities, because I get calls in my office all the time about it and the state of the facilities, as well as, you know, people on the brink of homelessness and looking for a place to go and people needing a place to go. So it's tough, and, you know, the beds are always occupied. So I feel like there's something. I don't know if we have to think outside the box. I don't know what that looks like, but, you know, that definitely needs to be a priority for us in some capacity. Mister early, did you have. Yes, I just wanted to correct something I said a minute ago. So the ARPA money was shifted to other places, and $8 million of bond money was moved into the homeless shelter projects. All right, thank you. Also wanted to find out, I know here it mentioned that you were expecting ambulances to come in in April. Have those been received yet? I will check as soon, as soon as I leave here, because I saw that as well, just to make sure those deliveries have come in, and we'll follow up on that. Okay. Because it would have been on backorder for quite some time, along with a couple of other emergency vehicles. Okay, great. Last question. In regards to the 13 funded vacancies, what barriers are you finding in regards to those vacancies? I know you mentioned about the trades, the people not getting into the trades anymore, but I wanted to find out if there were other barriers to funding those. No, I think some of the other barriers are common to some of the other jurisdictions, just the competition, the job market, where folks, we are seeing that when we look at our compensation structure sometimes may not be the highest, but it's certainly competitive. But I think it's still a competitive job market and we still have just some hard to fill positions just based on the scope of those positions. When you look at building engineers or building electricians, they have to be licensed and certified. And so there's a good deal of investment that a person has to make in him or herself in order to get to that level. But I think we're down considerably. Again, as I mentioned, with the 6% vacancy and getting down to 13, and not all 13 are building folks. Jumping in to staffing, I think that is a really essential, you know, part of this agency. Attrition and vacancies continue to have an impact on the office and its ability to comply with council mandates in a timely manner. Another thing I just wanted to point out with staffing is that they currently have five vacancies, and in the past year, there has been five employee separations, which is an attrition rate of about 7%. Reasons for separation have include retirement, transfer to other agencies, and also other job opportunities. One thing to know is that right now, a full 57 of current staff has ten or more years of service at the agency, which is great, but it has become a challenge for them to, you know, try and get young people that can continue that important work and make sure they're trained appropriately to be able to do that. Moving on, when it comes to operating expenses, the budget is proposed at $1.5 million, which is an increase of 3%, or about $44,000. By far, the biggest portion of their budget comes from office automation and then also operating contracts as well. All but three line items in this operating budget show increases over the previous year, but the biggest increase that we see here is only $43,000 increase in office automation to align with projected costs that are provided by OIT. When it comes to recoveries. You can see that information on page five. Recoveries total around $4.7 million, representing an increase of 288,000. And on page six, you can see a rundown of what projects they have working on in information technology. They have a project that they're in the process of implementing to migrate a new version of Kronos and a new treasury system. A more important project that has been in the works for a number of years now is the new treasury system that they want to implement. This is a project that is seen as extremely important to the office and how it functions. Right now, the county is operated on an outdated system, what they call a legacy system, which does pose a number of risks for the county. And when it comes to collecting sources like property tax, all of that information is contained in there. And so we want to make sure that this system is going to uphold. And so there is a project to bring in a new system, but the implementation of that has already seen multiple delays, and the go live date is once again being pushed back to spring 2024 from previously, it was spring. Sorry, spring 2025. Previously, it was spring 2024. The office sites that the main reason for this is having, you know, other mandates that they have had to comply with, such as the elderly property tax credit, any other tax credits. They do need what they call a quiet system in the run up and make sure that they have adequate staff resources to roll this program out. But despite the urgent need for the system, the office does maintain that further requirements put upon the office could delay that project even further back. And some additional risks that they have as well are that the main people that they have working on this project and implementation right now is currently two retired employees that are working on a part time basis to get this done. So if any of them was to separate from the agency, that could also cause some setbacks as well. When it comes to the fair election fund, the funding proposed there is $800,000.01. Thing I just want to point out is that funding is not expected to be provided at the level that the Fair Elections Fund commission believes that it will need. The commission has expressed that they think they need level of $3.6 million. And in the talks with the Office of Management Budget, there was the sense that we weren't told exactly how much it would be for the program, but there was a sense that this program will not get close to that number that is needed before the 2026 election starts that the commission thinks is needed for this program. The final thing I wanted to touch on, on page seven and eight is risk management. And you can see at the bottom of page seven the fund balance that exists for risk management. It is currently a funding debt of 225 million for FY 24, which represents a decrease of six, 0.3 million. And accident injury claims for FY 2024 are expected to slightly decrease. But the Office of Finance and OMB continue to work together to try and stop this deficit from getting any worse. But right now, there's no current plans to pay off any sort of lump sums to get that number down. Even more, you can see a breakdown of accident and injury claims from 2023 and 2024 on page eight. We have the three divisions here within the Office of Finance, the administration division, the treasury division and the accounting division. It's the down arrow. Okay. All right. And the administration division. Just some of the functions we do there. We do the debt management, the risk management, general administration and financial systems. Under the general administration, we have that new program added there, the fair elections fund commission support. In our accounting division, they're responsible for accounting and reporting. The accounts receivable function is there, as well as the accounts payable function, which gets a lot of traction with vendor payments and vendor related questions. Been pretty involved with the pandemic relief efforts and as far as payments to all the participants in that program. And of course in accounting, we also have payroll, the payroll function as well. In our treasury division we have our tax billing and collections group, our cash management group, which handles a $2 billion investment portfolio. We have our tax administration, who handles the billing and collection compliance efforts, our customer service group and our revenue collections group. Now just a brief discussion about some of the things that we have accomplished in 24 or will accomplish in 24. We had the successful launch of the Elderly property tax credit implement program in fiscal 24. That was quite an undertaking, very popular program with 25,000 applicants. And of the those applicants we had about 23,000 who were eligible and about 25% of them, some 6000 receiving credits in the amount of $2.2 million there. We are also underway with the implementation of the Public Safety Officer Real Property Tax Credit, which is effective this coming July, and it will provide up to $2,500 of county property tax credit. We're partnering with agencies for various communications around that and setting up an online portal where we can efficiently implement that particular program. Our Fair Elections Fund Commission launch was successfully accomplished by our office. We are meeting every second Wednesday of every month and the efforts there are on the way a very engaged commission, somewhat out of our bailiwick as far as what the Office of Finance does, but we have successfully launch that effort and as Stanley mentioned, there's some 800,000 that will be appropriated in fiscal 25, available in fiscal 25 for that effort. The next thing I wanted to discuss is our cyber captive self insurance strategy program. We have effectively and successfully set up a captive self insurance program for cyber security or cyber type claims. What was happening in the regular program was that we were paying quite a bit of premiums and retention money would have to go out the door if there was, if there were a claim and before we got the first dollar reimbursement from the insurers, we could have paid up to some $4 million before we were even able to get first dollar insurance. So what we did was set up a self insurance captive where that the county can contribute to that cell, captive cell and then retain the money and build equity in that to fund any potential claims. So that is a win for a risk management program. Additionally, we in the risk management area, we have our safety off

On our debt management front, we've also successfully did the water quality subsidized loan for stormwater mitigation. A $65 million loan was done there over the 30 year term and the interest rates can't be beat. It's a 1.8% interest rate there and over a 20 year term. That saves accounting in just raw debt service payments, some $32.3 million with the NPV savings over the 30 year period with a ten year tail on the water quality loan NPV there of $10.6 million. Additionally, some other things that are being launched in 24 is the launch of a streamline unclaimed property communication outreach where we'll be communicating with those who we have paid, but yet they have not cashed their checks on claimed property. And then as a result of that, the money would have to then be over to the state. So what we're going to do is increase the communication to this group through postcards and also additionally we'll be attempting to do increased communication with our vendor community about direct deposit availability within the county to avoid any kind of delays in payment. And in our treasury group, we have language access compliance. We have effectively launched that. We've translated documents. We are getting good feedback from sister agencies on the effectiveness of our program there and just making sure that we have language access to our community for those who speak other languages other than English. I'm going to hand over to Linda to just talk about our strategic focus for fiscal 25. Thank you. Thanks, Steve. As Andrew and Steve both mentioned, we are really a very lean agency. We have ongoing responsibilities for, you know, providing key government activities. And then periodically, we're required to perform additional state and county mandated programs and initiatives. And it's why our FY 25 strategy really does focus on people and technology and innovation. And so we'll continue to enhance our team, implement the public safety officer tax credit, and we'll move into our second year of the senior tax credit, as well as ramp up for the 2026 election by staffing our fair election or the Fair Election Fund Commission. We'll continue to work with OIT to develop and deploy a new tax billing and collection system, and we'll work with our actuary, our claims administrator, and OMB to identify ways to decrease expenses and add more resources where we can to improve the health of our risk management fund. Our first strategy really does focus on our staffing and filling vacancies. We know we have to fill them with the right people, mainly because most of our staff, as Andrew even mentioned earlier, most of our staff has been with the agency over ten years. Most of our staff is over 55, so they can retire. And as you know, when long term employees retire, it's very difficult to replace them with someone who is experienced and who really can do the job effectively off the bat. So it really does make it somewhat difficult and challenging for us. And while we all know the value and benefit of working for county government, I don't know that we've really done a great job of letting millennials and Gen Z'ers realize the importance and the benefits of working for county government. So that's something that we want to definitely put more emphasis on, is really putting out there kind of the benefits of working for county government. But in the meantime, the employees that we do have, we know that we need to continue to develop them, that we need to encourage them to continue to participate in professional organizations and even get certifications. And we have done much more of that in the last few years, and we'll continue to do that in the coming years. chunks.text: So the next two slides I'm going to pass on to Cindy because she can talk about the elderly property tax credit and the tax system. Thank you and good morning again. Thank you and good morning again. So, for the elderly property tax credit, which went into effect in July, you've heard a little bit of this already. Going into the next year, that value for the assessed property cap is going up by the lesser of the 3% or CPI. So it goes to 515,000 for new applicants coming into the next fiscal year. In our implementation, we had, I think, 73% of those who applied were eligible, but were already receiving 20% from their homeowners or home homestead. So that put us at about the 25% or so that actually received a credit. And this is for those who have been in their home for at least ten years, for those who are over 65 and then also has the limit on their assessed value. We worked with partners in creating flyers and distributing them. We had enrollment days where we also had a staff member who was a spanish speaker. So we had citizens able to come on site for three different blocks of time. And we were really. We were really just completely inundated by the response to this. Most of those applicants were paper. So also in handling and having to put things in, in a manual fashion, we are working right now on putting out a postcard that we will send out to anyone who was determined to be eligible, whether they received a credit or not, because they don't need to apply again, will have the ability to rerun those people in our system for each year going forward until they've actually received a credit, five years total. So, you know, as long as they are already eligible, they don't need to reapply. And we really are hoping that we can get that message out. So there's, you know, we have many, many calls that come through our customer service line of citizens feeling like they need to apply again because they didn't get the credit, but they were eligible. So we're also working on getting that onto our online system where they can go on and look up there where you can normally go on and look up your bill, and you'll be able to see there that you are eligible if you have already met the criteria. So that would be a huge benefit for us and not having to go through that. So we also will be participating again this year with the Department of Family services. They have an annual senior information fair. We'll be there with staff on site on May 14 14th, and we'll have staff there with computers that will be able to assist those who have not yet applied, that would be able to also apply at that time. And, yeah, so we're closely monitoring for any changes going forward as well on that credit and then on our tax billing system. Just a couple clarifications to make. The two staff members that we have that are working, that are retired and working part time, they are the key people managing our mainframe system, which is what we're currently using in order to create the bills and manage tax sale and all of those functions. They're critical in also the knowledge transfer. There are three to four developers at a given time working on the new system, and other several other IT staff members that are working on the development of this system. We have made significant progress on it. The elderly property tax credit is the most recent delay to our moving forward and being able to make the progress that we had anticipated originally. And so, just to be clear, the original delays were the fact that we're working on this during COVID So many of those it resources were redirected to developing systems for vaccinations and for the health department, and they've had turnover. So all of these things contribute to delays on our being able to move forward. The system that we're working on right now is a mainframe built in the eighties, as you heard. For fiscal year 2024. The office reports that the engineer series classification and compensation audit was completed and updates to the classification plan are being prepared for modification. Additionally, the office reports that it has completed occupation studies for the Office of Law, county Attorney and state Attorney series and the results are under reviewed by the respective agencies. Also, the office reports that the county is currently in collective bargaining negotiations with all ten bargaining units for fiscal year 2025 through fiscal year 2027. HR partnered to obtain several million dollars in federal funds for the summer youth employment program, helping young people develop a strong work ethic and learn to work in a professional environment.
The HR department is focusing on digitization and automation to improve efficiency and move away from paper-based processes.
HR is working on performance metrics for employees to set realistic, specific goals and ensure managers are involved in the process.
The Office of Information Technology (OIT) has been commended for their assistance in helping county agencies with digitization and automation.
The Health Department has significantly improved its ability to fill positions quickly in the past six months, which has been a long-standing struggle.

Do you hold, do you wait until you receive all candidates until it closes before you push the candidate information over to the agency? We do, yes. So there's really five or six phases that we have broken down and this is how we track it. So the first phase is creating the posting that's on HR. The agency reaches out to us and says, hey, we want to hire an engineer. Then we do the job. Advertisement working with the agency again to make sure that we have the lingo right, whatever it is, consistent with the class spec. Then once the candidates come in, we wait until the job is closed, meaning the posting is closed. Then there's the evaluation of the candidates, and that's on HR as well, meaning do they meet the minimum quality? Sometimes we work with our agencies. If it's a rather large number of applicants, like, do you want us, how do you want us to look at this and screen this? Or do you just want all 73 applicants? Sometimes the agency wants to go through all of them. Sometimes they want us to look for certain key attributes, like this amount of experience, or they have this in their background. Once we're done with that phase, it shifts over to the agency. So then you're in phases, you know, four and five, which is you go into the screening, what we call screening. But that's the interview process. The agency handles that. They do the scheduling. They pull together the interview panel, they pull together the interview questions. We're there as a resource if they need us. And then it ultimately boils down to they. However, it works, because many agencies do a two step process. So you'll have your hiring managers maybe recommend two or three candidates to the director, and then the director will want to interview the top two or three candidates. So if you're doing a two step process, that adds in a layer. Not all agencies do it that way. Some do, some do it only for upper level positions. And then it's at that point where they communicate back to HR that this is the preferred candidate, this is the salary we want to offer, and then we do that analysis to make sure it's consistent with the county regulations. So all of that breaks down to our target is 87 days. And many agencies, I can tell you in this last quarter, are beating that. You know, like, I can look at the Department of Social Services. So our biggest agency is public safety. They have multiple people helping them. And also because they have the background check issue and all of that, smaller agencies like the Office of law that has 50 or 60 people, they may have one individual that does not only their budget, their it, but also their HR. That's to include the background and medical process. So it really, it's a large, you start off with a large volume to get down to a small volume, unfortunately. Right. So one of the things we have proposed, and we are, I think as HR, we have not necessarily landed on the solution to this, but we want to give candidates a window. So that way 50 candidates go through fire school or 50 candidates go through the police training. And that's just been, they usually wait till they get enough candidates to schedule that class, and we hear the same thing, that we're losing candidates so what we're proposing, and again, this is all in the proposal stage, is that we provide candidates with a specific window. If you apply between, we're just going to say January 1 and March 31, you're going to go into the class that's scheduled April 1. If you apply between April 1 and June 1, you're going to go into the class that's scheduled July 1. We're going to pick class dates in advance, and no matter how many people we get, we're going to move forward so that way we don't lose those recruits. The recruits have a sense of, okay, I've applied in this time frame. If I make it through the background, I will be in this class. That would be great. When do you plan to kind of implement? So we are in discussions with all of our partners now. Our test is really, we are working with corrections, the sheriffs first crossing guards. Those are our first group of priorities. We are working with police and fire, but because they are the much larger agencies, we're working with them, and it's going to take a little more time. Right. We had the police department as well as the Office of Human Resources management probably over provided over requirements. We tested more than what we needed to test in the medical. We did more backgrounds than we needed to do. And so we took a look at our process first. We looked at our class specification to determine the eligibility requirements, and we did modify that based on benchmarking and community standards. There was no need to really have a crossing guard at a certain age or have a driver's license or have other requirements own a vehicle or anything of that nature. Those were just some artificial barriers that had already, has always been in the process, which we were able to remove out of the process. Then we looked at our medical standards and we looked at what was required by state, and that is the requirements that we're using. And so that might be more important to the person when they make that decision about the different choices that each company offers. I understand we have Kaiser, but, you know, that's a one stop shop, you know, and I get the reason why, but you only have one other choice. I did note in our justification statement that under the new zoning ordinance, the standard size parking space is nine by 18, which is what we are proposing here. And that's also a standard that's been adopted pretty regionally by a lot of jurisdictions, including Montgomery county. So nine by 18 is by no means a substandard sized space, but it does provide that extra flexibility to make sure that we have adequate circulation within the parking lot. And then the final thing that I would like to note is included in our justification statement. It just so happens that in 2021, Maryland National Capital park and Planning Commission did a study parking needs in this Tacoma Langley park area, and they concluded that the commercial businesses in that area were adequately parked. If you look at any aerial photograph of this area, you'll see large parking lots serving the existing commercial uses. One of the concerns expressed by the owners at that time was with the knowledge that the purple line was coming, what impact that would have on the parking and their need to reconfigure their parking lots. Well, and that's exactly what Mister Beagleman is doing through this application. But that's not the case. The mere fact that the state acquired that property and resulted in this reduction in the parking lot size, it's his responsibility to fix it. If it drops his parking below the the mandatory requirement, he's got either find a way to create more parking or obtain a waiver, which is what we're doing today. So the approval of the waiver will allow the shopping center to continue to operate with adequate parking that is safely accessible and will also result in an improvement of the shopping center.
